PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from 32 citizens), Mr Fife (from 102 citizens) and Mr Snow (from 101 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from 19 citizens) and Mr Fitzgibbon (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising on Radio and Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Jull (from 36 citizens), Mr Reid (from 65 citizens) and Mr Reith (from 46 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD, we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth'' and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``humbly relying upon the Blessings of Almighty God . . .''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The Adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Simmons (from 12 citizens) and Dr Bob Woods (from 28 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that ratification of United Nations Conventions, such as the above, by the Federal Government, without Parliamentary debate or consultation with the people through a referendum, is a gross abuse of the Australian Constitution and is contrary to democratic principles;
2. that the Convention's philosophy of parent/child relationships is based on a false premise and embodies the totalitarian principles of State ownership of children;

3. that the Christian principle of parental authority is essential for the proper functioning of society, but phrases in the Convention implying parents' rights are virtually meaningless, with escape clauses permitting the widest of interpretation;
4. that Articles 12 to 16 giving children the right to seek, think, say and be whatever, where ever and with whom they wish violates the common sense of any normal parent;
5. that some Articles contradict other Articles and imprecise wording adds to the confusion by providing loopholes for the protection of paedophiles and certain types of child traffickers;

6. that some of the proposed rights are inappropriate for immature child minds and have no logical connection with the protection of children from abuse or deprivation, such protection being already provided by existing Australian laws.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate or provide for:
(a) a twelve month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles;
(b) a referendum to follow the Moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Baltic States
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Soviet troops have been killing innocent civilians in the Baltic States and, more generally, that the continuing unprovoked use of force in the Baltic States by the Soviet Union is contrary to the human rights of individuals as well as to the rights of self-determination of the Baltic peoples and therefore requests that you condemn this action and urge the Australian Government to implement trade sanctions and to suspend relief action to the USSR.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble.
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
1. By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Hostel Care Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
(a) The signatories express deep concern that the hostel care subsidy for non-financially disadvantaged persons will be abolished as from January 1991:
(b) This budget decision will cause hardship to residents of hostels; or
(c) Will seriously damage the financial stability of hostels forcing many to make callous decisions in regard to hostel residents.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives will call on the Government to reinstigate the hostel care subsidy for nonfinancially disadvantaged persons.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia expressing complete opposition to the banning of political advertising, and regard any ban as:
a denial of the freedom of speech;
promoting the government in power by allowing the continuation of government department advertising;
a guise to cover a move toward massive direct-mail campaigns which will make the removal of sitting members a virtual impossibility.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. The Parliament rejects any move to abolish political advertising; and

2. Parliament enacts legislation to abolish public funding of political parties, which costs taxpayers up to $13 million each election, and acts to artificially boost expenditure on political advertising.

PETITION.TITLE: Archerfield Airfield Fire Fighting Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. As residents of the State of Queensland, we wish to bring notice to The House, of the Civil Aviation Authority decision to withdraw the Fire Fighting Service from Archerfield Airport and we hereby request The House that this Fire Fighting Service be retained at Archerfield.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coat of Arms
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth their concern that proper protection be afforded both the Australian Coat of Arms and the present Australian national flag. It respectfully requests that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will take legislative action to protect the present Australian Coat of Arms and National flag along the lines of existing legislation which protects the word `ANZAC'.
The petition further requests that in any legislation the House of Representatives ensures that:
1. Penalties are provided for the unlawful use of the Australian Coat of Arms in any commercial undertaking without seeking the approval of the relevant Minister.

2. It is an offence to assist knowingly in any act to deface, defame or denigrate the Australian national flag, or any Armed Force or Merchant Marine ensign with a penalty of no less than $500.00 and/or three months imprisonment for any such offence.
3. The offence of destroying or burning the flag or emblem provide for a fine of not less than $1,000.00 or six months imprisonment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forest, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Otway Rainforests are being exploited inappropriately. We pray that the export woodchip licence supplied for Midway Wood Products be rescinded immediately and the Otway Rainforests be managed in the best interests of the people of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could, if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia draws to the attention of the House our concern with particular aspects of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child in that some of the Articles of the Convention, as they are presently drafted, do not recognise the rights and responsibilities of parents towards their children and may diminish the parent/child relationship.
Namely, the Convention declares that children have the right to ``freedom of expression'', a right described as including:
``. . . .freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print . . .''.
The Convention declares the right of ``freedom of association and freedom of peaceful assembly''.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take action to have the Convention amended to give adequate recognition to the rights and duties of parents with respect to the education as well as the physical, social and moral development of their children.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i) call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.
(ii) call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.

PETITION.TITLE: Jobst Garments: Medicare Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
1. There is no rebate under Medicare for the cost of special pressure dressing suits``Jobst Garments'' used to flatten scar tissue of burns victims.

2. That``Jobst Garments'' are beneficial in relieving the discomfort and itching experienced while scar tissue is fresh and that the compression by the garment helps minimise functional disability caused by scar contraction.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to do everything in its power to provide a Medicare rebate for ``Jobst Garments''.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ROMANIA, GREECE AND LONDON

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Romania, Greece and London, November 1990. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I present the report of the Committee entitled Follow the Yellow Brick Road-The Final Report on an Efficiency Audit of the Australian Taxation Office: International Profit Shifting, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which I have tabled today is the third report by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on its inquiry into international profit shifting. In the previous Parliament the Committee tabled two reports on this inquiry, namely Shifting the Tax Burden? and Tax Payers or Tax Players. The first report dealt with aspects of the administration while the second report focused on tax havens. The second report acted as a catalyst for the introduction of legislation dealing with tax havens just last year.

SPEECH.PARA: In this third report the Committee has focused on the issue of tax avoidance arising from the withholding tax provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Those provisions deal with a tax which is withheld from interest and dividends earned within Australia by non-residents. In the report the Committee also has considered aspects of the cash transactions reporting system relevant to international profit shifting.

The Committee's interest in investigating the withholding tax area arose as a result of allegations made by Melbourne academic Ms Barbara Smith. Ms Smith alleged that Australian residents were establishing arrangements which took advantage of the low rate of interest withholding tax to reduce and even avoid their income tax obligations. During the inquiry, it became evident that the withholding tax area has been left to float in the backwater of taxation administration and policy. Treasury officials told the Committee that no formal review of withholding tax rates had been conducted since the system was introduced in 1967. Australian Taxation Office representatives advised of the lesser priority directed to the withholding tax area, as compared with other areas of taxation administration.

The Committee itself gained first-hand experience of this during inspections in Melbourne and Sydney. The Committee came to the conclusion that the low priority accorded to the withholding tax area, coupled with a lack of adequate administrative controls, had been important factors contributing to the abuse of the withholding tax provisions identified to the Committee.

In its task the Committee was not distracted by the debate which ensued about the amount of taxation revenue which may have been lost as a result of tax avoidance arrangements established to take advantage of the withholding tax provisions. It considered that the problem was significant enough to warrant attention and, accordingly, directed its efforts towards determining how best to deal with the problem.

In this regard the Committee has made a number of substantial recommendations aimed at strengthening the legislative and administrative framework for combating tax avoidance in this area. It has also addressed some of the broader issues relating to the equity of the taxation system which were identified during the inquiry.

One of the primary considerations for the Committee was the appropriateness of retaining the existing 10 per cent rate of interest withholding tax. The Committee found that one consequence of the existing low rate for non-residents is that it has provided some Australian residents with a potential to establish arrangements aimed at reducing and even evading their income tax obligations.

The Committee considered proposals to increase the rate of interest withholding tax across the board and to have differential rates of withholding tax applying to countries with which Australia has and has not entered into double taxation agreements. However, from the evidence it received, the Committee was unable to evaluate in detail the full economic implications of these proposals and, in particular, the impact which they would have on Australia's ability to attract foreign investment.

The Committee, nevertheless, is concerned that greater attention has not been focused previously on whether the withholding tax rates which were set in the 1960s are still in the best interests of Australia. Accordingly, we have recommended that the Industry Commission conduct a comprehensive review of the withholding tax system as part of its existing inquiry into the availability of capital. The particular matters which need to be addressed in that review are detailed in the report.

Pending the outcome of the Industry Commission's review, the Committee has recommended a discretionary power for the Commissioner of Taxation, which would allow the Commissioner to impose the top marginal rate of tax, rather than the withholding tax rate, in cases where the Commissioner has reason to believe that the interest income derived by a non-resident from an Australian source relates to an arrangement established by an Australian resident for tax avoidance purposes.

In the report the Committee also has addressed the concerns which were raised about discretionary trusts being a principal vehicle for tax avoidance involving the withholding tax provisions. The Committee considered that the use of discretionary trusts for purely tax avoidance purposes is a negative consequence of the differing approaches which have been adopted towards the taxation of trusts and corporations. We therefore indicated that there is a need for fundamental reform in this area by recommending that there should be a move towards a system of taxing trusts and corporations in a uniform manner.

The implementation of this recommendation may take time because of the need to consider the broader economic and social implications which may arise as a consequence. In the interim, to address the issue of tax avoidance through trusts the Committee has recommended the removal of the tax advantages which can accrue in arrangements which rely on the streaming of interest income through a trust to a non-resident.

A further allegation raised in the Committee and addressed in the report involved the use of overseas charities in tax avoidance arrangements. It was claimed that schemes are operating whereby trust distributions to overseas charities are returned ultimately to the original donor. The net effect of the schemes was purported to be a lowering of the resident trust tax liability. However the Committee did not receive substantial evidence that overseas charity schemes are being perpetrated in Australia on any significant scale. Nevertheless, we became aware that there are concerns within the Tax Office about the potential for tax avoidance in this area. To address these concerns the Committee recommended the introduction of a specific anti-avoidance measure aimed at eradicating the potential for tax avoidance hidden in the guise of donations to charities.

In relation to withholding tax administration, the Committee was concerned particularly about the adequacy of the existing procedures for verifying that those who claimed to be non-residents are actually non-residents. We agree with the Tax Office that the exemption for non-residents from the new tax file number requirements is a problem which needs to be addressed and to remedy the situation the Committee has recommended that the tax file number system be modified to incorporate non-resident verification procedures. Additionally, we have recommended that as part of the non-resident verification procedure the Tax Office should seek to identify those non-residents acting in the capacity of trustee for Australian residents.

Another consideration for the Committee was the Tax Office's ability to gather evidence from overseas. In this regard we have recommended that taxation agreements with countries which have comparable taxation regimes to Australia be pursued actively, that anti-treaty shopping provisions be included in taxation agreements and that Tax Office representatives be posted overseas to facilitate information exchanges.

In the report the Committee also highlighted the importance of prosecution action as a weapon against tax avoidance arrangements. We have recommended that prosecutions should be pursued vigorously against both the promoters of and participants in tax avoidance arrangements and such prosecutions should be publicised widely.

The final chapter of the report deals with the Cash Transactions Report Act. This inquiry is the first opportunity which the Parliament has had to review aspects of the cash transactions reporting system since its introduction. The reporting system was established to inhibit tax evasion, money laundering and other fraud and crime. We have recognised that the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA) provides a valuable source of information for the Tax Office and law enforcement agencies in their efforts to combat tax evasion and crimes, but one deficiency was identified. The reporting system focuses on cash movements in transactions, not on telegraphic and wire transfer of funds overseas. As these telegraphic transfers are the most appropriate means by which funds from Australia are channelled overseas the Committee considers that the capture and analysis of telegraphic transfer data would add a significant dimension to the information available to the Tax Office and law enforcement agencies. We are pleased to see that on the advice of the Attorney-General the Cash Transaction Reports Agency has commenced investigation into the possibility of including an existing arrangement to monitor the telegraphic transfers and therefore to report back through that agency.

Clearly this report presents a number of substantial recommendations aimed at combating deficiencies identified by the Committee in the withholding cash and cash transaction reporting systems. I take this opportunity to thank my fellow members of the subcommittee appointed to conduct the inquiry, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) and the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear). I additionally thank the subcommittee secretary, Mr Andres Lomp and our very good friend and adviser Mr Lawrie Hill, a secondee from the Australian Taxation Office, and also Ms Laura Gillies who was responsible for typing the report.

With the tabling of the Committee's third report on this subject area, the Committee is in a position to conclude that for some the road of international profit shifting truly is paved with gold. Implementation of the Committee's recommendations in this report, however, will ensure that those who choose to follow the yellow brick road at least will have to pay the appropriate toll. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report tabled by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) contains very substantial recommendations. Their urgent implementation is essential if our tax laws are to be fair to Australians and foreigners, as well as being fair as between Australians. The report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration contains 21 recommendations. Many of them call for improvement in the administrative arrangements of the Tax Office and the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. These recommendations can all be read in the report. Because of the limited time available to me I will not comment or attempt to summarise these recommendations other than to say that the implementation of the administrative changes recommended will help to reduce the loss of revenue due to international profit shifting.

SPEECH.PARA: The report does, however, contain other recommendations, the implementation of which will involve the Government in decisions of a policy nature. These recommendations, if implemented, will have far reaching effects. I will now briefly comment on three issues dealt with by these policy related recommendations. First, I will deal with a call for a comprehensive review of the withholding tax system and the basis upon which we should enter double taxation agreements. Second, I will refer to the call for the taxation of trusts in the same manner as we tax corporations. Third, I will speak about the call for greater transparency with respect to the tax deductibility of qualifying donations and the exemptions from tax of trust income distributions to charities.

As to the first issue, the Committee has recommended that Australia's tax withholding system be referred to the Industry Commission for a comprehensive review as part of its current inquiry into the availability of capital. It did this because it did not believe it had the time or the resources to go into all the ramifications of such matters as the appropriateness or otherwise of retaining the existing rate of withholding tax; the appropriateness or otherwise of having a common rate of interest withholding tax applied to interest income earned in Australia by non-residents living in tax treaty and non-treaty countries; the equity of tax sharing arrangements between Australia and other countries, particularly whether the primary right of taxation should be retained by the country of source of income; the equity of the tax treatment between residents and non-resident individual investors and between Australian owned and foreign owned enterprises; and, finally, the adequacy of the current thin capitalisation rules.

As a result of the consideration I have been able to give to these issues, my predisposition is that our approach to the taxation of Australian sourced income of non-residents should be based first upon the claim that we have the primary right to tax all income derived in Australia and, secondly, that the rate of withholding tax should be raised to a level equivalent to the corporate rate of tax, which rate should be reduced so that it is no more than 30c in the dollar. Thirdly, a lower rate of withholding tax should be payable on interest and unfranked dividends paid to investors resident in countries whose tax regimes are similar to our own. Fourthly, an even lower rate of withholding tax should be levied where the non-resident investor is resident of a country with which we have a comprehensive double taxation agreement. Fifthly, the existing double taxation agreements should be renegotiated and new agreements negotiated to provide us with the right to impose interest withholding tax up to a rate not exceeding 30c in the dollar. Except when varied by tax treaty, such a tax regime would enable us to remove the difference between the tax rates now imposed on company and other business entity profits and the much lower rate imposed on interest paid by those enterprises out of their pre-interest, pre-tax profits. I urge the Industry Commission to take careful note of the issues the Committee wants reviewed. I hope it will not be overwhelmed by the argument that we must attract foreign capital at any price.

There is no doubt that higher domestic savings must be encouraged and sustainable levels of foreign investment permitted. But profits, dividends and interest income sourced in Australia should be subject to the same tax burdens, whether the investor is resident in Australia or not. Any relief from this burden should be granted only either as a consequence of double tax agreements under which there is an acceptable quid pro quo in Australia's favour, or through explicit and costed tax rebates or rate reductions aimed at achieving economic outcomes which adequately benefit Australians.

I turn now to the second major recommendation of the report, namely, that we move to a standardisation of the tax treatment of all business income, whether the income is derived by a company or a trust. I think we should have a uniform taxing system for companies, trusts, partnerships and other forms of family arrangements and business activities, whether owned by, or operated for the benefit of, residents or non-residents of Australia.

The report of the Committee goes only so far as to recommend the taxation of trusts in a manner similar to corporations. This would involve extending the imputation system used in respect of company taxation to avoid the double taxation of taxed trust income. Such a change would take away the tax advantages now available to a privileged class of taxpayers who are in a position to arrange their affairs so as to move income through the most tax effective business vehicles and family arrangements. This behaviour is rational, legal behaviour and conforms with the court confirmed principle that no man in this country-as occurred in the United Kingdom, where the judgment of the court was given-is under the smallest obligation, moral or other, so to arrange his legal relations to his business or to his property as to enable the Tax Commissioner to put the largest possible shovel into his stores. But it is the responsibility of legislators and policy makers that, when circumstances warrant, they restore tax equity between those who are able to organise their affairs to be tax effective and those who cannot do so.

A uniform taxation system for companies and trusts, and eventually partnerships as well, and other vehicles used for conducting family arrangements and business activities would ensure that the vehicle is tax neutral to the individuals who ultimately benefit from the taxable activity. This can be achieved only when the primary rate of tax payable by all types of entities used in engaging in taxable activity is the same, and only when that rate coincides with the highest marginal rate payable by individuals. That means that the top marginal rate payable by an individual should be the same as the top corporate rate.

I wish to refer to those recommendations which relate to tax deductible gifts to charities and other organisations coming within the ambit of section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the distribution of trust income to charitable organisations within and without Australia. There is a need not only for the improvement of the administrative arrangements, but also for reform of the law under which tax deductibility can be claimed in respect of donations to charitable and other organisations, as well as reform of the law under which trust income distributions to charitable organisations overseas are exempted from tax.

It is important that policy makers have the information necessary to enable them to assess the appropriateness of existing mechanisms for supporting charities within the taxation system. I hope the implementation of the Committee's recommendations will establish this transparency. The time may then come when, in the interests of the many genuine organisations with tax deductible status and those who are equally genuine but have not been granted that status, the Tax Office will develop a program which will enable it to match donations claimed with those received. In the case of overseas charities, it may become necessary to limit the tax exempt status of distributions to charities to those in respect of which the tax authority of the countries in which they are based can provide regular verification that the funds so distributed are received by such charities and are used for a charitable purpose. It may be fairer to Australian taxpayers if such organisations were to be made subject to an approval process such as that required by overseas aid organisations in seeking tax deductibility.

I hope it will not be too long before the Parliament is asked to implement major reforms of our withholding tax arrangements, our double tax agreements, the law providing for tax deductibility or exemption of donations and distributions to charities, and especially to achieve uniformity in the approach to taxation of companies, trusts, partnerships and other like arrangements. I join the Chairman of the Committee in thanking members of the staff, Andres Lomp and Lawrie Hill, and hope that it will not be long before the recommendations are acted upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 April, on motion by Ms McHugh:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled The Injured Coastline-Protection of the Coastal Environment, comes before this House after an inquiry which received submissions from around Australia from almost every conceivable source. Moreover, Committee members were able to visit centres and see and hear at first hand what is happening to the Australian coastline. The message is clear: this Parliament has the responsibility for doing something about a problem that threatens the well-being of the coastline and waters that lap our shores and, as a result, the well-being of Australians and their environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate of Richmond, which I have the honour to represent, is, as honourable members know, one of the fastest growing areas in Australia. Indeed, the population of the north coast of New South Wales is predicted to reach over 700,000 by the year 2016, almost double the population of the 1986 census.

When the discussion paper which preceded this valuable report was released last year, my offices in Lismore and South Tweed were inundated with requests for copies of the paper. The requests came from all sections of the population-from environmental groups, local government, industry and developers. In all, over 200 requests for the paper were received. Following such a deluge of requests, the Committee visited Byron Bay.

The message that was repeated over and over again at those meetings by people was that they were sick to death of inquiries from governments and that they believed that now was the time for action. Developers also said that they would welcome clear guidelines, and that they were devastated by the rules imposed by local and State authorities continually changing.

It is clear that in some respects there has been a lack of political will by decision makers at the various levels of government to confront and deal with the problems of the coastal zone because they are so complex. What has occurred is that a host of small, ad hoc decisions have been made almost on the run by decision makers to deal with whatever happens to be the present pressure. We see over and over again the resulting impact on the environment from what has been aptly called the tyranny of small decisions.

Even when authorities set out to protect the coastal complex of wetlands and the life they sustain, the cumulative effects of many small decisions and many small developments have proved to be devastating to the environment. All of those pressures are upon the coastline right around Australia. They are present in my own electorate. The desire of people to live near the ocean continues to heap pressure upon pressure.

In my electorate of Richmond this has led to conflict between groups struggling for the preservation of unique sites and those groups who see those sites as development sites. Even now, at the mouth of the Richmond River, just to the south of my electorate, bulldozers are moving in to destroy what is virtually the last of the Aboriginal midden sites and what is stated to be a burial site at North Creek in Ballina. Further up the coast there is an ongoing battle to preserve the Fingal Peninsula from being lost to the people. Again, debate continues about whether a road should be built through the wetlands in order to allow fishermen assured access to the beach. Further north in the same area a quarry operates on a site which demands protection. These and similar situations have led to conflict between groups and ad hoc decisions have been made by those who have had the responsibility for making those decisions. The case for Commonwealth coordination could not be greater.

I want to clear up a misrepresentation of the report carried by some sections of the media. It was reported in the Telegraph Mirror on 12 April that a levy was to be struck to pay for a coastal clean-up. No such recommendation was made by the Committee in its report; rather, the Committee recommended that a national coastal management strategy be developed by the Commonwealth in cooperation with the States and Territories, which, with other features, would be incorporated into Federal coastal management legislation. There is no doubt in my mind that the public now demands action about the condition of the coast. As the Committee Chair said in her address to this House, the Commonwealth's activities in the coastal zone at present are ad hoc, uncoordinated and lacking in focus. This report is about redressing that situation.

The need for Commonwealth coordination could not be clearer when one considers the present situation in New South Wales. In that State, a report from a bipartisan upper House committee will recommend that the Greiner-Murray Government recognise and acknowledge the failings of the present coastal planning and management system in New South Wales. The Government of New South Wales is accused of lacking vision, but I would put it a different way: I would say that the Greiner-Murray Government has a vision for the coastline, but it is very different from the one the rest of us have. Those who know the north coast of New South Wales will remember the problems caused by the National Party's concrete proposals. That Party is hell-bent on development, no matter what the cost to the environment. It is clear that not all members of the Greiner-Murray Government are like Tim Moore. That is why the conflict will continue. There is no trust in what the New South Wales coalition Government will do. That leaves developers and environmentalists blaming each other when the cause of the conflict lies with the actions of the Government making the rules. Already the Premier of New South Wales has been reported as dismissing the recommendations of that report.

Management of the coastal zone is also a matter of growing international concern. A working group of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) is currently conducting a project on the integration of environmental considerations into coastal zone management in member countries. The Committee learned during the inquiry that a section of the south-east Tasmanian coast provided the Australian case study for the project. The OECD coastal group is, among other things, examining the desirability of national governments developing coordination mechanisms and overall policy guidelines for coastal management for regional and local government. It is worth while noting that the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts are in line with the general approach to coastal management likely to be taken by the OECD group.

The Committee has developed and maintained close contact with the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) regarding its inquiry into the coastal zone, and the report identifies areas which the Commission may wish to explore further. The Committee believes that coastal management initiatives by the Commonwealth should not await the report by the RAC inquiry into the coastal built environment. The Commission's report should be used to improve, direct, assist and guide such policies, structures and plans as are in place or are being prepared at the time of reporting.

I reiterate one recommendation of the Committee which I feel is most important and which, after the time spent on this report, goes to the crux of what the Committee members desire for action and where that action should come from. That recommendation is recommendation No. 12, which states:

Following preparation and development of a national coastal zone management strategy, the Commonwealth enact legislation which sets out a Federal interest in the coastal zone, agreed national objectives, agreed national and environment guidelines and standards-including standards for water quality and industrial waste discharge-and financial assistance schemes to assist the States and local government to formulate coastal management plans and policies that are consistent with the objectives and goals of the national strategy.

In conclusion, I thank the members of the Committee and the staff, including David Crawford. It has been a pleasure to work with members of both sides of the House on this Committee. It is the first committee that I have functioned on, although I am certain it will not be the last; however, working so well with members from different parties has been an education and it has given me an insight into the workings of government. It is a great pleasure to commend this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by endorsing the remarks made by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell). I, too, have very much enjoyed working with members from both sides of the House on the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I commend this Committee report to the House, because I think it is an extremely important report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that too much in this House and in this Government-as in all governments-there is a tendency when there is a problem to say, `Let's have a report', and that in producing the report, there is a feeling that we have done the job, we have talked about it and we have a report. This is an important report that needs not just to be filed away; it needs definite action. What we have on our coast now is akin to a national disaster. Australia has a coast which started off in a natural pristine state but which now has 75 per cent of the Australian population living on it. That is causing enormous degradation to that coastline; it is causing degradation through sewage, through development and through deposits of nitrogen and phosphorus, which from way back have entered the river systems as run-off from farming lands and are carried out into the sea.

In my own area of South Australia, which the Committee visited, we saw the effect of urban water run-off on the waters of the St Vincent Gulf. We have streams coming from agricultural communities where the dogs, cats, cows, ducks and everything else go into the water, leaving their refuse in the water, which flows down the streams, picking up all the silt, dirt and grime that comes off the roads, and then straight into the Gulf. That is a particularly bad instance of urban water run-off, but it was not the only instance. This is happening all over the coast and at the moment very little is being done about it. Part of the problem is that responsibility for the coast has been given to the States. The States see the coast as part of their areas, yet when one looks at the definitions of `coast' that the various States have, one finds that their definitions are different. Some States will look at the coast as that very little bit of water that laps onto the sand, whereas others will define it as an area that goes much further inland and much further out to sea.

I mentioned urban water run-off because that was particularly bad in my State of South Australia, as we saw at the Patawalonga. Let me say that there are much worse instances around the coast. We all know of Bondi and the raw sewage that goes out and back into our famous beaches at Bondi. Bondi was once the symbol of Australia, where overseas people saw the beach with our great lifesavers on the white sands. Now there are days when one cannot swim at Bondi because it is a health hazard. But Bondi is not an isolated instance. The Committee saw that this is happening elsewhere along the coast. We saw that down at Lorne and similar places sewage is still being pumped into the sea. Not only is it being pumped into the sea, but also some of the water boards doing that have an old-fashioned attitude that that is an acceptable practice and that the sea is there to have sewage dumped into it. That is not what the sea is there for, and if we keep dumping sewage into it, we will lose more of the sea grasses and our fisheries. We are doing enormous damage to the seas by pumping our sewage into them.

As part of the Committee's activities, we went to see Memtech Ltd, an organisation in New South Wales which is looking at a technological solution to these problems. I am surprised that we have not taken up the options offered by Memtech, because its process is an Australian process and one which is very technologically advanced and could solve many of our problems in putting sewage out into the sea. There are some moves to use it in New South Wales, but as far as I can see, it has not been taken up with the vigour that it should be. The only reasons I can see to explain this are not just related to the cost, because the cost of pumping sewage into the sea is enormous anyway, but that it is such new technology that people are reluctant to embrace it and many of the water boards still have very old-fashioned attitudes to this sort of thing.

The member for Richmond referred to the `tyranny of small decisions'. Indeed, that is what we are suffering from on our coast-the tyranny of small decisions. Much of the responsibility for the coast is that of small councils which have very narrow resource bases, yet they have to make decisions about the types of development that go along their piece of the coastline.

When those councils say, `All right, we will give that natural piece of pristine coastline for development', they are actually saying, `It really doesn't matter, because it is only this little bit'. However, it does matter, because with a council making that decision, the adjacent council along the coast will make the same decision, and so will the next one, so that we have this tyranny of small decisions and end up with what we have on the east coast, where 70 per cent of our wetlands have now disappeared.

In case it is thought this is not important, these are wetlands which filter our waters near the coast, and these are wetlands where fish breed. So it is essential that we stop the process now before it goes too far.

The role of the Committee was to see whether the Commonwealth in fact has a role in the coast, and it does. It has a role to coordinate those bodies which are at present looking after the coast, to provide some national guidelines for those bodies. It does not need another role as a draconian level of government; we have enough of that already on the coast. We now need coordination.

In conclusion, I would like to express my thanks for all the help of the very hardworking secretariat, who particularly asked me not to mention the actual fun we had in going around the coast. But let me put that in; it really was quite a delightful trip. I think I shall remember for a long time the time we had in Broome. Although we were only there for 1 1/2 days, I feel I saw the whole of the Broome area. One of my concerns now for the future, perhaps, is what will happen in that area, and I have some terrible fear of going back one day and finding, next to that beautiful, natural wonderland-the aquamarine water and the red soil-a giant pearl at the gates of Broome saying, `Welcome to Broome'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in speaking in this debate to note the report entitled The Injured Coastline: Protection of the Coastal Environment, the report of the House of House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. As has been mentioned in the tabling statements of the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), as Chair, and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), as Deputy Chair, and the contributions of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) and the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus), the Committee did make extensive inspections of a wide variety of coastal situations around Australia. Whilst a number of those coastal environments are different, there are great similarities in our ability as a nation to appropriately control what is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: If we reflect upon the number of inquiries already held about the coast, one would suspect that now is really the time to get some coordinated action about the management of the coast. Let me refer back to the predecessor of this present House of Representatives Committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. Back in 1980 it reported on the management of the coastal zone. If we compare the recommendations of that Committee with the recommendations that appear in the report The Injured Coastline, there are definitely some similarities.

Back in 1980 there were recommendations that whilst State and local governments had recognised the importance of the coast, they often lacked the resources to undertake research or preparation of management plans. Again this was something the Committee found as it toured around, especially with regard to local government. Due to the size of local government and the resources which are available to local government-compared with the types of things they are required by legislation to investigate-often a great deal of support is required to enable them to carry out their role appropriately.

The 1980 report referred to aspects of coastal planning where national interests should override State or local interests. I think in most inquiries of committees of this place, one of the recurring themes can be what are seen to be the difficulties of controlling things at a national level as a result of our federal system of government, particularly the way in which we divide responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the State. This inquiry was no different.

As the honourable member for Hawker said, it is not a matter, at a national level, of dictating what should happen, but it is certainly a requirement at a national level that we should have appropriate guidelines and we should give appropriate leadership so that the other spheres of government, and those groups within the community which have an interest, can get on with the job. When we say there is a responsibility at the national level to be involved, that is all we are saying. There is a responsibility at the national level to be involved in appropriate research, there is responsibility at the national level to set appropriate guidelines, but there is also a responsibility at the local level to ensure that there are appropriate mechanisms of consultation.

I suppose another recurring theme in this inquiry, as we moved around Australia to the various areas that we visited, was the amount of conflict which was created over plans for the use of the coast, plans for outfalls into the sea or such other things. The headline, `The killing of our coast', which occurred in local papers in the Geelong region, is an example of the types of emotive expressions which are used at the local level for some of the things carried out.
The first recommendation of this report calls for:

Effective public participation in coastal zone management be encouraged at the local government level by a variety of mechanisms, such as: the preparation of local zoning plans in consultation with the community, the development of better environmental mediation procedures and the establishment of local consultative committees on specific projects and issues.

That is not to say that in some cases, perhaps in a majority of cases, those mechanisms are available, but perhaps it indicates there is a need to emphasise the availability of those mechanisms so as to encourage the wider debate that is required to satisfy the community that in fact when decisions are made about the coast, they are appropriate decisions. I suppose that was at the kernel of much of the conflict that we saw.

I compare some of the matters that we investigated in this inquiry with some of the things that this Committee was exposed to in the previous Parliament in its land degradation inquiry. Again there was this Commonwealth-State relationship; again there was this lack of coordination between the many agencies in the different spheres of government which have control.

The honourable member for Macquarie spoke of our responsibility as stewards of our environment, and that was one of the recurring themes in the land degradation inquiry; land care groups understood that they were there as stewards for their environment and that they needed to look after it appropriately to pass it on to future generations. In the land degradation inquiry it was perhaps a bit clearer how the community could become practically involved through freehold or leasehold tenure, and other such matters. There was a more direct relationship between the environment and habitats which people were asked to be involved in-to either repair or to look after. It is not as clear when we look at the coastal environment because those issues of ownership are perhaps not as distinct. Certainly the same principles of involvement of the community can be put in place.

To do that we really have to look at the information that is available, we have to look at the baseline data which research enables us to have, and I think the more emphasis we can put on that, the more guidance and the more assistance through research grants we can have to the number of agencies doing work in that field, the better things will be. It became a bit frustrating when people saw things like the London Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, which set guidelines about what we pour into the oceans from ships, was not applied to the things we allow to go into oceans through outfalls. I suppose that is something we really should look at, because it is incongruous to have a regulation about those things dumped at sea rather than those things dumped into the sea.

The coast is the interface between the land and the water environment. It is very important that something which has evolved over many thousands of years should play a role. The pressures which are placed on the coastal environment through human activity are great, whether they be through recreational purposes, tourist purposes, industry or the stresses of large urban cities. They are things we have to take into account. Those pressures will undoubtedly lead to change, change at a greater rate perhaps than the environment is either capable of or should be capable of taking.

Those are the important things that this report highlights. It is an important report which focuses community attitudes on the way in which we treat the coast. I join with those who have spoken before to congratulate the inquiry secretary, David Crawford, on his efforts. He was ably assisted with secretarial support by Tracy Cumberland. The way in which the Committee has been able to put together this report is a reflection of the professional attitude of the secretariat staff.
In conclusion, I quote from the Canberra Times editorial on the report, which said:

Just as the nations of the world have begun to realise that they must work together to reduce ozone depletion of greenhouse gases, on a national level we must realise that pollution must be addressed with one voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also am happy to join in commending the report of the Parliamentary Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled The injured coastline: Protection of the coastal environment, and in particular to commend its recommendations to the Government. This report has been prepared over the life of two parliaments. It was begun by the previous Committee and concluded by this Committee. The report is some 126 pages but it is thoroughly readable and provides a great deal of information for anyone who is interested in this vital topic. There is a lot of anecdotal information that helps to draw attention to specific problems that illustrate the national perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a much studied area of community interest, and one whole section of the report deals with a review of some of the work done by other committees and other reviews. David Crawford and the staff and all those associated with the preparation of this report have put together a document that will be a textbook on the subject for many years to come. I congratulate the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), and others who worked on it for the way the report has been prepared. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) also requested that she be identified with these words of thanks, particularly to the Committee Chairman, who has a wonderful way of putting witnesses at ease, ensuring that we receive the information we require.

This country is one of vast space. A great deal of land is shared amongst not a large number of people. Yet in Dorothea Mackellar's land of sweeping plains and rugged mountain ranges, the fact is that most Australians live in the coastal zone. Something like three-quarters of the entire population is gathered along that tiny strip, leaving vast inland areas largely vacant. So the vast number of Australians are directly concerned by the report and its recommendations.

People often move to areas they consider to be beautiful and pristine, but the very reason they move there-often to be away from others-has the effect of attracting other people. Conflicts soon develop; those who went there in the hope of serenity and silence find other people joining them, and the issues grow. Those small communities develop into cities with high rise, sewerage and industry, and the issues grow into ones of monumental proportions.

As this Committee travelled around Australia, visiting what many might consider to be glamorous locations but usually examining sewerage systems and factories and other less glamorous aspects of those societies, it was almost invariably confronted by local action groups which were dealing with this, that or the other local issue. Many of them asked the Committee to intervene and perhaps to make some kind of assessment of their case. That was not our role, of course, but we were very interested in the dynamics of dispute.

It is clear that individual environmental disputes are attracting a lot of attention. A small group sometimes is able to focus national attention on an issue that does not enjoy broad community support but nonetheless is able to generate a great deal of heat and a great deal of conflict. Without doubt our society would be better if we were able to put in place mechanisms that enabled these kinds of disputes to be settled in an orderly and peaceful manner.

The Committee looked at that whole question of dispute resolution. I note with interest that in my own electorate the Fitzgerald inquiry currently looking at Fraser Island and environs is also examining this area. The Fitzgerald inquiry is going about it in a much different style. A grand conference was held in the Sheraton in Brisbane which, regrettably, only people with rather large salaries could afford to attend, so it missed something of the point.

The inquiry is trying to come to grips not only with the issues on Fraser Island but also with the fundamental question of how we can better resolve disputes. True, there are procedures in place. There are legal arrangements whereby people can appeal and go to the courts, but they are costly, not just for the protest groups but also for the developer. Many worthwhile projects have floundered because even the developer cannot afford to be involved in the disputation processes of the courts. So we certainly need to look at other measures for resolving these kinds of issues.

Some people have moved to the Green political parties building out of the great number of individual disputes all over the place, but those sorts of parties will never resolve the issues. We need to have in place a system that is effectively able to deal with issues within the mainstream of the political process, without the need to set up particular structures.

I notice that some newspaper articles have suggested that the Committee was advocating an environmental levy. That is not the case, and some of those newspapers have subsequently corrected their errant headlines. The fact is that, without any doubt, the environment is such an important issue in the community that some people are even prepared to pay extra taxes. But we should not allow environmental levies to be used to gild what is fundamentally another tax. Caring for the environment is a fundamental task of government and should be considered within the normal budgetary framework. It does not need extra levies. Environmental issues need to be considered on their merits and dealt with on that basis.

Someone has already mentioned that many decisions are made every day that affect the environment and that these small decisions sometimes multiply and have a significant general effect. It also needs to be pointed out, however, that not all development is evil. The title of this report is The injured coastline. The coast is not dead; it is not ruined beyond redemption. True, heavy population pressure has changed it in many ways, but some of the development has been for the good. The Committee saw development work that seems to have made the environment even more pleasant. But when we put large numbers of people in a small area in a fragile environment, there is naturally going to be some effect, and we need to manage that effect.

Over recent times there has been something of a change in attitude in our society from one where man was master of the environment and had a right to treat it as he chose to one where man should be subject to his environment. I think the real situation should be somewhere between those two. Humans have a perfect right to live in the world, just as animals, birds, frogs and trees have a right to be here. When a tree grows in a particular area it alters that environment. When humans live in an environment they change it as well. We have the power of reason and therefore the power to manage our use of the environment in a way that other species perhaps do not have.

Whilst other species have a right to be here, so do we. So it is essential that, in reviewing the way in which we live on this earth, we care for our environment and manage it in such a way that future generations can also enjoy it. But we do not have to be ashamed of, or apologise for, our presence here. We just need to use the environment wisely and well. I believe that this report will contribute in that regard. I commend it to the Government and urge the Government to review the recommendations seriously, because it has the capacity to improve considerably the way in which this nation not only manages its environment but deals with the various environmental issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The goals which the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts set out to achieve were indeed onerous ones. To identify particular areas of the coastline which were under environmental stress, to identify and propose specific measures to be implemented, to raise the profile of environmental degradation in the coastal zone, and to define an appropriate role for the Commonwealth are indeed difficult tasks. Honourable members from Western Australia, of course, in compiling reports such as this, suffer also from the tyranny of distance because it is difficult to travel the great distances that are required to attend all of the hearings of such a committee. Indeed, for the one part of the trip that I really wanted to go on, to Broome in my own State, I found myself in Sydney with the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, the banking inquiry, while other members of the Committee were in Broome.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would like to do in my brief period to speak is just to focus on some of the issues that are peculiarly Western Australian. During November last year, we had the opportunity to spend a day travelling down the coast of Western Australia and we saw the full spectrum of the difficulties which exist there. We started off, of course, at Scarborough Beach. If one stands on the beach in Western Australia, one can look as far as one wants north or south and see beautiful white sands and lovely blue water. Unfortunately, the one thing that obscures one's vision is that monolith at Scarborough, Observation City, a testament to the work of the forces of evil, if I might say so. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who is sitting here in front of me, throughout the machinations that surrounded the building of that monument was one who, to his great credit, opposed the proposal most vehemently.

There is a problem with residential beach development and the usage of beaches. Indeed, along that stretch of coastline in Western Australia, the housing developments are considerably removed from the local beach areas. In Los Angeles and in Sydney and in other cities of the world one does not see the separation of the coast and the usages of the coast by individuals from the residential settlement. Indeed, we have made some good decisions in that respect. In the older areas, of course, like Cottesloe, housing is to be found right up to the beach area and there are problems.

We went further south to Cockburn Sound. The difficulties that exist in Cockburn Sound relate, of course, to industrial pollution. In that area are located iron and steel works, an oil refinery, an aluminium refinery, cement works, chemical plants, meat and fish processing plants, power stations, and facilities for ship maintenance, fishing and tourism. The result has been considerable pollution of Cockburn Sound, which is, of course, a matter of great concern for people in the area. Indeed, there has been a massive loss of the sea grass meadows in Cockburn Sound and it will take many years to turn around the environmental consequences of this pollution.

We moved further down to Warnbro Sound and we saw the difficulty mentioned by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who spoke before me about public participation and the need for the public to be involved in the processes locally. The local action group told us of their interest in the development of the area of Warnbro Sound and, indeed, in recommendation No. 1 we pick up the possibility for increasing public participation. Local zone plans need to be developed; there is a need for environmental mediation procedures to be developed and, indeed, for local consultation with local committees. In fact, in recommendation No. 1 we pursue that particular issue.

We then moved further south to Mandurah. We saw the effect on the area of the movement of nutrients from the rural hinterland into Mandurah estuary. The proposal is for the establishment of the Dawesville Cut, an area which will allow the estuary to breathe and to be washed out into the sea. But with every proposal that we saw along the coastline, what needs to be remembered is that, whatever we do to interfere, there are effects and countereffects. So it will be necessary for us to watch very closely what occurs in that area.

I understand that we are very limited in time. Let me finally say that I have great admiration for the Committee, for David Crawford, who is here with us, and Lindy Smith and the staff and, indeed, the Chairman, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), who put so much work into this Committee. I hope that we will minimise the problems for the future and that we will have some long term outcomes and balanced solutions in the future as a result of this report.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ROMANIA, GREECE AND LONDON

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure today to be supporting and talking with respect to the tabling of this report of the delegation to Romania, Greece and London because it was probably one of the most enjoyable trips certainly that I have been on and because the theme which ran throughout the visit was the overall importance of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation visited Romania, which is itself a fledging democracy; we visited Greece, which of course is the cradle of democracy; and whilst we were in London the opening ceremony of the thirtieth annual session of the North Atlantic Assembly was conducted in Westminster Hall, which is the cradle of parliamentary democracy. So the theme of democracy was uppermost in our minds during the visit.

The first place that the delegation visited was Romania, and ours was the first visit by a parliamentary delegation since democratic elections were held in that country in May 1990. The visit was characterised by outstanding warmth and hospitality, and we were able to have wide ranging discussions at senior levels-very senior levels, in fact-and we conducted several inspections both in Bucharest and Brasov, which is in Transylvania.

Discussions highlighted the commitment of Romanians to the democratisation process and to the move to a market economy. There was real concern, however, wherever we went at their lack of experience in operating a democratic political system-for example, a major problem in understanding the legitimate role of opposition parties to criticise. We found wherever we went that the National Salvation Front found it very difficult to comprehend that oppositions were able to criticise-that that was their job. They are also concerned, of course, at their inexperience in administering a market economy.

There has been a number of problems in Romania since the May elections, and the most serious was the miners strike and associated violence in mid-June. Since that time, the situation in Romania appears to have improved, and it seems also that the democratisation that has occurred is going to continue. But, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is one of the recommendations of the delegation that the Romanians should be encouraged to further improve this democratisation by both direct and indirect assistance. We recommended to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) that Australia, in its capacity as a group of 24 nations, join in agreeing to giving assistance to Romania. Of course, not all that long after the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade indicated to us in writing-and it is part of the report-that, indeed, Australia would do that.

The visit highlighted the terrible plight of the Romanian people and the dreadful legacy of the Ceausescu years. The country is characterised by poverty. There are queues for even basic items like bread and meat and a lack of variety of nutritional foods. The darkness, the starkness, the greyness, the industrial pollution, the buildings marked with bullet holes and the memorials to the martyrs of the revolution were all things that stick out in our minds when we think about that trip. People frequently asked us, `Do you know what we have gone through?'-and they really are shell-shocked.

Possibly the most graphic illustration of the former dictator's legacy was evident in the orphanages we visited. A lot has been said about the orphanages in Romania, and I do not want to dwell on that. I want to read one section of the report of the delegation which says it all in terms of some of the orphanages over there. Paragraph 2.4.15 states:

Subsequently, the Leader, Deputy Leader and Secretary of the Delegation were invited to inspect the orphanage at Timis de Sus, housing approximately fifty children whose ages ranged from 18 years to infancy. Children with severe mental and physical disabilities were mixed in with normal children of all ages and both sexes. The difficulty of finding adequate accommodation became clear during this inspection-though generally clean, the sleeping areas were very crowded-up to 15 per room-and sanitation and ventilation provisions were most inadequate, with sewerage buckets kept behind the door. However, the children were warm and adequately fed, despite the fact, as the nurses stressed, that it was difficult to provide a variety of nutritious foods, a problem common for most Romanians. Most remarkably, the children were responsive to the nurses, an enormous contrast to what had amounted to apathy on the part of the children when the nurses had first arrived.

I am sure that I speak on behalf of the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), and the secretary to the delegation, Anne Hazelton, when I say that the stench is something we will never forgot. It is something which will remain in our nostrils. One of the other things that we will always remember is the heart-wrenching thought when the kids were coming up to us and grabbing our legs and more or less indicating that they did not want to us to go.

Apart from that, there is nevertheless a sense of optimism and hope for the future in Romania. The delegation's recommendations regarding Romania are aimed at encouraging the process of democratisation and in further developing trade opportunities. I want to stress that the warmth of our reception in Romania and the friendliness of the people are long lasting memories for the delegation. I am very pleased to say that, under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), an Australian Romanian Parliamentary Friendship Group has been set up. We hope to meet with the Consul-General of the Romanian Republic in Australia, Pavel Platona, in the very near future.

The next country we visited was Greece. Our visit to Greece served to emphasise the very strong ties between our two countries. During discussions, Greek officials frequently mentioned the contribution of Australians during World War II. Our ties were bolstered by very significant contributions to our political, cultural and economic life made by the Greek community in Australia. Enormous debt is owed by Western civilisation to the philosophy of ancient Greece. The delegation was privileged during the visit to inspect many achievements of the ancient past.

During the visit both sides expressed regret that trade and commerce relationships between Australia and Greece are very small, and we would hope that that can improve. We held many interesting meetings in Greece.
