For example, the delegation appreciated the knowledge and insights of former Prime Minister Papandreou, who last November-remember, last November-in discussions on the Middle East crisis and its aftermath, foreshadowed a heightening of the Kurdish problem and destruction of the Kuwait oilfields with long lead times necessary to repair the damage. That, of course, was before a shot was even fired. Overall, the visit was one of outstanding warmth, hospitality and friendship. It was really something that we will never forget.

We also visited London. A major reason we visited London was to talk with the Anzac Parliamentary Group. Unfortunately, something happened that day-namely, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher decided that she would resign. She announced her resignation on that day and the delegation was in attendance during Mrs Thatcher's last address as Prime Minister to the House of Commons.

Our principal task in London was to attend the thirty-sixth annual session of the North Atlantic Assembly (NAA). This was a significant step forward for Australia on this occasion as we were accorded associate delegation status, entitling Australia to a seat at committee tables, and the right to speak in committee debates and in the plenary session. The delegation saw this as a valuable opportunity to put forward Australia's viewpoint on a range of issues. The key concern of the delegation was the future of the Uruguay Round of talks, which at that stage had not stalled. The delegation focused on the significance of agriculture to the Round and the need for movement in the areas of export subsidies and market access.

Other issues raised by the delegation were the Gulf crisis and developments in eastern Europe. The delegation has made recommendations to ensure that, in future, steps will be taken to the effect that Australia's delegation to the North Atlantic Assembly will be well placed to present Australia's views on a broad range of issues. Attendance at future NAA meetings for Australian parliamentary delegations is indeed an exciting and challenging prospect.

Before my time expires, I want to thank a number of people. Firstly, I want to thank the staff who have helped to put the report together, particularly Pat Sherman, who did the word processing, and also Andy Hall and Terry Lyons, who did the printing. If I had 10 minutes more I would tell honourable members how members of this delegation got on tremendously well. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know how important that is. Everybody got on. Bipartisanship was everywhere. They were a delight to be with as far as I and my wife, Tina, were concerned. I want to thank my wife, Tina, who helped me get through a lot of after dinner speeches. It would have been very difficult for me if she had not been there.

I want to thank the honourable member for Bradfield and his wife, Monique, and the mascot, young Ellis, who I think will probably join the Labor Party after the brainwashing I gave him. I want to thank Senator Austin Lewis and Mrs Willie Lewis, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) and his wife, Cathy, the honourable member for Port Adelaide and his wife, Aldona, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) and his wife, Julie, and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck).

I want to thank in particular Anne Hazelton, the secretary to the delegation. She was just marvellous. She was always available. She was the packhorse for all our gear. I am sure everyone on the delegation would say that she was just simply wonderful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) in noting, for the benefit of the House, the great success, the harmonious activities and the undoubted enjoyment we all shared as members of the delegation, which worked extremely well together. It can best be described as a textbook delegation, in contrast possibly to what happened in Africa last year, which you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be aware of.

SPEECH.PARA: We did our best, with considerable success, in maintaining the important tradition of this Parliament. Regardless of political differences at home, when we are abroad we always speak as Australians. Our leader held up the flag extremely well, as did his wife, Tina. Anne Hazelton has already been referred to. I join with the Parliamentary Secretary in confirming that Anne was an outstanding secretary to the delegation. We could not have asked for better support.

There is no doubt that the delegation was successful because the group was able to mesh so well together. In a parliamentary sense, one often wonders precisely what is successful, but one thing is quite clear-Australian parliamentary delegations have the potential to make a very significant contribution to Australia's overall diplomatic activities and the extension of our national interests abroad.

I want to draw to the attention of the House the fact that there are 11 official delegations each year. Some 50 senators and members leave these shores and visit probably every continent in the world. I have always felt that the parliamentary contribution to Australia's diplomatic effort is significantly underplayed, because there is a perception in the bureaucracy that overseas visits are simply junkets, a way of keeping members of parliament, preferably backbenchers, happy. If people examine the veracity of that assertion against the facts they will find that it is an absurd proposition.

Australia today has its back to the wall. We are not just talking about `free markets'; we are talking about a free market for ideas. We are talking about the very existence of this country. Perhaps I could draw on none other than Thucydides, the famous Greek historian of the fourth and fifth century BC. Even then he identified this problem. He said that `in the affairs of states the strong will demand what they will and the weak must yield what they must'. When we travel overseas we often go to countries which are weaker than us. We also visit many other countries which are stronger than us. The one thing which is common to both is the almost total lack of knowledge of this country, what it stands for, its political beliefs, its principles, its values, its economic potential and what its role should be in the world.

I think this goes very much to the core of much of our problem. The world is now influenced so much by change. Yet our incapacity to develop and distribute those ideas and to influence events is contributing to us losing the battle. Our problems with Malaysia at this very moment are merely symptomatic of that situation.

The delegation visited Romania-a country which, in human value terms, has little. The capacity of its people was almost destroyed by the Ceausescu Government-by 48 years of deprivation, intellectual regimentation and almost complete destruction of the value systems of that nation. Yet we saw the spark of democracy being relit-a passion of a people to rebuild despite the problems of the past. They wondered why their great ally, that great supporter of democracy, the United States-fortunately, the policy has changed since we were there-was standing back and saying, `You are different from the rest of eastern Europe. We are not satisfied with your progress towards democracy'. Perhaps the Americans and the European Economic Community (EEC) not realise the danger of that approach and the damage it was doing to a relatively few people who had the courage to take up the challenge and were trying desperately to apply democratic principles through their legal and institutional framework.

As we were the first western European delegation to visit Romania since the overthrow of the Ceausescu regime, we were able to hold out the hand of friendship and demonstrate to Romanians that the democratic ideal was worth trying to achieve, despite the problems; that there is a role, as the leader of the delegation said, for oppositions; that just because a government is elected by a majority it does not mean that its word is law indefinitely or in every field; that every idea has a counter view; that progress can always be improved. The objective of Romania and all those countries of eastern Europe must be to combine the intellectual capacity and vigour of their people in their parliamentary system to achieve common goals-the freedom and the integrity of their people.

When we went on to Greece we discovered a new disease called visual deprivation. May I explain it briefly. In six days in Romania we did not see one neon sign. We did not see one shop with a decent display in a window. All we saw were empty shelves and queues of people. We did not realise the psychological impact of that until we landed in Greece and travelled into Athens from the airport. We saw before us Volvo and Mercedes signs, bright street lights, neon signs, well-dressed people and cars all over the place. If anybody believes that the socialist system as applied in eastern Europe for decades has given anything to its people they should simply spend a week in Romania and then go to Vienna, Rome or Athens and see for themselves the stark contrast of the lifestyles of the people. Nobody could leave that environment and not support the democratic process, with all its faults. As Churchill said, it may not be the best, but no-one has come up with a better ideal yet.

I make just two brief observations. The Anzac group will present us with a challenge in the future because I believe the links with the United Kingdom are being reduced. We need to consider in detail the importance of the United Kingdom in the context of the European Economic Community, because Britain offers a springboard for Australian economic penetration of western and eastern Europe that must never be ignored for what it can give Australian businessmen in the future.

My final observation is about the North Atlantic Assembly. It is an important institution. This was the first time we had had a delegation led by a member of the government executive and we recommend in our report that that be continued. In many respects, the Asia Pacific seminar was not a success because we were dealing with Europeans, who have no real conception of the Asia Pacific region-and few seem to want to know. Sadly, I have to say that the Americans were the worst because they did not even attend the seminar. Nevertheless, this is a challenge and is one that we must take very seriously indeed.

I recommended at that forum that the Australian Government and this Parliament start considering seriously the implications of establishing in our own region an Asia Pacific parliamentary assembly. We must be able in our own environment to create a political mechanism, in addition to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group, which is essentially a governmental and economic mechanism, to give parliamentarians throughout this region and the Pacific world the opportunity to come together on a regular basis to discuss and compare each other's systems and to better understand problems. Malaysia is a classic example of the very real difficulties and the clashes which can take place between an Eastern philosophical tradition and Western ideals.

There are fundamental differences. They are important differences to both cultures. The only way they can be overcome is through a process of education and information. We cannot stand back from Asia. We cannot stand back from the development of the Pacific. It is going to be the economic centre of the world into the twenty-first century. Australia has an important role to play. If we miss this chance and do not take it up now, we will be passed over by Japan, by China and by developing members of the Association of South East Asian Nations. The opportunities which this country should have for its children will be missed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Ronald Edwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My purpose in presenting the National Measurement (Standard Time) Amendment Bill to the House is very straightforward. I would regard this as historic legislation. Under section 51(xv.) of the Constitution, it is clear that the Federal Parliament has the responsibility for setting time zones in Australia. Many honourable members would be aware that in Australia currently this responsibility is held by State governments. So far that has presented no major difficulties except when we move to summer time. Painting an analogy, summer time in Australia is somewhat like our rail system-that is, through the stubborn refusal of some people at the State level we do not have a uniform system of summer time. This has presented enormous problems in terms of managing the economy and conducting business, let alone the general direction of Australia as a community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to recognise that, for example, in Europe there are two time zones. Western and continental Europe span two time zones, but they choose to operate on a single time zone-one hour ahead of universal time. This zone covers all members of the European Community, except the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, Portugal, Greece and Turkey; all members of the European Free Trade Association, with the exception of Finland; as well as Yugoslavia, Albania, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland. In other words, if one goes from Warsaw in Poland all the way to the English Channel, one has one time zone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sensible.

—As the honourable member for Perth says, it is very sensible. In Australia, because of what I would call narrow-mindedness at the State level, we have had a reluctance, particularly in Western Australia, for people to recognise that in summer time there is a benefit in our retaining a parity of two hours time difference between Western Australia and the rest of Australia. The Liberal and National Party dominated upper House of Western Australia has refused to recognise that it is part of the real world. It still belongs to the fading curtains brigade-those who believe that somehow if daylight saving were introduced their curtains would fade. Someone actually telephoned me and said, `My grass has been drier this summer, and if you bring daylight saving in it will get worse'. That is the quality of the argument put forward. It is not unusual in this place to deal with a similar quality of argument from the other side, but I did not expect it on this issue. However, that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: In Western Australia we are severely deprived in terms of adopting summer time like the rest of Australia, with the exception of the Northern Territory. I exclude the Northern Territory for geographic reasons. But in Western Australia there is no excuse. There are three major reasons for my argument: a significant reduction in energy usage; improved recreational opportunities; and significant reductions in business costs. Bringing together our time zones represents a major step towards micro-economic reform.

I would say to those who will get excited about States rights that this legislation provides for the Commonwealth to consult with the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory or the Premier of each State to get his or her advice on the matter. If, as has happened in Western Australia, we had summer time being blocked by the upper House, the Premier in fact could advise the Commonwealth and summer time could be introduced at the national level. But it is important, in my view, that we recognise what has happened in many parts of the world; that micro-economic reform requires the introduction of measures that reduce costs and improve the recreational opportunities for people. I set that out very clearly.

I am particularly indebted to John Birch and Professor Goldsmid of the National Standards Commission for their work. I thank them for the advice they have given me in preparing this Bill. It is my view that, if we do move to introduce this Bill and have it passed in the Federal Parliament, and if we have a say in the setting of time zones, their expertise and that of a body such as the National Standards Commission will be very helpful to have on hand for this sort of exercise.

In concluding, it is important to emphasise that in Australia previously we have used daylight saving. We used it for wartime emergencies. In Tasmania it was introduced when there was a particularly severe drought; to reduce demand upon energy sources. At a time when we are trying to improve our energy efficiency, to reduce business costs and to improve recreational opportunities, it is important that we have a much better national approach to time zones, and that we give areas of Australia such as Western Australia, which has been deprived of daylight saving, the opportunity to move into the twentieth century with the rest of Australia and share the opportunity to have a common time zone measurement. Accordingly, I am pleased to commend this Bill to the House. I hope that colleagues in other parties see fit to support it. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) notes the major contribution to enhancing local facilities made by the Commonwealth Government's Community Recreation and Sporting Facilities program through provision of financial assistance to sporting and recreational organisations;

(2) notes that the purpose of this program is too encourage the development of high quality sport and recreational facilities across Australia to enable greater community participation in sport and improved development of skills to enhance Australia's national and international sporting performances, as recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration reports of May and December 1989 entitled ``Going for Gold'' and ``Can Sport be Bought'', respectively;
(3) seeks a continuation of this program in the 1991-92 Commonwealth Budget to enable additional support to be provided throughout Australia for development of further community facilities; and
(4) calls upon the Government to allocate:
(a) a sum of not less than $20 million over a three year period for the Recreation and Sporting Facilities program; and

(b) a similar sum for the establishment of a National Sports Facilities program to provide substantial financial support for the construction of sporting facilities of national significance, particularly in regional centres, in accordance with recommendations contained in the above-mentioned reports.

The presentation of this motion to the House is appropriate at this time, as the Government is commencing the process of framing the 1991-92 Budget. I hope that we can look forward to the support of honourable members on both sides of the House on this motion, as there are no partisan political objectives behind it. In moving the motion, I should reflect on the contribution that has been made in the past by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in pursuing this issue. I appreciate his support for the motion today, although he is not in the House at the moment.

The honourable member for Macarthur was the chairperson of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration when the two reports mentioned in the motion, Going for Gold and Can Sport be Bought?, were produced and tabled. He has been a persistent and articulate advocate for all people in our community who participate in sport and recreational activities, particularly those people who strive to provide excellent sporting facilities for our young people.

In the 12 months since my election I have had the pleasure to meet hundreds of people involved in community sporting clubs in the electorate of Moreton. They have been either keen players or participants in local weekend sporting activities or parents and supporters who work hard behind the scenes to enable the events to occur. I have visited a number of clubhouses, playing fields and swimming pools to present trophies, congratulate winners and commend the efforts of all involved in the presentation of their sport. They are involved in a multitude of sports: cricket, rugby league, rugby union, touch football, swimming, croquet, lawn bowls, tennis, softball, athletics, netball, hockey, soccer, badminton-the list goes on. Their clubhouses and grounds vary greatly in size, range of facilities and standard of equipment. But there is one common thread: their spirit of determination to strive to excel; their spirit of competition; and their desire to provide the children of our community with opportunities to play and to develop skills.

Thousands of children and adults every weekend are out enjoying healthy exercise, developing and honing skills and making friendships which will last throughout their lives. Almost all of these clubs and groups operate on shoestring budgets. The parents or members run raffles, dances, barbecues and other fundraising activities to buy the equipment, maintain their grounds and, if they can, build a clubhouse for training and meetings. Millions of dollars is raised every year by local community sporting and recreational clubs to enable people-young and old-to participate in a healthy way of life. They do an enormous amount for our community.

I am pleased to be able to speak in this Parliament on behalf of all of those groups in my electorate, and those all over Australia, to express their hope for a continuation of the valuable assistance provided by the Commonwealth's community recreation and sporting facilities program. This program was introduced in the 1988-89 Federal Budget with a $13m allocation to be spent over three years. It was a popular initiative, and over 1,000 applications for assistance were received. Unfortunately, only about 200 of them were able to be granted assistance, and the $13m was soon spent. The number of applications compared with the funds available demonstrates the need for this program to be further funded in the next Budget.

I know of at least two submissions from my electorate which will be forwarded if further funds are provided. I am sure that there will be many others made by many of the clubs in my electorate. The first one that I would like to touch on comes from the Brisbane Metropolitan Touch Association, which has its headquarters at Whites Hill in my electorate. It was a recipient in the previous program, receiving $15,333 in 1988-89 for the provision of lighting at its grounds. The total cost of the project was $60,515, so it is obvious that the Association members made a major fundraising effort to complete the project themselves. They are now wishing to construct a clubhouse, at a cost of some $200,000, to establish a Brisbane headquarters for touch football at Whites Hill. This clubhouse will serve over 5,000 touch football players who compete every week in the Brisbane area. It is a very worthwhile project, deserving of support.

The other submission is in considerable contrast to the touch football association's. I am patron of the Stephens Croquet Club, a small but vibrant group who owns its grounds and building at Annerley.

TALK.START.PARA: —You look as if you're just about ready for it.

—It is a game played by young and old, and it is enjoyed by many thousands of people around Australia. That club has been for many years, and is now, a well respected and very competitive contributor to State and national croquet competitions. One of the members of the Stephens Croquet Club represented Australia at an international competition held in London last year, and played very well. Its submission relates to its clubhouse, which is now quite old and is requiring renovation and upgrading. It also will be seeking our support through the program.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are just two examples of many hundreds around Australia in all honourable members' electorates. Worthwhile men and women, boys and girls, working hard, enjoying their sport and the friendships and personal development associated with it are seeking our support. These are the people whom the community recreation and sporting facilities program was established to support. In the first round, financial assistance offered was snapped up very quickly. The initiative of the Hawke Labor Government in funding this program demonstrates our clear commitment to the community-to families and to children. We need that commitment to continue. Clearly an increased allocation is required to meet the needs of these groups. They are providing very productive, beneficial and efficient means of recreation, physical exercise, personal development and community infrastructure which costs the Government actually very little. Each dollar invested by the Government in this program is repaid many times over in terms of improved health, less crime and better educated and positively developed citizens leading productive and worthwhile lives.

This is clearly a program of national significance. One has only to review the list of recipients of assistance from the last program to understand this. It is quite an extensive list: from Aurukun in far north Queensland down to Hobart; from the Boree Creek Lawn Courts Committee to the Wickepan Football Club in Western Australia; and from the Whyalla Workers Bowling Club to the Northern Territory Police and Citizens Youth Club. They have invested the contribution from the Federal Government wisely and well in the people of our nation. Funds from this program went all across the nation and in most Federal members' electorates.
I have not addressed the second program suggested in the motion, the national sports facilities program. I understand that the honourable member for Macarthur will speak on this proposal.

I will conclude on this note. In good times and bad, whether things are looking gloomy or bright, our community will always need and rely on our local clubs to develop our young people into keen, fit, worthwhile Australians. These programs deserve the support of Government and of all honourable members in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —To a certain extent, I personally endorse the terms of this motion. The objectives seem good, though I intend to put some alternatives to the methods proposed by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). I think that somewhere in there we can achieve a result. There is no doubt that, since the instigation of the program, the National Party of Australia and Liberal Party of Australia have recognised that physical fitness really does have a bearing on the general health levels of the community. We are acutely aware that improvement in the overall level of community fitness does impact on the cost of health care and the increase in productivity in the workplace. Benefits of a very important kind in a general sense are accrued to the community if we have a fit, capable and sport conscious community.

SPEECH.PARA: The program that the Government has instigated hands out something like $13m a year to a wide range of groups. These groups sought $100m worth of grants last year and the Government was able to find only $13m to assist in this community area. That indicates that there is a strong demand, a strong wish, for improvements and facilities that this Government-and I believe any government-could not possibly meet. The modest proposal of $20m over a three-year period is an increment, bringing the total roughly up to $20m per annum.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to some of the problems of this program. The honourable member who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Moreton, spoke of the Brisbane Metropolitan Touch Association. He indicated that, despite a need for $60,000, only $15,000 was able to be supplied by the Commonwealth Government-and it was one of the fortunate grant recipients.

Running through the list, the City of Heidelberg, for instance, received $100,000 towards an indoor recreation centre. It would not have been even a drop in the bucket. In those circumstances $100,000 would not even be acknowledged at the opening ceremony by the local authorities. It does not contribute to any major degree to the project. The Shire of Hastings received $100,000 for an indoor swimming pool.

I am choosing these at random, but we can run through almost every one of the grants and say that a minuscule amount has been contributed to an existing program by the Commonwealth Government. In that regard, while the program is good in intent, I do not know that it is really achieving its objectives. First of all, it falls short, massively, of the total amount of funds being sought. Secondly, where funds are supplied for projects, they touch only a minuscule part of the total cost.

I would like to see the Parliament and our community look at other alternatives. The alternatives that I believe are available to us include tax deductibility for donations to sporting bodies. I would agree to the scrapping of this program tomorrow if tax deductibility could be gained.

For example, just to use one project in my own area, I know of a large netball complex that will cost $1.5m. My electorate has a large population. Netball is a massive sport, the third most frequently played sport in Australia. The facility demand is intense. There is no way a group of netball enthusiasts and their local council can raise the $1.5m needed for a complex like that unless they can gain significant support. I believe that that support should come down to them through the national body of netball, the national body receiving the tax deductibility so that donations to it can be passed down to the local level for groups raising funds for a facility.

I put an alternative proposition. I do not believe it is the time for the taxpayer to continue to fork out funds in this way-a little seeding grant here and there. Whilst the objective is good, to extend the burden on our Budget by any method is really not in the best interests of the Australian community. Australia is in a dreadful situation today. How can we afford to keep paying out on everything, no matter how worthy the cause may be? How can we afford to keep paying out on everything?

The Budget was going to have a massive surplus. It will be a lineball surplus or a deficit. That will impact on next year. There is pain and job loss and all sorts of things happening in our community. The old catch cry of the Australian Labor Party was `What about the workers?'. What about the workers? The Labor Government is not attending to those issues, but the honourable member, worthily, wants to give out more money for the cause of community recreation.

It is imperative that we look at alternatives such as tax deductibility and the encouragement of sponsorship. Being involved in a parliamentary inquiry, I understand that sometimes there is difficulty in achieving a rapport between a sport and a potential sponsor so that there is a continuity of money and goods or services supplied by the sponsor to a sporting group.

But an educative process is needed for sports which find their presentation is not attractive to the public. Some sports do not lend themselves very readily to much public participation or public viewing, particularly on television. One has only to look at the massive changes that have been made in the presentation of sports such as netball, as I referred to earlier. The sharpening up of the rules, the continuity of the action, the types and quality of uniforms and the presentation of the participants all add to viewers' perception of and willingness to support a particular sport.

This applies to many sports. A lot of effort has been put in to sharpen up the public perception of women's tennis. Show jumping is another sport which is often seen on television. I would not classify snooker as a sport but, in programs such as Pot Black, snooker-and lawn bowls-can be presented compellingly so that people can view the sport on the field at the place of playing or on television. I believe that, with the coming of cable and pay television, minor sports will take pre-eminence for people who are interested in sports. They will be able to tune in and watch a television channel that will play all sorts of sport continually. Therefore, people will see croquet on television when there is pay or cable television. That then will start to draw a sponsorship reaction. There can be advertising in the background and, in the competitive process, teams will attract a lot of attention.

Sponsorship needs work from government. I would rather see effort being put into developing a cohesive approach to sponsorship. I would like to see more effort put into developing avenues through which sponsors feel they can be recognised. It should be explained to our amateur sports that they are not losing their status or their role in our society. Amateur sports men and women see themselves as having an ethical role when they accept sponsorship. I have seen a big movement of sponsorship into many sports, but not until there are full time professional players does the sport really change. Up to that point it is very healthy to see the community-those with funds and a wish to advertise what they do-joining with those who participate in sport to present effectively our sports men and women.

It is the Opposition's view that we should be seeking a wider participation in sport. The elite sports program of seven sports only fascinates me. New South Wales has 11 elite sports. There are different approaches throughout Australia. The New South Wales Government is doing a magnificent job. The honourable member has already mentioned much of the work. I would prefer to see sports being developed regionally. Last year in New South Wales $5m was provided to the regional sports facility assistance program. That will have quite an impact. The elite sports groups run in the States, talented youngsters groups-all of these programs are excellent. We in this Parliament should seek a wider involvement in sport, and from that core of participants we will build the elite of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not a lot of disagreement between members of this Parliament on the need for funding of sport. That flows right through from Commonwealth and State to local governments. In the short time available my plea is that this Government take into consideration the recommendations in the reports of two inquiries of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration that I chaired. The first report is entitled Going for Gold and the second Can Sport be Bought?. These reports touch on all the issues that are being debated here. They go to the questions of how much should be allocated; the size of the grants; who should be involved at what level-that is, elite athletes and broad participation; whether the State or Commonwealth government is responsible for facilities; and the question of tax deductions. All of those matters are contained in these documents and, in my view, the recommendations contained in them are worthy of consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating two parts of the program that the various Ministers responsible for sport have been able to put into place since this Government came into office. The first has been covered by my colleague from Queensland, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), and that is the community sport and recreation facilities grants program. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was absolutely right in saying that the amounts of money were not enough to complete the projects he referred to. Notwithstanding that, in many cases the funding was enough to complete small projects such as a croquet field in Queensland or to provide some light so that the National Soccer League team of Wollongong City could participate during the recent summer competition at Brandon Park in my electorate. They were appropriate amounts and they fully achieved what was required. In other areas they supplemented funds which the sport itself had been able to find or which local government had been prepared to put in. In some cases, I agree, it was a drop in the ocean. In other cases, the money went towards providing the necessary back-up so that the facility could be developed.

I am particularly concerned-as are you, Mr Deputy Speaker, because of your concern for sport and your support for areas such as the Croome Road sporting complex in your electorate-about the need for some form of national and regional sports facilities program to be developed. In our area, for example, the Steelers play in the national rugby league, the Wolves and Wollongong Macedonia in the National Soccer League, and the Hawks in the National Basketball League. But it is only the Wolves and Macedonia, who share Brandon Park, which was built with grants that came from the Federal and former State Labor governments and Wollongong City Council, who have a first class facility to play on. It is in need of further work, and the trust that has been established to look after it is working on that matter.

Wollongong showground, where the Steelers play, has been improved, but in the main because of private sponsorship from benefactors of the Steelers who have been prepared to do the work. That is appropriate. The community and local government are brought in. In relation to the need for the provision of grandstand facilities, the honourable member for Mitchell referred to the New South Wales Government. I applaud it for making a grant of $2m to Wollongong showground to improve spectator facilities and grandstands for the patrons. The Commonwealth Government, with a national facilities program, should be in a position to complement that.

The Hawks, who are in the National Basketball League, play in a stadium known as the Snake Pit, for the obvious reason that it is the pits. It is a terrible facility and they recognise that. They are looking at ways of harnessing private enterprise and government to build a new facility. But the Commonwealth needs to be involved. In that regard, I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to read recommendation No. 24 in Going for Gold. I also refer to the issue of funding in the second report Can Sport be Bought? It is simply not good enough for the Minister to say that we will conduct another review as to whether these sorts of grants are necessary. They are, and all-party committees unanimously recommended it. The two reports are here. They have been adopted by the Parliament and they need enacting.

I plead with the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when considering the Budget this year, to look at the provision of funds for national sports facilities in regional areas, which seem to miss out because the funds always go to capital cities, and at the community sport and recreation facilities program, so that small battling organisations can get some money to contribute towards the construction of those facilities. Everyone's electorate benefits from that. Equally, there is a need for greater tax deductibility, and I applaud what the honourable member for Mitchell said about that. There are recommendations along those lines in the reports. It all needs examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) spoke very strongly and obviously believes very deeply in this subject. However, there are many good causes. Every day in my electorate office many good causes are brought to me. People say, `We need money for this project'. The Edwardstown Bowling Club said, `We desperately need loos for the women. We've got great loos for the men, but the women are really hard up'. I felt very strongly for them, but it does not happen only with the Edwardstown Bowling Club. All over Australia there is a need for more sporting facilities. We cannot afford to fund everything.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to Australia as a banana republic. I do not know whether this was a self-fulfilling prophecy, but that is the way we are going. We will have to look at issues such as this and say, `This is an extremely worthwhile cause but at the moment we can't afford it'. We cannot afford everything.

Regional areas should be a State responsibility. It is the States that know what is needed. How can we, in the Commonwealth, determine that what is needed in southern South Australia is a lacrosse ground? This might be the breeding place for the greatest lacrosse team ever, but we in the Commonwealth do not know this; States and local government will know this.

The responsibility of the Commonwealth Government is in international competition. That is where we should be putting our energies. Australia shows off at the Commonwealth level in competitions such as the Olympic Games. We always give excuses for our performances in the Olympic Games. We are either up there saying `Hey, we're doing really well' or `Gee, it's bad that we didn't do so well because we're a small population'. We could do a lot better in that area. My husband keeps pointing out to me that Australia, with a population of 16 million, won a total of 14 medals during the last Games whereas Hungary, his native country, has a population of 10 million, 50 per cent less than ours, and won a total of 23 medals-almost twice what we won. We should be concentrating on this area. This is a Commonwealth responsibility.

Getting back to regional grants, I had a look through the regional grants and it seems to me that there is great ability here for a government in power to do a nice lot of pork-barrelling. I am not suggesting that this Government would, indeed, stoop so low as to pork-barrel in marginal electorates; I would never do that. But the fact that this is a possibility I think should be considered by honourable members. So perhaps we could leave the pork-barrelling to the States and to their conscience. I cannot see on what grounds we would decide to give Tooraweenah and District Tennis Club a tennis court resurfacing, the Glen Alice Community Association amenities, and Cowra Skateboard Club skateboard facilities and miss out on all the neighbouring towns which, I am sure, have an equal need.

I have listened to the speeches of honourable members as much as I could. And there was no mention of the need for the Commonwealth to look at the problem we are now facing; that is, the lack of interest in women's sport. I will give honourable members a few facts on that. In the 1988 Summer Olympics there were 151 men's events, but only 78 women's events. In the Winter Olympics there were 31 men's events and 16 women's events. In the programs of the Australian Institute of Sport, 66 per cent of the people there are men and 34 per cent are women. On newspaper coverage, only 2.5 per cent of total sports reporting space is devoted to women's sport. Photographs of men's sport outnumber those of women's sport roughly 12 : 1. At the Olympic Games there were 169 events for men and 76 events for women. This is what we are facing.

I would have liked honourable members who spoke previously to have mentioned that there is a need for the Commonwealth to look at sport and to be supporting sport-though that support should not go where the States should be acting-and to look Commonwealth-wide at what is happening to women's sport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of issues raised in this motion. I wish to say something about the national perspective. Indeed, I support the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) when she says that our primary role must be the development of elite sport.

SPEECH.PARA: I must mention the contribution by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He suggested that tax deductibility was a superior route because it represented less cost to the Government. I say to him that that is revenue forgone. Tax deductibility represents public revenue forgone. Whether we contribute grants or provide tax deductibility, it is still loss of revenue whichever way we look at it, so the net effect is the same.

The principal matter I want to focus on today is the national and international perspective. For too long in this country it has been accepted that the Australian Institute of Sport, which conceptually is something that I support, needs to be the engine that drives that. Increasingly it is the case that the States have the wherewithal, the States are making the contribution locally and the States are where people are living. It is necessary for us through the Australian Sports Commission to contribute to the programs in the States where athletes are being developed and want to live. The fortress that exists in Canberra is no longer an appropriate source for significant public funding for elite sport. There can be programs in Canberra, but we need to make contributions where the athletes are-in the States.

In particular, I want to look at what has happened in Western Australia. An article in the West Australian yesterday is headed, `WA Emerges as an Athletics Power'. For the first time since Western Australia has been holding national championships in a number of age groups, it has finished in a commendable position-third behind New South Wales and Victoria, which have significantly larger populations. This represents the start of programs in Western Australia which are beginning to produce results. We are producing talented athletes in Western Australia because of a significant program instituted by the Western Australian Institute of Sport and supported by the Sports Commission, but not to the extent that it should be at the moment.

What we can see happening in Western Australia is that program coming to fruition. Let us look at gymnastics, and at women's gymnastics in particular: there is a contribution from the Australian Sports Commission of $25,000 to the program in Western Australia. The contribution from the Western Australian Government is $100,000. From the fundraising and fees that parents and friends pay, there is $50,000. Over the last few years that program in Western Australia has consistently produced 25 to 50 per cent of the national team in that sport, yet the contribution that is being made from Canberra to that program in Western Australia is insufficient.

If we look at swimming, we see that the same situation is occurring. The Australian Institute of Sport, which is where the bulk of the money is being spent by the national Government, produced five of our team of 38 for the world swimming championships. It is the case that in the States there are centres of excellence. They deserve the support of a national government when we talk about producing elite athletes. The differentials are the same in athletics as they are in gymnastics, swimming and a number of other sports. If we look at the gymnastics program in Western Australia, we see that it has Andrei Rodionenko, who is arguably the best gymnastics coach for women in the world. Yet the support that program is getting from the national program is insufficient.

I have argued in this place many times that it should be the case that funds distributed through the Australian Sports Commission to those programs should be allocated according to the quality of the programs. The factors that need to be taken into account are the quality of the athletes, the quality of the coaching and the sports medicine and science backup. In all of those programs where that is appropriate and the States are meeting the standards, there should be significant and greater contributions from the Federal Government. That does not mean additional resources. We have significant funding for sport and for elite sport at the moment. It means the reallocation of those resources which presently exist.

It is the case that the Swimming Coaches Association of Australia is asking for this to occur. It is something that needs to happen. There needs to be a focus of attention on decentralising our sporting funding when it comes to elite sport because athletes want to live near their homes. The majority of people are not living centrally in Canberra, they are living in the States and the capital cities, and that is where the funding should be directed. It is the case that for too long reports have been recommending this change and we have not undertaken it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with some pleasure to talk on this debate. I think it is interesting that we should note the somewhat different approach and the two different arguments that are running parallel on both sides of the House. The first and foremost is the debate on what the Federal Government should be involved in. I think that everybody has so far agreed that we should be involved in elitist sports where Australia is represented.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the privilege the other day of going to the Australian Institute of Sport and having breakfast with some of the sportsmen. They are being provided with training by international coaches. We had a young team of cricketers through from all over Australia. One has to be impressed with the job that these coaches are doing to train those people in excellence. I fully support that. I think it is a Commonwealth responsibility.

When we get down to sport at a community level, we then have to ask: how do we effectively get the most number of people into sport-not looking at sport but participating in it? That is the key. This particular motion fails on that point because, once again, it is trying to pick winners. It is asking Commonwealth bureaucracy to take some sort of a list of worthy recipients and dole out a very small amount of money to help them. Quite frankly, that does not work and it does not work on the figures that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) put forward. Of the 1,000 people who asked for donations, 200 were recipients. So the other 800-they are all, no doubt, taxpayers-contributed to the 200 successful applicants. That is not a terribly fair way, it does not pick winners and it is very selective in the way it goes about it. Obviously we have to look at how we achieve those particular results.

Let us go back to the logic of this argument. Honourable members should remember that it is taxpayers' money that we are taking. The Commonwealth Government does not have any funds of its own; it gets it from the taxpayers and redistributes it out. If we did not put one penny back into sport, do honourable members think that netball, cricket, football, basketball-all those sports that have been played traditionally in Australia over many years-would disappear? Would they fold if the governments were not active in them? Of course not. We have to find a way to leave more money in people's pockets so that individuals can participate at that level.

Quite frankly, as a politician, if I were given the option of spending $20m on sport or $20m on the hospital system, I know where the money would go. In my electorate we have the tragedy of one hospital being so underfunded that it has stopped taking Medicare patients who need operations, other than those who need emergency surgery. That is a local tragedy. At the same time, one sees a grant of $100,000 going to a sporting complex down the road. Once again we are trying to pick winners rather than targeting money, which is really a Commonwealth and State joint responsibility, into areas of necessity.

I very much agree with the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who came up with the idea of tax deductibility. When I look around this nation and see how it became great, I realise that it did so not because of bureaucrats giving little dobs of handouts here and there but because pioneers got off their butt and did things that were good for their communities. When one drives around my country electorate, one will suddenly find a hall or church built in the middle of nowhere. The people of that community, some 70, 80 or 100 years ago, or even 150 years ago, decided that that was where they wanted to spend their money, and that is where it went. The obligation on this Government, and on governments of all persuasions, is to have a smaller taxation base and to leave money in people's pockets, letting them decide which sports they would like to fund and how they want to go about it. The Government should not try to pick winners, as it has done, other than in those areas of obvious need, such as in elitist sport where Australia is represented in the Olympic Games and cricket and so on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to support the motion proposed by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) today, which calls on the Government, as part of its Budget planning process, to develop and reinstate the program dealing with local community sporting facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: This phrase that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall) used-this notion of picking winners-is one which obsesses members opposite and one which is abused in very fundamental ways. I think we saw further evidence of that this morning. The motion calls for a program designed to ensure that the communities throughout Australia have the opportunity to enhance their sporting and recreational facilities, and to recognise the role that sport, physical fitness and recreation play both in encouraging the development of young people and in ensuring a healthy lifestyle for all people. Certainly in urban electorates like mine, where sporting facilities and other public infrastructure historically have been later in arriving than the development has been, this sort of program is particularly important because it is the catalyst to ensure other people contribute actively to sporting activities.

When the program was last in operation, two sets of grants were given to be applied in my area. One dealt with sporting facilities for the disabled, a group of people which all too often is neglected. With the greatest will in the world, no-one is going to come forward and cater for a minority group like that unless there is public financial support towards those facilities, as there has been. People who now utilise the facilities that those grants helped to provide have been much the better for it. As well as that, the grants in the last program were able to provide funding for new facilities for cricket at both the first grade and junior levels, and particularly training facilities. Again historically it has been difficult to get resources to provide them. Above all else, these grants ensured that other levels of government actively contributed to the development of sporting facilities, as has the community. As much as anything else, these grants form the catalyst for other people to participate in the development of sporting facilities.

One area which has needed attention is the development of women's sport. Historically, women's sport has not had the attention devoted to it that many of the male sports have had. In my own area the greatest participation in any sport is in netball, yet very little in the way of facilities has been provided for those who participate in that sport. However, we were told earlier, `Look, netball wouldn't finish if there was not public financial support'. That may be, but why not take the correct and appropriate view and say, `Why should not netballers have the opportunity to have facilities that ensure that they have courts which are safe and secure'? At the moment their facilities are second-rate ones and encourage ankle and knee injuries because they are so poor and not enough regard has been paid to them from all levels. Certainly there is not the corporate support that is given to many other sports, in spite of the fact that more people play netball than any other sport in areas such as the western part of Sydney.

There is a responsibility to develop these programs in a way which says, `We're going to look at providing sporting infrastructure, not only for the major sports but also for the developing sports where the infrastructure facilities are poor'. This is particularly important when we talk about the development of the elite areas of sport. Sure, we want to provide funding for elite sporting activities, but let us not forget that real sporting excellence is achieved by getting people to develop their skills and participate actively in sporting endeavour. They may go on to become representative athletes as time goes on. But if they do not participate, they will miss the chance to get training and the basic skills and become great athletes.
I strongly support this motion and I trust the Government will take it on board very seriously in the lead-up to this year's Federal Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this motion has expired; therefore, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses concern at the deteriorating standard of living of those Australians in rural areas.
At the turn of the century a gentleman by the name of James Riley made a statement saying how important the farmers were to the community and the nation. He said:

Without the farmer the town cannot flourish. Ye men of the streets be cordial to our rustic brethren. They are more potent than bankers and lawyers, more essential to the public good than poets or politicians. Do all you can for them. Farmers should vibrate wisely and heartedly between the Public Square and the farm-and we of the same should do the same.

At this time in Australia's history farmers are facing hurt; in fact, rural Australia is hurting. Nothing highlights this better than the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics general projection that the net farm cash operating surplus will fall by 67 per cent this financial year, following a 20 per cent fall last year, and will fall a further 20 per cent fall next year. For some the fall in income will be even greater.

Last week I was approached by a successful businessman in my electorate, who was emphatic that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should come and spend a day on a farm in his district so that he could gain a first-hand understanding of the crisis that exists in rural Australia. It was suggested that if more city-based politicians were to spend a day in the country to gain an appreciation of the rural crisis, this Parliament might start making some decisions that will ensure we keep rural Australia alive. If they do not choose to visit the rural areas now, they certainly will not have the time later this year when the effects of the rural recession hit the economic base of our major metropolitan areas. They will then be far too busy trying to explain their Government's failed economic policies, but no-one at that time will be listening.

I appreciate that many in the cities are also hurting, but I believe that the effects of the Federal Government's induced recession combined with low commodity prices are taking a greater toll in country areas. As in the metropolitan areas, unemployment is increasing in rural Australia as farms adjust to the dramatic reduction in their incomes by laying off staff and cutting spending. The one small compensation is that many of those now out of work have access to the unemployment benefits or some other allowance, although for many the payment is barely enough to feed and clothe their families. However, most farmers are entitled to nothing except a small family allowance payment, which is eagerly awaited by many families. Thank goodness members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia were able to stop the Federal Government, as announced in the Budget last August, applying an assets test to this allowance also.

Some families are entitled to the family allowance supplement of $53 per dependant per fortnight if their taxable income is less than $20,056, but this allowance is asset tested and, as farmers must have assets to be farmers, they are excluded from any assistance. This is despite the fact that they have very little, if any, cash flow. In many cases this is resulting in families surviving on budgets of $100 to $120 per week borrowed from the bank, and this is of great concern to me and also should be to the Federal Government and to this Parliament. Many of us in this building would not be able even to begin to comprehend this situation, or how we would begin to cope on such a minuscule income if we were placed in the same situation.

With budgets like this something must give, and unfortunately in some cases it is the children's education. I appreciate that many on the Government side are ideologically opposed to private boarding schools, but for students in isolated areas of Australia it is their only access to high school education. This fact is recognised by governments through the payment of an isolated children's allowance. For each child who is forced to leave home and study because of isolation, a non-means tested, non-asset tested allowance of $1,500 is paid. Any additional payment is income and asset tested.

The maximum allowance per year for primary school students is $2,912, for under 16-year-old high school students $3,235, and for those over 16 slightly more. However, the cost of tuition and board at an average boarding school is in the vicinity of $11,500 per year. One does not have to be a mathematical genius to calculate that there is a shortfall of approximately $8,000 per student per year that the parents have to pay. These costs are horrendous, especially when parents have two, three or four children away at school.

Today the Isolated Children's and Parents Association (ICPA) is holding its annual conference in Bourke. As honourable members would be aware, the ICPA is one of the most effective lobby groups to visit this Parliament, and it is to be congratulated on the work it is doing to improve access to education for students in the isolated areas of Australia. Although welcoming the recent increase in the non-means and non-asset tested component of the assistance for isolated children's allowance to $1,500, the ICPA would like the total allowance increased to 55 per cent of the average cost of a boarding school. I am sure that many honourable members would agree that, given the difficulties and cost of education in isolated areas, this request is not unreasonable.

The fact is that, after having cut their spending to the bone, parents are now having to withdraw their children from boarding school. For those in extreme financial difficulties, this means bringing their children home and assisting them with their schooling by means of correspondence. However, in the main this is far from satisfactory because, apart from the social aspects, the children must rely heavily on their parents' time and educational skills. This is placing great stress on many families, because not being able to afford any labour means that both parents must spend a greater time helping each other outside, whilst at the same time the children need parental assistance with their correspondence lessons.

Other parents are driving their children excessive distances morning and afternoon in order to catch a school bus, and in some cases long distances to and from school. Apart from the physical toll on the child, any person who has driven in western New South Wales recently-and I have no doubt the situation is similar in other outback areas-would be extremely concerned if their spouse were on the road every day, because of the current plague of kangaroos. To avoid this some mothers are leaving their husbands and renting a house in their nearest major centre with a high school so that they can care for their children during the week. This is certainly not conducive to keeping families together. They return home only on weekends, and this often involves a 250- to 300-kilometre drive one way on dirt roads with the added danger of hitting a kangaroo, emu, goat, wild pig or domestic stock.

For others it will mean placing their children in a student hostel in their nearest major centre with a high school. However, these hostels only have limited vacancies, and cost approximately $4,500 per student per year, so some parents are going to find themselves in a very difficult situation. Recently, on a visit to an isolated town in New South Wales, I was approached by two ladies expressing concern that they could no longer afford to pay hostel boarding costs, and this would mean that they would have to withdraw their children from high school in their nearest provincial centre. These ladies are not farmers, but townsfolk on wages, and they cannot afford to pay the difference between the isolated children's allowance and that charged by the hostels. This is not the fault of the hostels because they also are victims of the Government's high income cost policy. This is just one indication of how the rural recession is affecting everyone in the country, and it is a particularly sad day-and a reflection on this Parliament-when the education of rural students is at risk.

As I mentioned earlier, unemployment is also rife in rural Australia. Managers and farm hands are being retrenched and in many cases they do not know where to go; nor do they have anywhere to go. When they lose their jobs they lose the roof over their heads, and finding suitable accommodation while the rural recession continues is becoming very difficult.

With farmers watching every cent they spend and unemployment rising, businesses in country towns are also suffering, and this in turn is affecting industries in the city. The reliance our economy has on the rural sector was exemplified in 1983 when, after a several year drought broke and farmers started to spend again, the total economy picked up. The drought, of course, had a great deal to do with bringing down the government at that time. The reliance we have on the rural sector has not changed.

Businesses in country centres are hurting. They have tightened up as much as possible and are now starting to put off staff. Most businesses with a number of people are looking to where those staff can be relocated-or in most cases they are putting them off.

Unless the Federal Government does something to assist the rural sector, these centres will end up virtual ghost towns. I am not being dramatic, and I know my colleague the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) is going to say something about the effect of the rural recession on these rural towns which mean so much to people in rural areas. Of course-as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in a television broadcast recently said-what we are feeling now is the effect of high interest rates and high input costs that occurred over 18 months ago, so the rural recession really has not struck the capital cities, and when it does I feel sorry for those people who will be affected.

I will leave it there, and just call on the Government to try to do something about it. Whilst I know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has said something about the measures to be taken to assist the rural sector-and I am very pleased to see he is to do something about the rural assistance scheme and other areas, and also is to help the wheat farmers-I believe it goes beyond that. Whilst very, very welcome, we need more than band-aid measures; we need something done very soon about what has happened to the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody recognises the important role that rural Australia plays in our economy and in developing this great nation, and we on this side of the House not only support rural Australia but in the last 12 months have worked through some of the toughest challenges and times that rural Australia has faced to bring together measures which are reflected not only in the long term interest of rural Australia but also in the short term, in regard to direct aid and support.

SPEECH.PARA: Under these circumstances it is easy to understand political opportunism on the part of some honourable members of the Opposition, in utilising the downturn and the effect that that is having on the morale of farmers, to solicit votes. Over the last six to 12 months there has been a massive amount of politicking, particularly on the part of the National Party of Australia, in regard to the effect that the downturn in commodity prices is having on rural Australia.

It is important to rationally and logically go through the causes, and address those causes for the long term as well as for the short term. Regarding the short term solutions, the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) announced this week an increase from $64m to $160m for the rural adjustment scheme and, if need be next year, an increase to $240m. As well as that, the Minister announced $35m in compensation for the loss of sales of our grain to Iraq as a consequence of the embargo on Iraq and the Gulf War.

Regarding the long term solutions, it is important that we improve and proceed to have a fully integrated transport system in this nation. There is a massive saving of approximately $4 billion to be made if we are able to improve our transport system. It does require the support of all the six States; it does require goodwill, and it does require concessions by all parties if we are to get that system up and running.

In regard to the waterfront, this Government is the only government which has addressed the problems of the waterfront. The criticism now is that we are not doing it quickly enough. As I said in a debate earlier in this House, if we climbed Mount Everest the Opposition would want us to climb to the moon. The point is we are addressing this problem sensibly and rationally, but it takes time. The reason it has never been addressed before is that it has been put in the too-hard basket. Previous governments have not wanted to address the problem because they felt it was too hard to handle.

The Government took a further step recently and sent a bipartisan mission to the United States Administration, which I was pleased to be on, to state our case and to show the Americans the effects their enhancement programs are having on us. Of course, we are taking the fight to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) at every opportunity to try to break down the corrupted trade practices of the Europeans.

It is rather ironic that Europe gave birth to this nation yet has tried ever since to suffocate us by the most corrupt trade practices the world has ever seen. The behaviour of the cowards in the European countries that belong to the European Community does them little credit. Unfortunately, a lot of politicking has gone on with regard to the serious downturn in agriculture. One of the results of the National Party jumping on the bandwagon at many of the rallies we have had across Australia, gleefully urging farmers to take out their wrath on the Federal Government, has been to convince bankers and businesses that farmers do not have a great future. They do have a great future. As a result, farmers are paying 5 to 6 per cent more in interest rates than anybody else. I lay the blame for that directly at the feet of those people who tried right at the start to politicise this issue.

When it comes to looking at policies or alternative propositions for agriculture, I think it is a fair judgment to say that National Party members are political transvestites, wearing a different dress when they go to a different audience, and telling farmers not the facts but what they think the farmers want to hear.

The National Party has caught itself out. A classic example of this has been the argument on tariffs: `Nationals split on backing tariff cut'. For years and years the National Party has politicised the Government's attempt to bring down tariffs and to get the tariff monkey off the back of farmers. The tariff cuts set out in the industry statement will mean a reduction in costs for farmers of $350m to $400m. It is a wonderful decision, yet the National Party is still in a time warp, still supporting over-regulation and the tariff monkey, still agonising over the tariff cuts.

It is interesting that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who has been a supporter of maintaining the sugar embargo and maintaining high tariffs, is now agonising. Like the US 7th Cavalry chasing the Comanches, he is caught up with his own stupid rhetoric. The fact is that, by dropping tariffs, end users of sugar in Australia are more competitive; there is less pressure on the consumer price index; and we are in a better position to argue in the GATT. The reality of sugar is that 80 per cent of our market has to be found overseas. To be a short term populist the honourable member for Dawson has made himself look like a goose on this issue. The only other person in north Queensland who has supported him on this is his ridiculous mate, the editor of the Proserpine newspaper.

If we look at some of the other issues and at the behaviour of the National Party, we have the alternative Deputy Prime Minister of Australia saying that we would use United States bases as a last resort bargaining chip. That man has no understanding of foreign affairs, no understanding of our national security and our long term interests, to come up with such a stupid comment. The frightening thing is that he is the alternative Deputy Prime Minister of Australia. I think we are safe, though.
Let us look at what the Liberals are doing. One headline said about Malcolm Fraser-I am sure that some honourable members opposite will remember who he was:
Libs Lost in Bush-Fraser.
He said that there was no coalition policy on rural Australia. Another report states:

Malcolm Fraser . . . has accused the Opposition on its lack of rural policies; a crisis committee has been set-up because of the disenchantment with the Liberal Party . . . comments by Malcolm Fraser . . .

Because things are so tough in the bush the time for rhetoric, the time for populist short term answers, has long gone. What farmers want and need is the truth. If we are going to look after their long term interests, we have to make the tough decisions-not throw money at the issue, because that is not the answer. We have responded with the rural adjustment scheme in the right and proper way because that money is targeted to farmers most in need. But we still have the subsidy can being pushed on the other side. As I have said, it is unfortunate that at every meeting the rhetoric changes.

The interesting thing about the high moral ground the National Party has taken is that when it comes to costs it is the party that is going to support a 15 per cent goods and services tax that will go onto the price of food, clothing, and all the input costs across the board. In itself that will drive down the ability of people to buy our own farm products. It will push inflation through the roof, which again will eat away at the viability of farmers.

If that is not enough, the National Party supports getting rid of Medicare. Because farmers are doing it so tough, the majority of them do not have the opportunity at the present time to purchase private medical insurance. So the farmers who are doing it tough would be the first victims of the right wing, ultra-trendy group in the Liberal and National parties which is going to give the flick to the very social structures that we in government have set up.

When it comes to support for farmers, again it should be recognised that there is a subsidy on diesel fuel of $850m, of which half goes to agriculture. With the Gulf war, the fluctuations in fuel prices impacted directly on farmers, particularly in the grain industry. The Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) was out there saving between 2c and 8c a litre right across the board. What is the Opposition's policy on the PSA? It wants to abolish it-the very mechanism protecting the farmers and all other users of fuel.

The other issue that I have not forgotten but which the National Party would love to forget is the $30m drought rort that went into the pockets of a bunch of greedy graziers. That money could well be used now to help those farmers who are in need. What happened? Under the National Party in Queensland, over five years $30m went into the hands of a bunch of rip-off merchants instead of being targeted to those people most in need. The National Party has the audacity to come into this House and pretend that it cares about farmers. What it cares about is its mates with their heads in the trough right up to their ears, getting as much as they can, and still with the tariff monkey on their backs. They have not got rid of the McEwenism disease that imposed a massive weight on farmers and affected our ability to export. The National Party has never had the courage to get into micro-economic reform. It dropped the ball eight years ago and it is not going to get it back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was surprised to hear from the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice)-particularly as chairman of the rural task force-the tirade we have just had. I say to the honourable member and to all those on the Government side of the House that the motion before us today is not simply a case of political opportunism. As far as this Opposition is concerned, it is not in the too hard basket. In fact, I would suggest to the Government that we on this side of the House are the only group that in government will come to grips with the real need for micro-economic reform, whether it be in the area of a goods and services tax, on the waterfront, industrial relations, and the like. A lot of what the honourable member for Hinkler said was absolute rubbish. He is really out of touch with what is going on in the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion expresses concern about the deteriorating living standards in rural areas. I would go further than that and say that not only is there concern but for many in provincial and rural areas there is very real and deepening hardship . The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) talked principally about the problem on-farm. In the very short period I have available, I would like to talk about the provincial city impact of the problem he raised.

I use as an example the city of Toowoomba, which is at the centre of my electorate of Groom. For those who do not know, it is a city of about 90,000 people. It is the second largest inland city in Australia, not simply a provincial centre but now a microcosm of everything economically that happens in this country.
