Two and a half years ago it was voted in the national press-rightly or wrongly-as the best place in Australia to live. Whether that was because of its educational facilities, its health facilities or its housing standards I really do not know, but I take the opportunity generally to support that contention. It remains the best place in Australia to live; but it is in danger of becoming a city without a soul. That is not as a result of anything the city has done but as a result of the recession we had to have.

My comments today are particularly directed at three Ministers: firstly, the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-that Treasurer responsible for the `recession we had to have'; secondly, the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), with the portfolio responsibility for those 700,000 small businesses out there across our nation; and, thirdly, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who of course has the responsibility for that subset of the small business sector which provides about 40 per cent of our export income, not an insignificant proportion of the small business sector.

As I look around the city of Toowoomba, what do I see? I see farm machinery dealers very much in the grips of the recession-farm machinery dealerships closing. We see seed merchants struggling to make ends meet and, in fact, we have heard recently of plantings being down as much as 40 per cent. As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) quite rightly said, education is a very important area, particularly boarding education. I have 10 or 12 boarding schools in my electorate; it is therefore a very important element. In fact, all schools are reporting to me a general downturn in enrolments, particularly in years seven and eight, as a result of inadequate provisions for isolated children.

Only this morning I checked in my electorate to get a rough idea of the number of retail outlets and empty shops in the central business district of Toowoomba. We did a quick calculation and it seems that there are something like 80 shops empty in the central business district of Toowoomba, a city of 90,000 people. That, I think, clearly exemplifies the problems afflicting rural and provincial Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In making comments upon the standard of living in rural areas, the subject of this motion before the House, I have to reinforce and agree with some of the comments that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) passed with regard to the actions of the Government in assisting people right across Australia, not just in rural Australia. The honourable member for Hinkler did pass comments about actions pertaining particularly to rural Australia and the benefits which will flow to the people there. He did mention some of the changes contained in the 12 March industry statement, and how there is conflict still between the Liberal Party and the National Party with regard to the effects and the worth of some of those changes.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I feel that the general populace of Australia, particularly rural Australia, is coming to realise that we have to shake off the shackles of the past and that in doing that there is some degree of pain, but that, as we move towards the future, those jobs, the employment possibilities, and the wealth of the nation will be enhanced if we are prepared to shoulder those changes and to go ahead positively and productively into the future, and not with negative aspects. It is with regret that I have to comment on the fact that too many members of the National Party are still beating about the bush with negative comments, taking up some of the tougher things that we have had to do and simply illustrating those things to the people in the bush, without illustrating the positive things.

I think the conflict between the Liberal and National parties on the removal of the tariffs, as was illustrated so clearly by the honourable member for Hinkler, is just one of those areas that they just do not seem to be able, or are not prepared, to come to grips with. I know that in my electorate 60 years of neglect was finally put paid to at the last election with the demise of the National Party up there, and it will certainly continue with the State election coming up very shortly, I would presume. Some of the changes that are occurring there, I think, illustrate just the way that the people's perceptions of what is happening will be taken on board.

I had the pleasure towards the end of last year of being at a regional Country Women's Association conference of delegates from branches from not just in my electorate but from the whole coast. In opening the conference, the Mayor of Lismore, Alderman Harold Fredericks, passed the remark that things were a little tough, but that it was senseless for us to talk down the economy in the bush and to talk down the economy in general. He also passed the comment that things were also not so bad in the City of Lismore, the area that he knows so well. He said that that area, particularly the coastal area, was doing quite satisfactorily, and he was most peeved that a number of delegates were prepared to simply talk down the economy in a political sense for a political gain. I must point out to honourable members that the Mayor of Lismore is not a member of the Australian Labor Party, but is indeed a member of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —An honest man.

—I thank him for his honesty when, in speaking to those delegates, he made those statements and backed them; he was prepared to stand up and be counted in that regard. There are lots of things that we have done in the bush to help people, and I will just run through some of them very quickly. The actions of the Government with the rural adjustment scheme, putting in more packages to help farmers remain viable by subsidising interest costs, is one thing. Our changes regarding the cost of phone calls, which have been now put through Cabinet, are again something to help out people in the bush. Our changes with Austudy have helped people there with income. We have raised the threshold level on assets, with a little bludgeoning from both the country task force members and perhaps the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey)- although we did not take a great deal of notice of it! We knew we were going to get it through anyway. The pension increases and the increases in unemployment benefits-all those things are to assist the people out in the bush. But the main thing, I think, that we--
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the standard of living in rural areas, the subject of the motion before the House, I had to do no more than go to my desk this morning and pick up today's mail. I do not want to tell people my views on this matter. I thought it an ideal opportunity to read from some of those letters and give people in this place what people in the country are saying about this Government. This is a small business man and a farmer. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: With respect, our plight on the farm and indeed in the country anywhere, is akin to that of the Israelites in the land of Egypt of long ago. We labour long and hard for what has now become a pittance and before we get that pittance the largest slice of all times has been taken away in costs and propups. We are then taxed indirectly and as well as directly to fatten a lot of greedy bureaucrats . . .
That is signed by a Mr Ridgway from Coomberdale. I have a copy of a letter from Cunderdin addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This lady says:
I left school at 11 years of age to help on my father's farm, during World War II.

I have worked, ever since my marriage in 1954, to help my husband on our moderately-sized farm. After good seasons and poor seasons, we felt that in 1988 we could buy a small additional parcel of land . . . Although we have, since purchasing this extra land, met ALL production &budget schedules, &spent a minimum of money on any unnecessary items at all, we now face the possibility of being unable to carry on our business.

She points out the following: wheat prices halved; wool prices less than half; meat and sheep unsaleable; freight up; fertiliser up; chemicals continually rising; fuel risen; machinery and auto parts risen 50 per cent-and of course, she says, the shearing is going on. I have another letter from a person who wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Keating):

I write on behalf of my son and daughter-in-law . . . In spite of having met production levels in wheat, coarse grain, wool and lambs, according to the Budget schedule for 1990 . . . actual Farm Income is reduced to less than half!! Reluctantly, he &his wife &children travelled 160 kms to apply for family allowance, or at least see if they were eligible; only to be told at the office, that `We are out of application forms. You'll have to come back when we get some more forms . . . ` If it were not so serious and soul-destroying, it would ALL make a first rate FARCE. Are human lives &feelings really totally so VALUELESS to you &your party-
referring to Mr Hawke.
For the first 12 years of development of a bush property, John, another lady's husband, held another off-farm job. He writes:
It seems unbelievable that now I will be required to seek a full time off farm job-just to keep the farm.

Over the 25 years we have had this farm we have generated a great deal of overseas income-2-2.5 million dollars by our estimation and still after 25 years of work and careful living we have had to battle to make ends meet. The interest rate policy of the current Government has brought us to this desperate state.
The discrimination against people who live in country areas is a disgrace, in a democracy.
Country people have children to educate (a very costly business if so isolated)-
and the government has not done enough-
doctors to visit and we would like access to the services that city people enjoy.
Someone else said:
Since 1988 wool income has been reduced by $70,000 even though the quality and quantity of the wool for our 7,200 sheep has increased.
Income from sheep sales has been cut to one third of previous sales and barely covers freight and commission and killing charges. Grain income from 350 acres has reduced by 12 per cent.
The letters go on:
Our own living allowance hasn't increased for two years being $750 per month.
This year we are expecting to run a deficit budget of $33,000.
These people have told me that they bought their farm without debt. They have no higher purchase commitments. Another said:

The once lucrative live sheep trade seems to have been ruined by political misunderstanding and incompetence and it is high time people whose responsibility it is to fix this problem, get off their `backsides' and fix it.

We know who these people were talking about-the Government. One gentleman sent me his latest notice, dated 25 March 1991, from his bank telling him that his interest rate is 17 per cent and 20 per cent if he goes over his limit. What does that have to do with the Government's reduced interest rates? Members of the Government can tell us in here what they are. This is what the bank is telling my constituent. That is the situation in the bush and that is why living standards are falling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) finished his speech by criticising the banks. Rightly so; he should criticise the banks. That is why at present there is an inquiry into the activities of the banks. He really highlighted the fact about what the banks are actually doing to a lot of people, but it is not restricted to rural Australia by any means. He highlighted the point about set interest rates of 17 per cent and the fact that once those people go over their overdraft limit they finish up paying in excess of that. It is a very valid point, about the only thing on which I would agree with him. That is not necessarily the Government's fault; that is the free enterprise system that the banks operate under that creates that. The market forces determine that. It is an area that I believe needs attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) refer to the assets test on family allowance. We all know that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) actually supported an assets test on that in line with the Government's proposal. He was rolled in his party room, which we are all very well aware of. Honourable members need to be reminded again that that particular assets test was net of debt. That is often not mentioned by the Opposition. That is a very important thing. The family allowance helps a lot of people throughout our community. In that particular instance, it was something that needed to be looked at.

Education has been talked about a lot in the rural sector as well. We talk about ghost towns and such things in certain areas. I noticed there was a lot of talk by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling about the people on the land. There was not a lot of discussion about the workers in the rural sector and the workers in the towns. Over a number of years, when working for a bank in Queensland-I spent quite a bit of time in rural areas-a lot of times we found that people from the rural sector, the farmers themselves, ignored a lot of the country towns and always wanted to be associated with the large cities. In the good times they would all go off to the big cities in their planes and Mercedes-Benz cars to take advantage of things there instead of supporting those local towns.

I can remember, when I was the President of the Australian Bank Employees Union, going into bat at one stage for a little town whose branch of the bank was going to close. Naturally, we wanted to keep that open for employment reasons for our own members. I found out during the course of all this that the business in the bank had dropped off so much that it was not a viable proposition to keep it open any more. That rural sector is in the electorate of the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor). It is a place called Forest Hill. No-one shopped around Forest Hill any more; they were all shopping in Gatton. Hence, the business for the bank was no longer viable there. Of course, it finished up as an agency that opened for a few hours a day.

I know that there is a big problem in Ivanhoe about a branch of the Commonwealth Bank closing down. That is a disgrace. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling was right to take that issue up. At least the Commonwealth Bank is still open in some rural areas of Australia. If it were sold off, as the Opposition would like, we would certainly have no rural representation for that banking sector. We need to look at how some of these small towns are supported. The people who work in these businesses suffer a lot from that.

I wish to turn to a case in Queensland. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) is the chairman of the country task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which I am pleased to be associated with as well. I found it quite interesting, moving around Queensland-particularly in the Federal seat of Kennedy at one stage-to notice the big problems there. The problems have not been caused by this Federal Government. They have been caused after 32 years of National-Liberal Party rule in Queensland. Fortunately, that is now being corrected, but it is going to take the Goss Government in Queensland some time to fix that as well.

It was amazing to talk to some of those people in that area. They were more critical of what actually happened in those times. When we talk about rural Australia we have to look at our Aboriginal people because there is still a large percentage of Aboriginal people in rural Australia. These days something like 60 per cent live in urban Australia. In Queensland, in particular, they were dreadfully treated by the former National Party and Liberal Party governments. Those problems have to be corrected. They certainly will be addressed, in time, by the Queensland Government. I know it is giving it a very high priority. All those areas, including education, are areas that need attention.
