SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Events at the New Zealand Stock Exchange yesterday have forced me to rise today to ask the Government to come forth with a full explanation of the present financial situation of Qantas Airways Ltd, the true story behind the investment of Qantas in Air New Zealand and what arrangements have been made between Qantas, Japan Airlines, American Airlines and Brierley Investments Ltd (BIL). Yesterday the New Zealand Stock Exchange was advised that Qantas admitted that agreements that it has with Brierley Investments could result in it controlling 35 per cent of Air New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the notice did not make clear the circumstances in which Qantas would be taking over control of the 15 per cent of Air New Zealand presently held by Brierley. At a time when the Government is trying to move towards the partial privatisation of Qantas, at a time when Qantas is facing unbelievable losses, a full investigation and a full disclosure of some of the activities of Qantas must be forthcoming. The records of the Qantas investment in Air New Zealand make very interesting reading indeed. When Qantas moved into Air New Zealand its report of 30 June 1989 showed that the Qantas share of 19.99 per cent of Air New Zealand cost it some $NZ232m.

There was another fascinating aspect of that too because of the arrangements that it had with Japan Airlines, American Airlines and, indeed, with BIL to ensure that British Airways did not get into the deal. The reports also show that there was $NZ162m that acted as loans to the other shareholders to try to stitch up that particular deal.

In actual fact, Qantas paid a surcharge to take over its share of the Air New Zealand deal. It would appear that the New Zealand Government price for the sale of Air New Zealand was $2.357 per share, but the Qantas report of 30 June 1989 shows that Qantas paid $4.14 per share-a premium of $NZ100m. We are now aware that American Airlines has taken up its option and wants out of that deal and Qantas may have to take over that shareholding. There is some doubt as to whether or not Qantas may be forced to take over the Brierley shareholding as well.

At a time when Qantas is facing losses, variously estimated to be between $356m and $500m for the year, I think that the people of Australia and the Parliament need a full explanation of what is going on in Qantas. The statements by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) in recent weeks do not give one much confidence in terms of what is happening at Qantas. It was Minister Beazley who refused to give his endorsement, or vote of confidence, to the directors of Qantas Airways, or indeed to the management. Honourable members might remember his statement that he had confidence in the Chairman of Qantas, Mr Dix, but he refused to give his endorsement to any other of the major players.

What is going on at Qantas? It is absolutely amazing when one of its major competitors, such as Singapore Airlines, can say it has had a dreadful year and its profits are down 8 per cent to $US400m, or when Thai International can say it has had a dreadful year, its profits are down 9 per cent and it is making only $US386m, or when Cathay Pacific can say it has had a dreadful year because of fuel prices and the Gulf war and its profits are down to about $US400m. But Qantas blames the pilots strike, the increase in fuel prices and the Gulf for a $125m loss last year and a loss of up to half a billion this year, and there are estimates of what might happen in the next financial year.

We have heard time and again from the Government how well it has got Qantas on line. Yet we hear that Qantas is going to have to sack some 5,000 staff members. What is going on? Twelve months ago we heard that Qantas was going to have a major reduction in its senior staff. I would like to know how many senior staff have gone. I understand the number is very tiny indeed. We also heard as recently as last month that there were to be massive cuts in Qantas management. Following press reports that high-flying Qantas executives may be forced to take salary cuts in a brutal cost cutting campaign to curb the airline's already devastating losses, within 10 days we found out that a salary cut of 5 per cent for senior management of Qantas had turned out to mean no loss of income for most of the executives it was supposed to affect. The Qantas executives had an extra rostered day off per month and they were going to give that up. That was going to be the cost savings. As one Qantas executive said, who has ever heard of a company which gave its senior executives an extra day off to work 19 days a month?

The Government must come clean with some of the commercial deals that have been done by Qantas and what has been the cost of those. They were heralded less than two years ago as being the most amazing arrangements with Lufthansa and American Airlines, so there would be code sharing and traffic sharing. Those deals amounted to absolutely nothing. There must be a disclosure of some of the commercial dealings that Qantas has done with some of the consolidators around the place. What sort of yield is Qantas getting on some of those fares it is selling at the moment?

What we would like to know and to understand is this: what are the circumstances surrounding the departure of John Menadue two years ago as the chief executive officer of Qantas? His was a Government appointment; yet he left in mysterious circumstances with a deal being done between Menadue, the board and the senior executives of Qantas. Agreements were signed that nobody would talk about the reason for his demise. Yet we have found out that during the period he was in charge of Qantas there was a massive explosion of staff, that all the commercial decisions have proved to be wrong and now some 5,000 Qantas staff have to be retrenched.

We want to know how much of a say the Government has had in the day-to-day running of Qantas. Is it true that there is a hot line between the various Ministers and the Qantas management? Is it true when Qantas management complains that it receives up to eight ministerial directives a day? These questions must be answered. Yet the Government is on the record as saying that it is doing all the right things. One can go through the public statements of Ministers Beazley and Willis over the years. It is not too long ago-in fact, less than two years, on 1 June-when the then Minister for Transport and Communications, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), referring to government business enterprises, cited Qantas as having a performance that was absolutely outstanding. He said that the Qantas performance within the environment created by the Hawke Government was quite spectacular. He said that Qantas had created a context of more innovative and creative commercial decisions. We applaud that. As we go through all these references we find that we have an airline that is a shell of its former self. It is in an unbelievable financial mess and it is an absolute basket case. There must be a full disclosure of what the real financial situation is at Qantas, because the Government is in the turmoil at the moment of trying to work out how it will have the capacity to privatise 49 per cent of the airline.

Privatisation is not all about having fire sales of government assets. If we have a financial basket case with the national carrier, what is the Government going to do to get over that situation? Privatisation must be about efficiencies and competition and of being able to bring more affordable air fares to the people of Australia and for international visitors coming here. Yet we are expecting losses of up to half a billion dollars this year and perhaps even more next year. What future does Qantas have under this regime?

The Opposition urges the Government, as a matter of priority, to have a very good and close look at what is happening with the Qantas board. Mr Beazley has made a couple of changes, but what Qantas needs more than anything is a high-flying commercialised board-a board made up of proven performers in private industry-to try to get the airline back into some sort of shape so it can go towards privatisation and so the taxpayers of Australia, who are the shareholders in Qantas, have the opportunity of getting some real return when the 49 per cent privatisation comes about.

Qantas is in an awful mess. This House and the shareholders of Qantas-the taxpayers of Australia-have a real need to know exactly what the true financial situation is. They have a need to know exactly what is going on and to have a realisation of the unbelievable mess that this Government has managed to make of one of the world's proudest airline carriers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to publicly expose the maladministration and improper financial management of the Queensland Justices Association Inc. (QJA). My allegations come from a past president, a past vice-president and past senior officers of the QJA and are the result of a four-month investigation into the past and present activities of one Peter MacDonald, the full time registrar of the QJA who is also the owner and full time manager of the Peter MacDonald consultancy firm.

SPEECH.PARA: The allegations have been documented and they include the gross financial mismanagement of the QJA over eight years when MacDonald was part time and full time registrar, as shown by the fact that through improper practices and sheer incompetence MacDonald has turned a highly profitable organisation into one facing a massive financial loss. In 1983, it had $65,000 in reserves in a working account. Last year it recorded a massive loss of $57,274, and this was despite the fact that membership fees blew out from $6 a year to $30 a year and a number of profitable business ventures were introduced; for example, JP plaques, costing $95 each-although the QJA received only $4-video training tapes at $50 each; an upgraded journal; a JP travel service; a JP insurance plan; JP stamps at $25; ID cards at $12.50; and badges. Remember, this is an association that has something like 10,000 members.

MacDonald is accused of blatantly misusing his position as registrar for his own commercial ends and personal financial advantage. This has been demonstrated by the figures that have been presented to me by these people. He broke a personal and formal undertaking given on 10 September 1985 when he said he would declare all profits he was making through the QJA and he has not honoured that.

Instead, over this period he has made massive amounts of money for himself. He has turned this organisation, which in 1983 had outgoings of $45,000, into one which in 1989 had outgoings of $150,000. He has made massive changes in registration fees for himself and in clerical assistance which he has used. He is accused of manipulating the Association's accounts so that everything possible has to go through his consultancy firm. He operates from the same office, yet the Association pays 85 per cent of the rent of an unknown lease controlled by his consultancy firm.

He is employed as a full time registrar, yet he operates a full time consultancy firm using the QJA office, using the QJA computer, using the QJA staff-except for one person-the fax machine, the phone numbers and the legal advisers. But in the Queensland Business Directory Peter MacDonald Consultancy is listed as employing five to nine staff and it is supposed to have an expensive NCR computer. This is simply not true. He has even had the QJA put in a new, expensive telephone system, and he lists the entry in bold print in the telephone directory as his numbers.

MacDonald has blatantly misused his position for personal profit, illustrated by the fact that on 18 June 1988, in his capacity as the full time registrar, MacDonald ran a justice of the peace (JP) seminar. He has tried to smother that fact and has covered up the actual accounts; but invoice No. 661 reveals some of the story. Despite the fact that he was a full time registrar on a substantial annual retainer, he charged $1,000 for his own consultancy services and for himself to attend his own seminar.

During the same period leading up to the seminar and its aftermath, he charged the QJA another $1,000 in fees. He charged the Association $500 for rent and $2,827.28 for clerical assistance during the period. He claimed $1,624 for advertisements in a major newspaper. He declared an income for the seminar of $2,695, but he charged the Association $3,374 just for advertising, room hire and his personal attendance fee. There are no records of the true cost of running the seminar, of the venue or of advertising. There are no records of the true cost of rental or of the running of the QJA office. There are no records of the true cost of manufacturing the JP plaques, the JP stamps or printing the JP journal Justice . . . and the JP. Everything goes through MacDonald's consultancy firm. He bills the QJA without full substantiation, and the QJA has just paid up. Even the new legal adviser who was employed by the QJA is somehow on MacDonald's payroll. On one occasion the net wages were being paid by the QJA but MacDonald's firm was paying the group tax. I am sure that the Australian Taxation Office ought to have a look at that.

There have been strange goings-on with the non-payment of workers compensation for QJA employees. There is also a need to investigate a claim by MacDonald's firm for the payment of wages for an employee who had long since resigned and did not even claim her full entitlements. There is a need to investigate allegations of the misuse of proxy votes to elect a council sympathetic to MacDonald. There is also a need to investigate claims that he falsely gave information about the right of the QJA to conduct a State-wide postal ballot to elect its officers. He failed to include nomination forms in the journal prior to the annual general meeting. He failed to send proxy forms to members. He has blatantly kept information from the membership. There was even an attempt to cover up the loss of $57,274. The annual reports were significantly changed last year to cover up income and expenditure details.

His strategy has been to demand that all key accounts are handled by his consultancy firm. There is no information about hidden commissions or the topping-up costs. The allegations go on. He unconstitutionally signed an annual return in 1988. He even waged a campaign by legal action against his own members and his own branches. He even took one branch on the Gold Coast to court. He has removed any council members who questioned him-even presidents and vice-presidents. In 1984 MacDonald was accused by his critics of milking the Queensland Justices Association. Since that time he has finetuned his operations. Because of the incompetence, particularly of the present President, Mrs Clancy, he has continued to be able to make massive financial personal profits from this association. He has been protected by his cronies.
Mrs Merle Clancy, in the last edition of the journal Justice . . . and the JP, says:
The allegations that are being raised now by myself and ex-presidents and many other executive members are``old hat''.

She claims that they were investigated in 1989 by the Corporate Affairs Commission, which, after a full investigation, `found they had no substance'. I quote from an official letter from the Commissioner for Corporate Affairs, Mr J. V. M. Green, following his investigation of Peter MacDonald's activities and the QJA administration. Commissioner Green says:

. . . breaches of provisions of the Companies (Queensland) Code have occurred and there have been numerous occasions when the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association have not been complied with.

He goes on to say that sections 274 and 275 of the code have been breached, as well as clauses 26 and 35 of the articles of association. He talks also about auditors and solicitors not being properly appointed, the registrar acting wrongly at annual meetings and even the president being illegally elected because he was too old.

The most damning aspect here regarding Peter MacDonald was exposed also by the Commissioner. He exposed that MacDonald, even though he was the one, as a full time registrar, who set up this JP journal for the Association and the business JP Plaques, actually registered the journal and the plaques in his own company's name: Melkadee Pty Ltd. Commissioner Green says:
I consider the Committee should require the details of his (MacDonald's) business interests connected with the Association to be disclosed.

I see it as being inconsistent with the provisions that the Registrar . . . should be able to use the organisation to make profits for himself to the degree that a commercial advantage is being obtained by him or to obtain a significant personal advantage.
Commissioner Green says:
Unless there is strict compliance in regard to the abovementioned directions, steps will be taken for you--
That is the Association-
to show cause why the licence under which the Association is incorporated should not be revoked.

Yet here we have a president saying, `It is old hat; there is no substance to it.' This president has tried to cover up the blatant misuse of association funds. The council, under the leadership of Merle Clancy, has closed its eyes to MacDonald's practices. It has never challenged him for a billing system to know what it has been paying. It appointed people whenever he wanted them. There is still no accountability of MacDonald's use of the Association's office, equipment or finances, yet Mrs Clancy goes on and says that the allegations have no substance and were supposed to be old hat. Mrs Clancy, like MacDonald, has blatantly lied to the members of the Association and like MacDonald she has been part of an attempted cover-up for MacDonald to use the Association for his personal financial benefit. She should immediately resign her position; so should those other councillors who have been involved in this conspiracy to cover up.

As for MacDonald, his whole sordid role in the Queensland Justices Association should immediately be investigated, not only by the Queensland Attorney-General, but also by the Australian Taxation Office. For eight years MacDonald has milked the QJA for his own financial benefits. He has abused his position as registrar of a most reputable organisation. He has been aided and abetted by a number of incompetent, irresponsible people such as Mrs Clancy, who is also a blatantly dishonest person.

The time has come to put an end to MacDonald's sinister control of the QJA, so there will really be justice for the people of Queensland. This issue has been there for eight years. People tried back in 1984 to do something about MacDonald, but this man was very powerful in the old days because he is also the private minder and private journalist of Joh Bjelke-Petersen. He has even waged legal actions against individuals who criticised him and used QJA funds, legal funds, to carry out those vendettas-yet the settlements and judgments were to go to him. Clearly this is a case that has to be exposed and, despite other matters that I hope to raise tonight in the adjournment debate, I believe these matters ought to be taken up by the Queensland Attorney-General and also by the Australian Taxation Office.
I seek leave of the House to table documents from the Commissioner of Corporate Affairs and other matters that relate to business names in this connection.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to discuss matters related to young people and unemployment rates. One of the great tragedies that this country is facing today is the fact that 24 to 25 per cent of our young people aged 15 to 19 are unemployed. That reflects very much, I believe, on the policies of this Government and the policies which have been in place over a period of six or seven years. The tragedy, of course, is that some in the Government quite genuinely would like to have made certain reforms within the waterfront and shipping, with industrial relations in particular. But unfortunately for Australia and for many families and young people the Government has not had the capacity to do it. The Government has obviously been bound to two particular groups of people in this country for the last seven or eight years and is now faced with a recession. We have not got the structural changes which could have been brought about and which would have benefited many young people and many families and far fewer people in this country would have been thrown on to the unemployment scrap heap than otherwise would have been the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just go back over some of the figures so that people are reminded of the unemployment situation which we are faced with at this stage. The Government, of course, has been very keen to compare the record of the past coalition government with its record. We find that average unemployment in the Fraser years was 6.3 per cent; under the Hawke years, at the moment it is 7.95 per cent and on the way up. Of course, as people realise, it is now sitting at 9.2 per cent. This means that at the highest period under the Fraser years, 676,000 people were unemployed. Now there are 777,000 people unemployed, on seasonally adjusted figures-just over 100,000 more than the highest figure under the Fraser Government. Over eight years of the Hawke Government, the unemployment rate, on average, has been 25 per cent higher than the average rate during the eight years of the Fraser Government.

Many Australians have suffered because employment opportunities have not been there for them. So we are now faced with a set of circumstances where a large number of our young people are unemployed and an increasing number of people in middle age and getting up into their fifties are also finding themselves out of work. Of course, this leads to a loss of self-esteem, particularly amongst our young people. They have a sense of failure and are disillusioned with their society and the community in which they live. Out of that comes, after a few months or years, a great degree of cynicism about the policies and the society in which they are now placed. Not only is there within the person this loss of self-esteem and disillusionment, but also for the nation there is the loss of the skill base within our country. It is very important that our young people can develop skills with which they can contribute to community life-whether it be within their families or in being really positive contributors and participants rather than people who need other people's support. Those skills and skills which are of economic benefit to the country are developed during those vital years, yet we are failing to encourage that as a nation.

I point to a couple of illustrations where this Government has failed dismally, even though it says it is very positive about encouraging investment and development and providing opportunities for people to be employed. Coronation Hill is a classic example, as is the Wesley Vale project, one which is very close to my electorate. Many people who would have been employed on that project live at Wesley Vale within my electorate. I believe the Federal Government really wanted that project; the State Government wanted that project; the local community wanted that project; but when it came to the point the Government was prepared to bow to political pressure from the environmental movement.

Even though the Government generally says it is positive about business investment and encouraging business opportunities, the consequence of this is that every time a major project comes up, it ultimately takes a course of action which prevents its development. As this occurs year after year, in 1991 the job market is shrinking rapidly. It is a great tragedy for many of our young people that they have to sit at home, work out what they are going to do the next day, decide which video they are going to go out and hire, hire it and then go home and sit in the lounge room. It is a very devastating experience for many of these young people. The Government did have the capacity and still has an opportunity to do something about this by changing the industrial relations system within this country, changing and sharpening up the waterfront and the shipping area. If we did this the country would be far more competitive. Our business operations in this country would grow and develop and as a consequence there would be more investment.

At the moment investment in Australia is at a horrific low. That is why there are no employment opportunities. Twenty-five per cent of our 15-to 19-year-olds are sitting at home, going to the beach, wandering the streets, sitting down at the supermarkets, chatting, and filling in time because the Government has not taken the tough decisions to make us competitive and viable. It had the opportunity and fluffed it.

Another group to which the Government is beholden is the trade union movement, particularly the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). If the Government could remove itself from the shackles of the ACTU, it could take some of the policy directions that it would like to have taken. There are some in the Government-I know because I have talked to some of them-who would like to have gone down a different path. We know from some of the statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he would have liked to have gone down a different path, but could not do so because the union movement would not allow him. So we have a government here that now has got to a point of crisis.

There are two real crises in the country: one is within the Government and the other is out there at the grassroots of Australian society, young people and families. Families do not know whether they are going to have a breadwinner next week or the week after and young people have never had the opportunity to earn bread. The other crisis in this country is that the Government is preoccupied within itself, with its internal struggles, with its leadership debate. There were discussions even this week by one of the factions on whether it should keep the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or have a look at Paul. It is these sorts of preoccupations which the Government ought to move away from.

I would encourage the Government to get those things behind it and to present some vision for Australia, because young people and families are desperately crying out for opportunity, for a reward for effort. They are prepared to put in the effort, to get into it, but the Government is shackled, particularly by the environmental movement and the trade union movement. These shackles have not allowed it to move down pathways to give people an opportunity. So it has lost its vision. Of course, it is not only that. We recognise when we go out amongst the community and talk to people that the Government is perceived as being arrogant and out of touch, that it somehow does not understand where Australia is now at. I guess that is one of the consequences of not taking the really tough decisions throughout the last five or six years to bring about changes so that there could be real investment in Australia. It is a great tragedy that so many of our young people are now unemployed because of this Government's policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when the Australian clothing industry is improving its efficiency to meet overseas competition, it is a matter of serious concern that some operators are cutting the industry's throat by using low wage outworkers illegally and improperly. Australia's reputable clothing manufacturers are streamlining their operations, complying with the requirements of relevant State and Federal laws and employing workers in accordance with relevant industrial awards and safety provisions. They now face a growing threat from unscrupulous operators, not entrepreneurs, but despicable individuals who are importing Third World working conditions into this country and this industry via outworker arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of two Brisbane manufacturers and three Sydney manufacturers who are widely known in the industry to supply garments at prices we would expect to find in underdeveloped over-exploited countries. The use of outworkers or home workers is not a new phenomenon; however, it is a growing one. Union officials in this industry have successfully prosecuted unscrupulous producers in this field in New South Wales, recovering over $50,000 in unpaid wages in the last two years. One Brisbane firm, which has specialised in supplying Queensland sports clothes, claims to employ only two people for the entire operation-administration, manufacturing and sales.

A director of that firm, who claims to be one of the two employees, informed a Queensland industrial inspector that this was the case. What is more, I understand that the company has only one domestic sewing machine, yet it is able to fill orders for hundreds of tracksuits and other sportswear for various schools in Brisbane. What makes the claim even more interesting is the fact that everyone in the industry knows that you require between three and five industrial sewing machines to produce one commercial tracksuit. I am informed that this two-person team supplies approximately 13 south-east Queensland private schools with sports clothes, tracksuits, et cetera.

I have spoken to this director myself. The proposition that he makes a living by himself and his wife sewing away frantically-just the two of them-is an absurd and preposterous suggestion. It begs the question: just what sort of work practices, pay and safety conditions is this person so keen on keeping from public scrutiny? A Brisbane manufacturer recently wrote:

The situation is that over the last 18 months we have gone from 95 employees to 55 employees and this situation could deteriorate if something is not done about the thousands, and I repeat thousands of home sewers manufacturing garments that would normally be sewn in legitimate factories.
These people are not covered by award wages, superannuation etc.. and are not subject to the many government regulations factories and businesses have to observe.

It is not the actual sewers that are at fault, but the companies . . . who use these people that should be prosecuted. In some cases these people have three or four machinists as a front but manufacture thousands of garments each week through their network of outworkers.
The fellow whom I previously mentioned is not even smart enough to do that.
On Tuesday evening in this place, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) once again demonstrated the thoughtful and compassionate nature that has earned him the nickname `Iron Bar'. He said:

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) . . . painting the picture of the sweatshop-of somebody being locked away at home with a treadle sewing machine having to turn out 10,000 pieces of clothing a day to make two quid a day.
He continued:
Has he-
that is, the honourable member for Newcastle-
ever been in a typical Australian family home recently? For instance, has he ever seen where the sewing machine might be? it seems to be out in that nice, sunny . . . room.
Then we come to the Opposition's real agenda in these matters, because he went on to say:
We believe in giving them the encouragement, the incentives through voluntary agreements, to want to produce more and to produce it cheaper.

Once again the honourable member for O'Connor makes assertions and attacks other people without having the slightest idea of what is actually occurring in the industry. He and his ilk should think about the outworker in Sydney who was being used, or rather abused, by a manufacturer. This individual was working from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. After an investigation by the union, an action is being brought against that operator. Had that woman been paid award rates, she would have received an additional $19,671 in pay.

The following cases involve workers in Victoria. In the first, a prosecution in a magistrates court was brought against the employer concerning underpayment of an outworker. The claim was settled by the payment of over $9,000 to the outworker. In the second case, an outworker made a claim against her former employer for various underpayments. This matter was settled with a payment of $15,000 to the outworker.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am talking about massive exploitation. Are they the sorts of voluntary agreements that the honourable member for O'Connor and the Opposition favour? The Industrial Relations Commission has made clear its view of this practice-and not surprisingly, it does not conform with the sort of view expressed by the honourable member for O'Connor and the Opposition. Deputy President Riordan, in a judgment on one such case in 1987, said:
The present system of work outside the award provisions represents a serious obstacle to the achievement of justice and equity in the workplace.
He went on to say:

The evidence in this case of breaches and blatant evasion of the relevant award provisions, with the consequential unfair exploitation of the persons concerned, demands that the strongest possible protection be given to ensure compliance with the award conditions.

Forget about the breaches of the award and the lack of safety and superannuation entitlements-just as long as there is a ray of light filtering into the room. That is all that the honourable member for O'Connor and the Opposition seem to think that some Australian workers are entitled to. Fortunately, that view is not shared by most people in the industry. I am heartened by and pleased with the cooperation between responsible employers and unions involved in clothing manufacture. They are working together to build a competitive Australian clothing industry which we can be proud of, one in which workers share equitably in the profits of their labour, one in which they are able to enjoy a safe, clean work environment, and one which can compete successfully with imported clothing in both quality and price-an industry where the cancer of outwork is eradicated. I commend those employers and unions.

The Commonwealth and State governments have a role and responsibility in this fight. It requires resources and it requires commitment. If we are to end illegal importation of Third World salaries and conditions, we must act, and act now, while we still have honest and reputable manufacturers left in the industry. As a first step, we should immediately withdraw the opportunity for unscrupulous employers to use the Australian made logo. The Buy Australian campaign is not just aimed at import replacement. It represents to consumers a symbol that the product has been made in Australia to a standard and under conditions regarded as satisfactory in our country. Clearly, in terms of wages, that means payment of relevant award rates and it does not mean sweatshop salary rates at one-quarter of the prevailing award rates. That is the cancer which is filtering through the clothing industry at present.

I found somewhat interesting the comments of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the Opposition member who spoke previously in the grievance debate, when he referred to industrial relations and the need for some change in the way in which industrial relations is structured in this country. Those on the Opposition benches promulgate a view that we should eliminate the Industrial Relations Commission from the process and allow the workers in their individual places of employment to negotiate with their employers regarding conditions of service. Anybody on either side who has been involved in industrial relations knows where the balance of power rests in that regard-it rests with the person who has the H.R. Nicholls Society, the big lawyers and the right to hire and fire on his side. The result would be a reduction in the living standards of Australian workers across the board.
I wish to make clear my intention to pursue this matter further, to work with the industry and relevant Ministers and to see the culprits in this crime brought to account under the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address a range of problems currently facing the electorate of Isaacs as a result of the Hawke-Keating Government's lack of interest in middle Australia. I am aware that many other parts of Australia are experiencing similar problems and I am very conscious of the fact that the rural sector is currently experiencing severe hardship as a result of this Government's economic incompetence. However, during this afternoon's grievance debate I wish to restrict my comments to the damage being inflicted upon Australia's manufacturing industries and, in particular, the Moorabbin industrial estate and the Braeside industrial area within my electorate, which together comprise a substantial part of this nation's small manufacturing base.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has consistently got it wrong. It has got it wrong because it relies on the Canberra bureaucrats for advice on subjects of which they have only a theoretical knowledge. The Government's whole approach to economics is based on theory, whereas I speak on behalf of those who have a practical and working knowledge of the crisis facing Australia and the manufacturing sector in particular.

On 8 November 1990, I indicated to the House that unemployment would rise and that the Government's statistics were understating the problem. I made this statement with the knowledge of what was happening in my electorate. On that same day, I asked the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to visit the electorate of Isaacs and see for himself the damage that his Government's policies were causing. Once again, I invite the Treasurer to leave the cloisters of Canberra and visit my electorate. He should come and experience the real world of industry. He should come and witness the problems these businesses are having in keeping their doors open. The Treasurer should not delay, because the doors of industry are closing very quickly in my electorate.

Contrary to the approach of the Treasurer and this failed Government, there are no quick fix solutions to the current problems facing Australian industry. Yet the March industry statement by the Government is a perfect example of the fact that the Treasurer believes in the quick fix or bandaid approach. The Government's attitude to the removal of tariffs is proof that there is no commitment to substantial economic reform of our economy. To the contrary, the Government is telling Australian industry that tariff barriers are to be reduced and that the industry must either sink or swim within this context. In theory, this might appear an acceptable approach, but let me tell the House that those who are component suppliers to the automotive industry or those who are competing against imported products do not agree.

I accept that there are benefits to be gained from the lowering of tariffs. It will encourage manufacturers and producers to stay at the leading edge of technology and competitiveness. But those advantages can only-I repeat only-be realised if we have a level playing field. To be of value, tariff reforms must be accompanied by significant micro-economic reform which hits at the real heart of the problems facing manufacturers in this country.

This Government is willing to throw manufacturers to the wolves. It is prepared to take away the tariff barriers which allow them to compete without any signs that it will address the real issue requiring immediate attention-significant micro-economic reform.

The Government has been arguing for a flat $12 increase for workers and for an increase in occupational superannuation-all at a time when unemployment is rising and when this Government is telling us that businesses need to improve their efficiency and become more competitive. In his industry statement the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
This Government will continue to open up the manufacturing sector and Australian industry generally through lower protection.
I say to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that unless lower protection is accompanied by other reforms, they will not just open up the manufacturing sector, they will totally destroy it.

Support from the Government for the $12 increase, even though it was not successful, is proof that the Government is not serious about micro-economic reform. Industry is expected to launch itself into a new era, but this Government has entrenched itself in an arbitration system that should be dead and buried.

This week's pay increase should not be seen in isolation when we talk about the obstacles facing industry in this country. What about the increase in payroll tax? What about the increase in the trainee guarantee scheme contributions based on a percentage of payroll? What about WorkCare and other workers' compensation increases? What about increases in sales tax? What about increases in State and Federal government taxes on bank accounts? What about the effects of this pay increase on long service leave payments? What about the effect that this increase will have on holiday pay, with our unique 17.5 per cent loading? Finally, what about the inflationary impact that is felt throughout the entire economy? And all this at a time when unemployment is rising and businesses are struggling to hold their staff.

We are not talking about a clever country; we are talking about a very silly government. It is a government that has a blind loyalty to its union mates; a government that cannot see that, by its very actions, or perhaps one should say inactions, it is making the task of manufacturing in this country a nightmare.

So far I have only dealt with wage increases and the Government's refusal to introduce reform to this area. But there are many other areas which require immediate attention and should be given priority in any worthwhile program of micro-economic reform. What about power? The fact is that in this country our manufacturers pay about 30 per cent more than our trading partners for power for production. On the waterfront, the average turnaround of ships is five days, compared with 12 hours in Hong Kong and five hours in Singapore. Yet the Prime Minister comes into this place and talks about our efficiency increases on the waterfront as a percentage. That is typical of the selective statistics that this Government uses to justify its arguments. These are good examples of the reforms required to create a level playing field that manufacturers need if they are to continue to survive this Government's tariff reduction program.

The Government is constantly telling Australian industry that it is time for it to become more competitive, yet at the same time it allows the union movement to continue antiquated work practices which are strangling small business operators. Examples from my home State of Victoria in the public transport sector include the restrictive work practice that requires single skilled workers to carry out maintenance on Met trains. A union ban on using multiskilled employees means that it takes 20 people to carry out routine maintenance when it could be done with four employees. There are multiskill bans that mean that when matching holes are to be drilled in timber and steel, two tradesmen are required-one to drill in timber and one in steel. There is overstaffing on many railway stations where platform staff can often include one person to wave the train away, another to operate the public address system, a supervisor, a second supervisor, a first man, a second man and a third man, all with unspecified duties. I could go on and on with further examples-the list is endless. With those rorts in full swing this Government has the gall to tell Australian manufacturers to become more competitive.

In contrast to the Government's position, the Opposition is working closely with industry to ensure that the coalition's policies will help, rather than hinder, Australian industry. The coalition parties will introduce a comprehensive and wide reaching program of economic reform in complete contrast to the Government's piecemeal approach. The coalition rejects the Government's bandaid solutions to Australia's economic woes, when what is required is major surgery. Further evidence of the coalition's approach to this important issue is detailed in the speech to the National Press Club on 6 March 1991 by the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan). I quote:

. . . unlike the Government, we consider it would be unreasonable and unfair to expect industry to cope with further reductions in protection without accompanying comprehensive reforms in areas where inefficiencies increase production costs.

In conclusion, I wish to draw to the attention of the House a letter dated 30 June 1987 sent to business houses in the Isaacs electorate during the 1987 Federal election campaign. I was the Liberal candidate in the electorate of Isaacs at that time and I would like to quote from that letter:
I know that small business is the engine room of our economy. It employs the most people and has the greatest potential to generate jobs.

The letter is signed by P.J. Keating, Treasurer. If it is good enough for the Treasurer to send such a letter of interest in business in the electorate of Isaacs during the 1987 election campaign, and to write letters on government letterhead at taxpayers' expense, it is reasonable to expect that the Treasurer would now display some interest in, and concern for, the well-being and condition of industry and small business within the electorate of Isaacs and throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to report to the House that I received a letter from the Australian Automobile Association (AAA) on 22 March 1991, expressing concern over the Government's proposed banning of political advertising. I want to canvass that issue in the next couple of minutes. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to express our Association's deep concern over the proposal to impose a complete and permanent ban on so-called political advertising in the electronic media.

As the Federal Secretariat of the State and Territory motoring organisations, AAA is responsible for representing the interests of their 5.2 million members and, indirectly, all Australian motorists at the national level.
In order to fulfil this role, our Association has occasionally had to resort to paid advertising to ensure that motoring consumers are aware of issues affecting them.

I was at the receiving end in the last Federal election of some of the paid advertisements which the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland ran against the Government at that time. I do not deny its right to advertise its points of view, of course, but I was not at all pleased with the views which it purported to be the truth and on which it spent a great deal of money to issue to the electors of Petrie. Mind you, it did it no good whatsoever.

When the Australian Automobile Association-supposedly representing the interests of five million members-says that it wants freedom of speech, then it ought to know that freedom of speech costs about $13,000 a minute on television. It is not free. The issue for the Australian Automobile Association is: why can it-a powerful, wealthy organisation-put a particular point of view across but others cannot? That is the issue that I want to address.

It seems to me that the automobile associations are basically a lobby for the car industry, oil and rubber industry and the road-building industry, and that position is well known. A risk is being run in this country where large and powerful organisations with a particular viewpoint can be heard much more readily than those organisations that do not have the money to pay $13,000 a minute for television advertising. It is that sort of proposition which the Australian Labor Party is going to address during this debate on the banning or otherwise of paid political advertising.

The Australian Automobile Association and those who wish more roads to be built in Australia have done very well indeed. In 1981-82, the Federal Government spent $685m on land transport funding, a very minor proportion of which was spent on rail funding. By 1990-91, we were spending $1,610m on roads. The great jump in that expenditure, of course, arose in the 1983-84 Budget, where spending rose from $850m to $1,195m. This was a consequence, of course, of the stimulus given by the previous Liberal Government through the bicentennial road development program which was introduced on Budget night of 1982.

I do not dispute the fact that most of the taxation on petrol and the car industry would easily cover the amount spent on roads. But when organisations like AAA enter the fray, they inevitably put a very biased point of view and that can lead to sufficient pressure on governments to distort government funding. We do not hear the other side of the argument. The Federal Government is at pains to get people to understand that we prefer everyone to have a shot at election time at making their views known, not only those who are able to pay for those views to be expressed through paid advertisements.

The alternative side of the argument, which AAA would never have put and would never congratulate the Federal Government on, of course, is that if one increases expenditure on road funding one does not always get a better drive; one does not always look after one's five million members. In a recent report by the Economic Planning Advisory Council entitled Urban and Regional Trends and Issues-this is nothing new, but EPAC has done some work on policies to deal with traffic congestion which I use as an example here-it says:
. . . increased provision of roads does not always lead to reduced traffic congestion and accident costs. United States experience shows that it can lead to:
- housing and other development on urban fringes creating urban sprawl;
- reduction in the proportion of journeys by public transport;
- longer journeys (in terms of both time and distance) on average; and
- higher fuel consumption per capita as fuel efficiency of faster free flowing traffic is offset by increases in journey lengths of people living further away from the city.

The automobile associations would never put that sort of proposition, because it is a more difficult proposition to put, it is not so easily saleable and it is not one that would be immediately appreciated by the ordinary commuting public whom they purport to represent.

It is fair, and it is in the interests of freedom of speech in this country, that we do stop political advertising on television and radio so that we do not have these sorts of distortions brought up during election times. It is difficult enough for members of the public to make up their minds on who to vote for without these sorts of groups with big money entering the fray.

The United States electoral system has been totally corrupted because it does not have our system of party solidarity which gives protection to the individual member. The United States has an electoral system whereby individual members of the House of Representatives or senators have their campaigns paid for by large interests such as automobile associations, et cetera. We have a system that enables us to make reasonable decisions without undue influence by a large group of people who have sufficient money to pay for significant amounts of political advertising.
There was a good comment by Claude Forell in the Age yesterday, 17 April 1991, headed: `Manipulation is the message'. He commented:

Political advertising is something the Labor Party can't afford, the Liberals and Nationals don't need, and the public doesn't want. And no matter how clever or vivid, it isn't going to alter the outcome of the next election.
That is a brutally honest assessment of some of the rationale for introducing this ban on political advertising and Claude Forell, I think, is absolutely correct. But he goes on:

Let's not be kidded that this involves some lofty principle of freedom of speech. As veteran adman Phillip Adams has put it, political advertising has as much to do with free speech as graffiti on a dunny wall.
I think Phillip Adams, as nearly always, is absolutely correct on this one.

All three major political parties understand now that the cost of putting political ads to air is getting beyond them and that the danger of being induced into taking money from various organisations in order to pay for those ads is just too great. Too great an influence may be brought to bear on any political party in this country if a ceiling is not somehow put on the amount of money that can be spent. It seems to me that Britain, where paid political advertising has been banned since World War II, has coped exceptionally well with freedom of speech and with decent political debate without people having undue influence by spending large amounts of money on political advertising.

I say to the Australian Automobile Association that I do not support its particular views about road funding and I really do not care if it never again places another political advertisement. It will have to fight in the political arena as we do to put our point of view to the Australian public and the public shall decide what is right and what is wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in the grievance debate to address a subject which this Government has failed to come to grips with since coming to government eight years ago. The subject is the kangaroo industry and quotas.

SPEECH.PARA: The humble Australian kangaroo is potentially worth a potential fortune in terms of export income if this Government can see commonsense. The industry is a very emotive issue with very little commonsense prevailing from the arguments of Greenpeace and animal liberationists. The kangaroo population is currently 10 times its natural level-in other words, 10 times the level when Captain Cook arrived in Australia. Since 1984 the total numbers in a land study across 2.5 million square kilometres of New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland have grown from about nine million to 14 million.

Man has pandered to the needs of the kangaroos, creating a perfect environment for their survival and, indeed, prosperity by spreading water across lands where there was never any natural water. It is scientifically recognised that their numbers need to be controlled for the preservation of plant and animal systems. By controlling numbers, we not only protect ecological systems but also provide a basis for earning valuable export dollars and creating a domestic industry to serve local and international markets. The animal welfare lobby, a small group, has clouded the issue, seeing a complicated situation from a single perspective. The value of the kangaroo as a natural resource must be recognised by this Government to avert a potential $150m industry rotting in the paddock.

A major barrier to servicing the potentially huge export market for kangaroo and kangaroo products is the Federal Government's annual procrastination in accepting kangaroo management programs. The 1991 management program is yet to be announced. We find ourselves in the middle of April and the Federal Government is still failing to renew export licences or agree to an established kangaroo quota.

This program, subject to only minor alterations, has been put before the Government for the past eight years. Yet it still takes three to four months before the management program, which has scientific support, gains ministerial approval. As a result of the Government's inaction, the industry loses millions of dollars in export revenue and lost jobs. I can assure the House that there are many people in towns in my electorate desperate for those jobs and desperate to see the kangaroo industry revitalised.

If such poor decision making were to occur in private enterprise, the offending party would be sacked-and I say, sack the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). The Government's inability to hand down the management program for the year it applies to is costing and infuriating the industry. In effect, the Government is stagnating an industry at a time when Australia is in desperate need of every possible export earning dollar. The lack of stability and predictability promoted by the Government in the kangaroo industry provides no incentive for the industry's growth.

No-one would be prepared to invest substantial sums of money under such uncertain conditions. For the industry to become serious, an alternative to annual announcements of the kangaroo management program must be considered urgently. The Government must ensure to the industry stability of product. A management program reassessed every five years would ensure such stability and make commonsense. The five-year period would still allow for finetuning in unpredictable times, including drought.

Land degradation is scientifically recognised as the nation's single worst environmental problem. The area classified by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation as severely degraded is larger than Queensland. Kangaroos, it is scientifically documented, contribute significantly to this land degradation problem. They graze closer to the ground than sheep and, in drought, can destroy vegetation completely. Even light kangaroo grazing pressure can cause vegetation changes in the long term.

It has been estimated that kangaroos caused $148m worth of damage to the agricultural sector alone back in 1983-84 and, of course, today's figures would be much higher than that. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics updated those figures and established that each kangaroo effectively caused $3.72 worth of damage, a cost to the average Australian property of $1,364 a year. Back in 1983-84 kangaroos cost the average farmer in the wheat/sheep zone $1,441, which equates to $11.26 per kangaroo and, of course, this would be much higher today. Kangaroos also caused $2,073 worth of damage to the average pastoral property.

It is recognised by researchers and scientists alike that population estimates done to date grossly underestimate kangaroo numbers. Last year the commercial culling quota was set at approximately 4 million kangaroos. Therefore, a conservative estimate puts the kangaroo population at 14 million head in Australia. The harvesting of one in 10 kangaroos would maintain population levels at current rates. Harvesting one in 15 would have no impact and kangaroo numbers would in fact increase. The quotas are conservatively set and are in no way wiping out kangaroo populations. Scientific evidence shows that the numbers are being maintained at current levels. The quotas are responsible measures arrived at by professionals for the well-being of Australia's environment.

It is important for Australia to recognise the value of the kangaroo as a natural resource. If this recognition does not come about, we will be indulging in huge levels of waste. Kangaroo numbers must be controlled and to promote the end product only makes commercial sense. Eighty per cent of our kangaroo skins are exported. The export of kangaroo hide, skin and leather was worth $13m in 1988-89, even with the Government's stop start policy. This valuable industry has the potential to be even more valuable. As I have said, we have to control kangaroos because of the damage they do. A greater number of tanning facilities in Australia could improve the value of the export by at least threefold.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would provide employment.

—It would provide employment, as the honourable member says.hhThe promotion of tanning and processing plants across Australia has the potential to attract a valuable industry to remote Australia and, in turn, help maintain rural infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that if those who arrived with the First Fleet had been prepared to live off the land rather than bring their livestock with them, kangaroos by now would be the basis of an established meat and hide export industry, perhaps rivalling the beef industry in importance. Kangaroo is a fat-free red meat, not unlike venison to taste. In game meat terms, this industry would be worth $80m. In effect, this $80m is being left in the paddock to rot. More has to be done to promote kangaroo as a gourmet delicacy. It is a natural resource of Australia. Misplaced Greenpeace ethics should be kept out of the debate. If it is unethical to make money out of a native animal, it is surely unethical to elect an animal as the national symbol, shoot it as a pest and feed it to the dogs. That is what is happening. Kangaroo numbers must be controlled, so why do we waste this unique Australian resource?

For an industry to be internationally marketable there must exist some stability and predictability. No-one would be prepared to invest money if there were no guarantee of returns. The kangaroo industry is potentially huge, yet after 200 years it is still in its infancy. It will never progress from its infancy with a government that cannot hand down a management report in time for the year it applies. Whatever the by-product, the kangaroo industry will never amount to anything serious with a government pandering to the irrational, scientifically unsound and emotive pleas of a minority lobby group. The result is a huge waste on a huge scale which should not be tolerated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is, of course, a relatively young country. Indeed, in Western Australia, where I come from, it is only just beyond 160 years since the first colony was developed. During early colonisation a large number of significant buildings were established. It is much to our chagrin that many of these have been destroyed in recent times. The most recent controversy in Western Australia that really hit the headlines concerned Barracks Arch and the fact that at the end of St Georges Terrace, that arch stands alone; none of the surrounding buildings are still with us, which is something we should lament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of concern to me that another of our historic buildings, indeed two or three others within the precinct of my electorate, has come under scrutiny recently. I speak particularly about the old Swan brewery, which has been a symbol and focal point on the Swan River for more than 90 years. The original building was constructed in 1897. It has been, I suppose, a central focus of the Swan River.

Anyone who visited Perth would have recognised the Swan Brewery building situated on the river foreshore. It is a building of former glory but presently the site of great controversy. I first wrote to the newspaper about this issue a couple of years ago and was involved in the imbroglio around it. Since that time there have been established some coalitions of interest in respect of this. There is a group of people whose view is that we should knock this building down. The State Government, much to its credit, has steadfastly held to the view that it should be developed as a community resource and as a building of great significance which will provide an ongoing legacy to future generations.

The arguments to knock it down are quite numerous and in fact hardly coincidental. Many of them push in different directions. Those who wish to knock it down say that this building has failed to be listed by the National Trust. If one speaks to the National Trust about it, it says it has had difficulty establishing the age and indeed the historical significance of particular parts of the building because the Swan Brewery developed over a number of years by a dynamic process. The argument that has precluded the National Trust from listing the building is not one which suggests that this building should be knocked down. What is required is an objective study of the building and a study of its significance.

A small lobby group of Aboriginals has fought very hard to have the building knocked over. Its view is that the Swan River site, where the building is, is part of the mythical resting place of the Wagyl. The Senior report established many years ago noted that in fact there was no particular Aboriginal significance to this site. Whatever balance one wants to put on the evidence about this particular issue, it is clear that there is considerable discord amongst Aboriginal groups as to the significance of the site. Some say that the most significant sites are further down the river, others that the sacred site is in the other direction or towards Kings Park. There are differences of opinion within the Aboriginal groups. It is a source of concern to me that this particular aspect of Aboriginal relations has received such prominence.

I put a question on notice to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner) as to the percentage of Aboriginal Legal Service funds that have been spent on the particular court case regarding the Swan Brewery. As yet I am not satisfied by the answer because it is clear to me that many Aboriginals are unable to be defended in court because of lack of funds from the Service. I would like to know how the priorities are established in respect of funds which are made available from the Aboriginal Legal Service.

There is also a group which believes that there should be no developments around the Swan River, that we should establish a green belt and access should be limited. Western Australia is very fortunate to have some of the best parks and gardens in any city anywhere in the world. There is a lack of facilities for people using the river and enjoying the benefits of that great natural resource. They do not have access to public toilets, places where they can eat and drink or the normal amenities that one would expect. Cyclists, walkers, joggers, tourists and people who use the water all understand the need for some facilities around the river. Indeed, one could hardly say that the Swan River was an area which was overdeveloped in that sense.

There are others who argue that its position and the shape that the road needs to take present traffic hazards. The State Government has dealt with this issue. A road divider has been provided. The angle and shape of the road have been changed. Are they suggesting that the building be knocked down and that this Aboriginal site, which is so important, should be where the new road takes its place? I do not accept that this argument carries weight. Those who put the argument about the sacred site should realise that the road which passes next to the brewery building surely must be travelling across sacred territory also. Is there a suggestion that the road should be removed? All of these arguments are fundamentally flawed.

The worst intellectual argument is the suggestion that because the building looks terrible now, we should knock it down. Not so long ago a similar view was put in respect of a building in Fremantle. Because of the activity and the action of the local council, the Fremantle Arts Centre and Museum building is now one of the most significant buildings in the Fremantle area. That building was in disrepair and in need of refurbishing and refreshment. A breath of life from a local council brought about a change which sees that building as significant and important.

What needs to be understood is that the old Swan Brewery building is a symbolic building and has been for all of this century an important landmark on the Swan River foreshore. It has particular architectural, historical and industrial significance to development in Western Australia. Aesthetically it is a pleasing building and one needs to look at it as it can be, not as it is at the moment. The argument that it looks dilapidated at the moment, therefore it should be knocked down is, in my view, one of great intellectual poverty. We need to understand that in our country, which is relatively young, there are precious few historical buildings and buildings of significance. It is absolutely important that, when the Western Australian Heritage Council meets to discuss this issue objectively, it thinks very hard about it. Any decision to demolish this building will be fought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party Centenary Offer: Hawke Pewter

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to highlight the Government's lack of commitment to purchasing Australian made goods, its lack of commitment to Australian manufacturers and its lack of commitment to Australian business. I have positive proof that the Government pays only lip-service to buying Australian products. To celebrate 100 years of the Australian Labor Party it has a centenary offer-the Hawke pewter. It is either a tankard or a mug; I have had a look at it.
—A mug!

—Mug would be correct. The information states that it is a collector's dream, that only 100 have been made-I suppose that is one for each Party member after the next election-and that they are all individually numbered and gift boxed. They cost $45 each and are made of Selangor pewter, made in Malaysia. What an indictment that is of the Australian Labor Party. It should be ashamed to even take the prefix Australian in its name. This advertisement for the Hawke pewter has been distributed to every member of parliament. It has a decal or a transfer stuck on it with a photograph or an impression of the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I guess that using a decal was quite a clever idea because it can be peeled off and Mr Keating's name can be put on it.
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to an article that appeared in today's Canberra Times which highlights how industry is hindered by the lack of Australia's membership of a United Nations (UN) agency, the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation. I have been seeking the call in adjournment debates all this week in order to make a speech on this, but I have not managed to get the call. This article highlights the concerns that I was going to express. Australia is the only country of the 151 members of the organisation that has withdrawn. We withdrew two years ago and we are now losing, or have the potential to lose, millions of dollars because this is the organisation that organises a lot of the relief works. A lot of the rebuilding work in the Middle East will go through this organisation, and our businesses are going to miss out because we are no longer a member of this organisation. It will cost us $1.4m to rejoin; from that, Australian business will have the opportunity to participate in millions and millions of dollars worth of industry. So I call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to accelerate Australia's rejoining this important United Nations agency. I think it is abnormal that Australia is the only member that has ever withdrawn from this UN agency and we should rejoin it immediately.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has chosen to rubbish publicly a witness, Senator Paul McLean, who appeared before the Committee in relation to its inquiry into the banking system. The success of the parliamentary committee system depends largely on witnesses freely appearing before it without fear of harassment or public denigration. Senator McLean has spent some 2 1/2 years of research on inequities in the Australian banking system and has presented some 3,000 pages of evidence. This material could not have been properly considered by the Chairman prior to his regrettable statement. It was not even available to members of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman's premature and dismissive remarks have now resulted in public doubts as to the integrity of the inquiry. Whether the Chairman's remarks turn out in the end to be correct or not is irrelevant; his action was a petty party political statement designed to gain maximum media exposure. The credibility of the inquiry has now been damaged and proper consideration of the material submitted by Senator McLean has been pre-empted. The recent attempt by the Labor, Liberal and National parties to prevent public examination and debate on the Westpac letters, in spite of the efforts by Senator McLean and others, was disgraceful. These actions, together with this latest attempt to prematurely dismiss evidence, means that there can now be little public confidence in the inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee has made some ridiculous comments in the Senate. He said that he should not be criticised for stating that the Government should bring charges against people associated with moneys allegedly missing from the Ravenshoe sawmill. I suggested in a press release that Senator O'Chee read the humiliating evidence of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct about the separation of powers under the Westminster system. Sir Joh was asked to explain the doctrine and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well the doctrine you refer to in relation to the . . . where the Government stands and where the rest of the community stands and where the rest of the instruments of Government stand. Is that what . . .?
He was told, `No'. Sir Joh then said:
Well, you tell me, and I'll tell you whether you are right or not. Don't you know?.

All Queenslanders remember that. Senator O'Chee says he understands the doctrine, but then says that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) breached it by writing to the Director of Public Prosecutions and that the Government should bring charges against people. The Government should bring charges! Thank heavens we do live in a country where there is a separation of powers and the Government does not bring charges. In Queensland for too long we lived in a State where no such separation of powers existed. I suggest Senator O'Chee read the Fitzgerald report.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March in his industry statement the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) informed the Australian community of what we must do together to meet the economic challenges facing this country. The Prime Minister acknowledged that it is government's responsibility to get the policy framework right. However, thousands of businesses have gone to the wall because the policy framework of this Government has not been right. I will give just one example. The Seymour abattoirs has been closed and empty since last October after years of industrial turmoil. The only possible way that this abattoirs can reopen as a commercially viable enterprise is for private enterprise to use its initiative to reopen it by using contract labour paid on a productivity basis. It is vital that this happen in order to improve our export meat industry and to provide employment. The reopening of the Seymour abattoirs will give this Government a lead into establishing the right policy framework in order to meet those economic challenges the Prime Minister referred to. It is just not possible to build a competitive Australia with outdated work practices and obstructive unionism such as that practised by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to another nuclear disaster waiting to happen at Chernobyl. In the Melbourne Age of today there is a report from the London Times. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Soviet scientists who have visited the damaged reactor at Chernobyl fear another nuclear disaster will be caused by a collapse of its protective shell unless urgent action is taken to prevent it, `The Times' reported today.

If part of the reactor or shell were to collapse, hundreds of tonnes of radioactive dust would be released into the atmosphere, they said. The result would be heavy pollution of the surrounding area, though probably not on an international scale of the original disaster of 1986.

The concrete and steel shell was said to be radiation and disaster proof when constructed nearly five years ago. But now it was estimated to be riddled with up to 1000 square metres of holes, some so big that birds flew in and out, the scientists said.
Without urgent action and technical assistance from the West an accident could occur at any time . . .

It is significant to reflect on a statement I made last week when referring to the Chernobyl children who came here for lunch. I said that those who still talk about the nuclear power industry as being safe and environmentally friendly should get their blinkers off and look at what is really happening with these disasters occurring time after time.

These people are so dependent upon their little gravel roads which run up into distant parts of the valleys and also the main roads that connect them--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Queensland on 23 March the local government elections were held.
—Who won?

—We all won, of course. It saw the retirement from the City of Ipswich of Des Freeman as our long-serving Mayor after 12 years. Previously, he was an alderman of the Council and, of course, was a coalminer for many years. Together, Des and his wife, Colleen, worked extremely hard for the City of Ipswich and continue to do so. I would like to put on record my sincere thanks and best wishes to Des and Colleen Freeman for their great effort.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the election saw the return of another Labor Ipswich City Council, led by Alderman Dave Underwood and his team. Of the 10 divisions in the Council, nine were won by Labor. All three Liberal opponents were wiped out. I extend my congratulations to Paul Pisasale, Denise Hanly and Wayne McDonnell, who actually took those seats from the Liberal Party. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks we have heard a lot about WA Inc. and all its financial impropriety. But such unusual financial goings-on are not restricted to that State. We have heard a lot about the lily-white reputation of the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and its machine in that State. Recently, we saw the defeat of Sallyanne Atkinson in the lord mayoral race in Brisbane by one of the bastions of that lily-white ALP. I speak of `gentleman Jim' Soorley, the retired Jesuit, who has indulged in political grandstanding in recent days about his lord mayoral salary and allowance reductions.
