SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House a very important project currently under way in Queensland, which has implications for all women in Australia. It is, of course, the creation of Women's Place, which is an attempt to establish a national museum to acknowledge the contribution of women to Australian history and to get together all the collections that currently exist. As honourable members will appreciate, there are many small towns throughout Australia whose Country Women's Associations, other church women's groups and a whole range of other women's organisations have a number of collections of material.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also interesting to note at this time that collections are being put together of photographs of women in the union movement, of women in political parties and all other things. It seems an important time, now that women represent 53 per cent of the population, to acknowledge the contributions of women to our fine country and of the work that they have done.

I also draw to the attention of the House that one of the contributions to the collection is a very large portrait of Emma Jordan, who founded the Labor women's movement 100 years ago. Her first speech highlighted the needs of women in the area of child-care, education and equal pay. It seems that those of us who are here today must keep on with her fight and her struggle to ensure that women are treated fairly, equally and with dignity and are, of course, given every opportunity. ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday I was asked this question by the honourable member for Bennelong and I made the situation quite clear. He asked me whether I had received an approach from the then Western Australian Premier, Brian Burke, to urge the National Australia Bank Ltd to rescue Rothwells. That was yesterday's ploy. I responded to that and said that Burke was never in touch with me. I went on to say:

An approach was made to me concerning Rothwells' difficulties with the National Australia Bank. It was made by the late Mr Beckwith of Bond Corporation. The essence of the approach was for me to interest myself in the apparent difficulties of a merchant bank-Rothwells-over difficulties it was having in its ongoing financial relationship with the National Australia Bank. I was asked to approach the National Australia Bank in this regard.
Therefore, I have already told the House the answer to the second question the Leader of the Opposition put to me today. My answer continued:
This I did not do, but my office did inquire of the Reserve Bank whether it was aware that Rothwells may have ongoing difficulties.
As it turned out, the Reserve Bank had already been in contact . . . Accordingly, the matter was taken no further by me or my office.

That is the position. I got a call from Mr Beckwith late on the evening of Thursday, 22 October, I think it was, or early on the 23rd. My office was in touch with the Reserve Bank mid-morning on 23 October. Over that weekend, the 24th and the 25th, the rescue of Rothwells was put together. But I was asked whether I would interest myself in the affairs of a merchant bank. It was put to me that this was the first financial institution in difficulties after the stock market crash and that therefore I should interest myself in its affairs because apparently the National Australia Bank would not clear a cheque of Rothwells. I was asked to speak to the National Australia Bank. This I did not do. I inquired of the Reserve Bank whether it knew of Rothwells' difficulties. It did; it had already had a number of conversations with the National Australia Bank. I then heard from both the bank and the Treasury on the 23rd about the difficulties Rothwells was having with the National Australia Bank.

A package was put together for Rothwells over the weekend of 24 and 25 October 1987. The rescue package involved support from a number of Australian businesses and a $150m guarantee from the Western Australian State Government for bills issued by the National Australia Bank. There were 16 of those institutions: Kerry Packer, Alan Bond, Robert Holmes a Court, Ron Brierley, Larry Adler, Dallas Dempster, Allan Hawkins, John Elliott, John Roberts, John Dunoon, Brent Potts, Sir Tristan Antico, Bill Hughes, Paul Morgan, and Suncorp, the Queensland Government insurance authority. The package was put together by Wardley Australia. That occurred over that weekend.

I can only say what I said when I was asked about this issue by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, on the Monday morning, the same morning the rescue package was announced. I said that neither I, nor the Treasury, the Reserve Bank or my office knew of the rescue package before it was announced. I am saying that now. The honourable member for Kooyong said:

. . . I refer him to reports this morning that part of the rescue package to save Rothwells Ltd comprises a loan from a bank backed by Western Australia's Labor Government. Will the Treasurer clarify . . . to what extent is the Commonwealth Government acting as an implicit guarantor . . .
My answer was:
I am not familiar with all the details of Rothwells' financing or its structure, apart from what I have read in the newspapers.

That I answered on the day that the Rothwells package was actually announced. Let me repeat: neither I, nor the Treasury, the Reserve Bank or my office knew of the rescue package before it was announced. I was not approached by the then Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke, about the rescue package, nor did I approach him, directly or indirectly.
What is very amusing about this is that Mr Howard was very complimentary of the rescue. On 26 October 1987, that same day, he said at the front door of Parliament House:
The only comment I would make is that it is an admirable example of the capitalist system acting responsibly.
The questioner said:
But does the Rothwells matter indicate that some of the more recent merchant banks are fairly fragile-they have arisen so quickly?
Howard:
No, I don't believe it does. I think what it does indicate is an admirable willingness on the part of the leading corporate figure to act responsibly in a difficult situation.

He was very laudatory of the package. But not only was he laudatory of it. I was saying that I saw no need for the Government to be involved. He thought there was a role for someone to be involved, particularly the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the Government though.
—No, no. But then in the Australian of 28 October it says under the heading `Rescue of Rothwells':

ANSWER.PARA: It was disclosed Mr Bond had telephoned Mr Howard to ask him to pressure the Leader of the Western Australian opposition, Mr MacKinnon, into supporting the State Government's $150m guarantee of the rescue.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did, too, and I refused.
—Just hang on. This is the same Mr Bond you went to see with the then Senator Chaney. Remember-Alan Bond, B-o-n-d? To continue:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Bond made the call on Sunday, when Mr MacKinnon's refusal to support the Government move threatened to destroy the rescue package. Mr Bond had told Mr MacKinnon the rescue would fall apart if the Liberal Party did not give it support.
Mr MacKinnon said yesterday that Mr Howard had telephoned him after an approach from Mr Bond, who was an architect of the rescue.
Mr Beckwith from Bond Corporation rang me to telephone the National Australia Bank; I did not. But Mr Bond rang the honourable member for Bennelong to telephone Mr MacKinnon; he did. It continues:
John Howard indicated that he (Mr Bond) was trying to enlist his support to encourage me to make me change my mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?
—So what? That is what the honourable member was asking me yesterday. This is what MacKinnon said--
—You are missing the point.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—You are--
—The honourable member for Mayo.
—This is what MacKinnon said:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Howard did not do that but indicated that he wanted to be briefed on the issue. He said the decision was up to me because he did not know enough about it.
He did not know enough about it but he still rang. It continues:
In the State Parliament late yesterday the Premier, Mr Burke, claimed Mr Howard had supported the State Government's role.
That is what Burke had said. By the way, the West Australian of 27 October stated:
The Federal Government had not been asked to help Rothwells and Mr Burke had not discussed the issue with the Treasurer, Mr Keating.
So there are two corroborations that Burke was not in touch with me. Burke claimed:

Mr Howard had supported the State Government's role. He said that Mr Howard had told people he had made clear his attitude to Mr MacKinnon. He said Mr Howard had told people he had made clear his attitude to Mr MacKinnon. But Mr MacKinnon insisted this was not true. He said Mr Howard had not pressured him, nor had he given an opinion about the package.

The fact is that obviously we do not expect Mr MacKinnon to put in the honourable member for Bennelong; but Burke would know who helped him with the matter, and Burke said that he helped. This is the same person who lauded the package. He went on to say:
Mr Howard said yesterday MacKinnon had adopted the correct stance in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not expect--
—The honourable member for Gippsland.

—This is the same rescue that was an admirable example of the capitalist system acting responsibly. He said that on Monday. The honourable member for Bennelong rang MacKinnon but he never said anything like that over the weekend; oh God, no. He said it on Monday morning but not over the weekend. When Burke put him in and claimed that the honourable member for Bennelong had `supported the State Government's role', the honourable member for Bennelong said, `Oh no, MacKinnon exonerates me'. If the honourable member expects us to believe that Mr MacKinnon's exoneration of him positively supporting the thing is to be taken by the rest of us with any veracity, then he believes in fairy tales.
—Rather than believe you.
—The honourable member for O'Connor!

—Here is the Opposition-the professor, the ideas man in the Parliament-up doing a bit of mud slinging, following the honourable member for Bennelong yesterday, trying to inveigle me into the rescue of Rothwells when in fact it was that lot who were ringing Western Australia and MacKinnon and speaking to Bond and doing all these things. God, they have got some front.

ANSWER.PARA: We have seen this onslaught against the integrity of the Prime Minister, an onslaught that has now been brushed away by the facts. Those opposite are now back to the rescue of Rothwells in 1987, trying to inveigle the Government, when we have stated very clearly where we stand. I gave another answer to then Senator Chaney through Senator Walsh, which I will not bore the House by reading, that only further corroborates my position.

The Opposition is supposed to be about finding a new agenda for Australia. The picture is of a Leader of the Opposition with a thoughtful, moderate and sober demeanour. We thought over here that he was just thinking; we now find out that for the last 12 months he was just vacant. He has been sitting over there vacant. What we thought was a moderate, sober demeanour from a leader thinking about a new agenda-it boils down to this-was really dead ordinary and vacant.

When push comes to shove, he is just like every other common or garden Liberal: he is up into the mud slinging. Instead of a `visiting professor', he is a `visiting mud slinging professor'. That distinguishes him from the honourable member for Berowra, who is an ordinary common or garden Liberal professor. This is a `visiting mud slinging professor'. That is the best he can do. He got into the Prime Minister. We found that Senator Chaney had his hand out for the money. He was over there seeing Bond to get a contribution to the Liberal Party. He then saw Connell, and Connell gave him the money. That went into the Liberal Party's accounts, and never turned up in the declaration, of course.

Where has the mud slinging got them? Nowhere. At least they have peeled away the myth of the honourable member for Wentworth being some new bloke on the block they grabbed from a merchant bank and shoved into public life without all the baggage of political partisanship. He was going to think about a new agenda for Australia. We now realise that he has no thoughts about a new agenda for Australia; he is just hanging around for a bit of dirt, like all the others before him. This very shabby episode reflects absolutely poorly on the lot of you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the House whether he has seen reports in the Sydney Morning Herald and in other newspapers about the value of voluntary fundraising codes. In the light of these, has the Government revised its views on whether to proceed with fundraising disclosures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those reports appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald and elsewhere. I will go through the voluntary fundraising code that is referred to, said by the then Leader of the Opposition to be applicable in the 1987 election. He was very specific. The code states:

ANSWER.PARA: You never have any bank accounts over which you have control.
You do not have any leaders' accounts and you do not control money.
That is rule one. Rule two:
You do not involve yourself in collecting money. You do not ask people to give you cheques or accept cheques even to pass on to other people. Rule three.

Whilst obviously you will occasionally go to functions which involve people who are current or prospective party supporters, you must be careful not to be in any way directly involved in the raising of money.
Finally:

You avoid, except to the extent that it is impossible not to have a general idea who one's supporters are or may be, knowing details of who has supported you, to what extent and with what regularity they help.

That was the Liberal Party's fundraising code. Mr Seccombe records that when he attempted to get this public document he was told it was private. When it was eventually revealed that it was in his hands, the Liberal Party Federal Director rang him back and confirmed it. He then went on to say that it was unusual that Fred had gone out soliciting himself, in regard to the honourable member for Pearce, but that was not technically a breach of the guidelines. I hope Mr Robb never has to be in a position where he defends me in court if those are the grounds on which he will raise whether or not there is a technical breach of the guidelines.

There are a couple of notable things about what Mr Robb has had to say about fundraising. First, there is his attempt to distance himself from the Liberal Party, from the actions of the then Leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate, and maintain that this was unusual, that this was separate from the sort of thing the Liberal Party does, that we do not do that with any regularity and that, by implication, it was something on his own initiative. The second feature is the assumption that everything else that is done in fundraising conforms as far as that code is concerned. Of course, that is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are your guidelines?
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—The honourable member for Pearce, on his own evidence, made that substantial fundraising initiative of his at the behest of the Liberal Party in Western Australia-front and centre, what it wanted him to do. It asked him to do it and it provided the appropriate-from its point of view-cover for that activity.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, there is that famous organisation, the Liberal Party 500 Club, which keeps appearing but somehow or other can be incorporated within a guideline which says:
. . . knowing details of who has supported you, to what extent and with what regularity they help.

This is not just an odd fundraising dinner where one pays $100 a plate and everyone goes along to hear a politician sing, with which we are all familiar. This 500 Club had these characteristics when investigated by Four Corners a couple of years ago. The Four Corners correspondent said:

Here's one way you join the 500 Club. Conveniently, it's based right here at Liberal Party Melbourne headquarters. Party boss and Elders' chief John Elliott conceived the scheme. You sign up 500 corporate sympathisers.
You know who they are?
Charge them all $500 a year for membership.
You know what they contribute?
$500 a year for membership. And then pass the proceeds to the Liberal Party.
You know who it goes to? The Liberal Party.

In July the cost of belonging actually went up to $1,000 a year. This means that Melbourne's 500 Club is producing half a million dollars annually. Just about all of that will go undeclared into Liberal Party coffers.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the trade unions? What do they contribute? Trade unions have no choice.
—The honourable member for Moore will cease interjecting.

—Sydney now also has a 500 Club. We have now established that, front and centre, this is an organisation which of itself does not fit-if anybody appears at it, knows its members, sees its members, understands its operation-with that final guideline on what you know.

ANSWER.PARA: Who appears at that? Recently Andrew Peacock was a star turn at the luncheon. An unidentified woman at the luncheon asked:
Did you want a comment?
I have a lot of comments to make.
Was it a good lunch?
Excellent, and Andrew was very good, yes, but I didn't understand a word he said.
Did you make a donation?
We have always made donations, that is why we come.
She continued:
Very small, but we make them. I mean, the fact is that I want him to be more of a politician-less of a politician, more of a statesman.

The point about that, my friend, as you well and truly understand it, is this: those opposite have been claiming in this place, and they have claimed earlier on, that anything Senator Chaney might have been doing in that regard is somehow an oddity, standing aside from what the Liberal Party normally does.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the big point?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—The fact of the matter is that when those opposite attend the 500 Club dinner where they see all the corporate sponsors of the Liberal Party they know that, at a minimum, they are making a series of donations to what they are doing. This goes to the point that I made yesterday. I am not saying here that what those opposite are doing is wrong; I am saying that there is monumental hypocrisy in the way in which they portray themselves in this place.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor!

—I see that the Cro-Magnon man is heckling me again. Professor Leakey has been looking for him in the Congo for 20 years. Why does the honourable member not give him a call and put him out of his misery? The point about this is the hypocrisy of it as far as the Liberal Party is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: This sorry tale goes on, again coming off this particular article. It states that there is a problem with that particular donation from Mr Connell. We had the following advice from Mr Robb yesterday:
When it was received-
that is, the donation from Laurie Connell-

it was accompanied by the advice that the money was for party administrative purposes, not for election campaigns, just like Connell's previous $50,000 and was therefore not disclosable under regulations relating to funding.

Indeed, that is true. If there is a donation for administrative purposes that is not in any way directed by the person who makes the direction, then that is a donation for administrative purposes, not for election campaigning purposes. On Sattler's program this morning, Mr Jones, the State President of the Liberal Party, had this to say about whether that was, in fact, the course that occurred:
Are we to assume that he said-
that is Connell-
I want $95,000 to go to administration and $5,000 to the campaign.
Jones: no, you are not to assume that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am reluctant to take a point of order on the Leader of the House because he, above all, should be setting an example.
—Order! Does the honourable member for Hume have a point of order?

—I am referring to the relevance of the answer that is being given by the Minister. We are now 23 minutes into Question Time and this Minister has taken eight minutes of that 23 minutes in answering the question. Mr Speaker, I ask you to request the Minister to draw his answer to a close.

—Order! The Minister's answer is in order with the question that was asked. As I have said in the past, had the House been willing to put time limits into the Standing Orders my predecessors and I would have been very happy about that.
—Mr Jones stated:

ANSWER.PARA: No, you are not to assume that. You may very well assume that his whole donation was made available, probably on the basis from which he said it was to be used for-campaign purposes-or for administrative purposes, but we may have used $5,000 of that for administration associated with the campaign which cleared it.

The fact of the matter is that he does not know whether it was used for those purposes or otherwise. If it is the first, there is a problem; if it is the second, then in terms of the legalities of the arrangement, there may well not be. The simple fact of the matter is that there is total confusion between the two and it would be very nice to have that matter cleared up by the Liberal Party operating so well on its voluntary code.

There is no question about it-I conclude on this-as far as disclosure is concerned, the Liberal Party is running around the place like a chook with its head cut off. It knows very well that any particular promise to go down this road will stand on its head the fabric of the way in which the Liberals have conducted business as a political party for years. We have no better authority on that than an article which appeared in the Adelaide newspaper by David Barnett, a journalist close to Liberal Party sources. When asked what was going on and why the Liberals had committed themselves to it, they said that the reason why the Liberal Party came down in support of the Government's disclosure of legislation was this:
Sources said this was because they were stung by Prime Minister Bob Hawke's taunts in Parliament and they knew the legislation would go through anyway with Democrat backing.
Also, Dr Hewson had given an immediate favourable response to the announcement and the coalition felt it had to back him. We decided to make the best of it.

If that is the attitude on which members of the Liberal Party are going to go through into this particular discussion of disclosure, we will get from them the same thing that we got from them when we last made the attempt on disclosure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with it? Where is it relevant?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—When we introduced this disclosure legislation we made a full disclosure of our 1984 campaign donations. There was nothing from the Liberals and they immediately sought a legal way, a loophole, around the problem which then made a nonsense of the disclosure legislation, which we will now fix.

ANSWER.PARA: So that the honourable gentleman knows, we will not be backing away from bringing in this disclosure legislation. We intend to make it loophole free, and we intend to see that in this community it is respected.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is it not a fact that to ensure compliance with Prudential requirements, the National Australia Bank would not have committed $150m to the Rothwells Ltd bail out without discussions and presumably approval, maybe even agreement, of the Reserve Bank of Australia prior to the announcement of the rescue package on Sunday the 25th?

—The notion that I am supposed to pass a judgment four years later as to whether a normal transaction of the banking system should be subject to Prudential requirements and the rest of it is just a nonsense. The fact is that the National Australia Bank was in touch with the Reserve Bank, and vice versa, about these matters. The National Australia Bank apparently did not believe that Rothwell's cheques were any good. Rothwells apparently wanted the National Australia Bank to meet its cheques-that is, to extend it more credit-and, as it turned out, the National Australia Bank was not of a mind to do so. That is probably what precipitated the view that a package had to be put together for Rothwells because apparently in the wash-up other financial institutions had said the same.
—When did it become obvious that a package was necessary?
—God knows. Ask all your pals who I listed earlier.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Last Sunday in the beautiful Hunter Valley, the Minister very capably launched National Coal Week. Can he explain to the House the significance of National Coal Week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The coal industry has decided to put its best face forward-the face of coal, as it is our largest export industry. Eric put his face forward too, and it was a very nice face. The coal industry has worked out that if it does not blow its own trumpet, someone will come and pluck the strings out of its harp. Coal is now our premier export industry. Its earnings for 1991-92 are forecast to be of the order of $6.3 billion, which is about a 5 per cent increase on the previous year. This industry employs around 30,000 people, depending on what the multiplier is, which is vitally important for regions such as the Hunter Valley. Our export performance is now about 100 million tonnes. The estimates are that we should get to 150 million tonnes by the year 2005.

ANSWER.PARA: In keeping with the coal industry's promotion of National Coal Week this week, I think it is appropriate that members from the various coal seats in this Parliament give recognition to this great industry, because it is characterised by very strong and experienced companies. It now has a work force with some outstanding leaders. It has a long tradition of market development, high levels of capital investment and efficient technology and, perhaps surprisingly to those who do not understand the industry, a commitment to environmental excellence. I instance Coal and Allied Industries Ltd's Hunter No. 1 mine in the Hunter Valley, which received the inaugural award for environmental excellence for mine site rehabilitation.

The Coal Week, to which the honourable member referred, was organised by the Australian Coal Association; he was there, as was the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), the New South Wales shadow Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Rogan, and many other local people. The objective of this week is to bring home to the Australian people the importance of the contribution that coal makes to the total quality of life of us all. By educating, informing and challenging the Australian people the organisers are trying to get us to think about coal. I think we should all endorse those objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. As the late Peter Beckwith was not a member of the Rothwells board in October 1987 but was actually from Bond Corporation, and as Bond Corporation led the rescue of Rothwells, how can the Treasurer now claim that Beckwith's call to him was not part of the rescue? Is the Treasurer aware that the National Companies and Securities Commission has reported that the directors of Rothwells decided to pursue a rescue of the bank on Thursday, 22 October 1987-a decision which preceded the call to the Treasurer from Mr Beckwith?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?
—Just answer the question.

—Do not be so absurd, telling me to answer things. The fact that it was not part of the rescue should have been obvious. A call about a matter as limited as to whether one bank would clear the cheque of a merchant bank, and therefore the implied risk that that merchant bank could fail, was an issue, but I never spoke to the National Australia Bank.
—It is your veracity that is at issue.

—Oh look, I thought after the bumbling performance of the member for Bennelong yesterday, he would just shut up and do himself a favour. The member for Bennelong has fallen flat on his face. He is the guy who rang MacKinnon-the guy who took Mr Bond's phone call and rang MacKinnon-he is the guy who said, `This is an admirable rescue'.
—Oh, aren't we good!
—Order! The member for Gippsland!

—An admirable rescue! The remarks of the member for Bennelong are just terrific in hindsight. Rothwells went belly-up in 1988. An admirable rescue-I would have thought that the member for Bennelong would do himself a favour and, God, just shut up.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that I did not speak to the National Australia Bank. I spoke to the Reserve Bank of Australia, which knew about this issue; but that has absolutely nothing to do with the rescue. Now, the portents behind it may have meant, in the eyes of the people involved, that the organisation needed rescuing-that is a different matter-but I was not consulted about that. The Commonwealth had no involvement in it and I read about it, as I told the Leader of the Opposition, on the Monday morning.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and it concerns cooperative joint fishing ventures. Can the Minister inform the House--
—Ask Bob!
—Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Fishing is very important to me, Mr Speaker, particularly tuna fishing.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and concerns cooperative fishing ventures.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—What has happened to the cooperative ventures between the Australian and Japanese fishing industries to move the Australian fishing industry to long-lining for southern bluefin tuna fishing?

QUESTION.PARA: Mr McGauran interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the member for Gippsland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to get a legitimate question on fishing. The honourable gentleman takes a very close interest in it. It is very complex; last year when we were negotiating access to tuna resources with Japan, understandings were reached whereby the Australian and Japanese industries would work together to catch southern bluefin tuna by long-lining. The idea was to generate an Australian industry that could successfully participate in the most valuable part of the raw fish, or sashimi, markets in Japan, and at the same time we were catching larger fish, as long-lining does, which is better for the stock in the long run. This method of fishing requires rather specialist techniques and equipment, and we made significant efforts to encourage cooperation between the two industries. The transfer of expertise and technology from Japan to Australia is vital if we are to proceed down this path.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, the concept hit a whole heap of problems. It was hoped to have as many as 24 Australian-flag boats operating under the scheme in 1991, but we are now looking at perhaps only three. The remaining tuna quota that was set aside for these operations in 1991 will probably again have to be caught by joint ventures. The main problems have been at the Japanese end of the deal, with neither the Japanese industry nor Government being able to fulfil, at least at this stage, the undertakings that were given last year. I have taken this issue up with my counterpart in Japan, the Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, and intend to discuss it further at the Australia-Japan Ministerial Council meeting in May.

In essence, through the Japanese side being unable or unwilling to meet its obligations, the Australian industry has been placed in a most difficult situation-one for which it must take some share of the blame itself. It set aside a large portion of its tuna quota to fish in the cooperative long-lining ventures with Japan, and when things did not progress the Australian industry had no alternative but to seek permission from me to catch the fish using the timeworn joint venture approach-again with Japan.

I am not happy with this lack of progress, it is clearly unreasonable for me in the circumstances to refuse the Australian industry the opportunity to catch its quota this year. I thank the honourable member for the case that he has been putting forward on behalf of the Australian industry. I will approach other Commonwealth and State Ministers who have an interest in this matter in the near future, outlining the precise arrangements. I am only agreeing to this in principle in the short term. It is just an interim arrangement and we hope to get this matter all resolved.

Just one last point: the Government caught two vessels in a similar joint venture doing the wrong thing. As a result, we ended up owning one of the vessels and gaining substantial fines from the other. The level of monitoring and surveillance of this venture is going to be higher again than last year, with all costs being met by the joint venturers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In his earlier answer, he said that he had spoken to the Reserve Bank of Australia, but yesterday he said it was his staff who had spoken to the Reserve Bank. I remind the Treasurer of Hansard, at page 2860, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: I was asked to approach the National Australia Bank in this regard. This I did not do. But my office did inquire of the Reserve Bank whether it was aware that Rothwells may have ongoing difficulties.

Did the Treasurer or did he not speak to the Reserve Bank? If the Treasurer did speak to it, exactly what advice was given to him? In respect of the advice the Treasurer said was given to him on 23 October, was it advice given to him orally? If so, from whom? Or was it advice given to the Treasurer in writing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tut, tut, Sherlock, tut, tut. How desperate is the Opposition? WA Inc. has fallen apart because we have established that the real WA Inc. is over there, with not Red Fred but Dead Fred.
—Order! The Treasurer will refer to members by their titles.

—Well, the member for Pearce. I cannot say `the late member for Pearce', because he is still here. The fact is that the old established goldmining industry has had links with the Liberal Party of Australia, particularly Western Mining Corporation Ltd and other companies, for years. Members opposite have given that up because they have got nowhere, and now they are onto Rothwells in 1987, and to try to smother their embarrassment, they are trying to string out a series of pointless questions about the Rothwells rescue, in which the Government was not involved.

ANSWER.PARA: In the previous answer, if I had said I spoke to the Reserve Bank, my office spoke to the Reserve Bank-I mean the office of Treasurer, the office I hold. I did not personally speak to the Reserve Bank-my office spoke to the Reserve Bank, and the information came back to me. When I say `I', I mean me or my office. But why does this pedestrian not go back to a Liberal sub-branch meeting and try his wares there?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House of the economic rationale for levelling the tax playing field through the removal of tax concessions, and what are the Government's intentions in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rationale is that national resources savings, scarce national savings, go to the most productive places in the economy. The notion of a flat field is a notion of a flat field at home. None of us believes that there is a flat field abroad, but if we are in the position where we are not placing our resources in the best places in our own domestic economy, then of course we are doing ourselves a disservice.

ANSWER.PARA: The tariff preference and tax preference, which have otherwise dragged national savings from one place to another, and put them in places which have not optimised investment in Australia, have been part of our problem over the last 30 or 40 years. That is why we removed, amongst other things, the exemption on goldmining income. It was taking investment into goldmining where it might otherwise have been in national terms more optimal, optimising, in other parts of the economy. That is why the Government removed the gold tax exemption.

But the fact of the matter is that this has been a big issue in Australian public life. If we go back to 1985 when the honourable member for Bennelong was leader of the Liberal Party, we find the Kalgoorlie Miner saying:

Liberal tax threat stuns gold men. The goldmining industry has been stunned by shadow Treasurer John Howard's statement that the next Liberal Government will consider introducing a tax on gold. The President of the Kalgoorlie South division of the Liberal Party, Mr Krepp, dismissed Mr Howard's comments which run against current Party policy. `Mr Howard has a crack at the industry every year', Krepp said. ` It is . . .
That is, Krepp says:
`It is his hardy annual. Every time he meets members of the other mining industries he tells them that a gold tax would be considered'.
This is part of the ambience of the time. Then there is another report in the West Australian in August 1985:

The Western Australian Liberal Party is in a quandary over the Liberal Party's policy on the gold tax. The State Liberal leader, Mr Hassell, has fought strongly against the Hawke Government's proposed gold tax. He is worried by the possibility that his Party would introduce a gold tax. Yesterday he asked the Federal Liberal leader, Mr Peacock, to explain fully remarks made by his Party spokesman on treasury matters, Mr Howard. Mr Howard is reported to have said that he could not guarantee that a future Liberal government would not introduce a gold tax. `I strongly urge that such uncertainty be clarified', said Hassell.
Then in the same paper on 10 August 1985, two days later, it says:
The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, yesterday reaffirmed the Party's commitment not to introduce a gold tax.

So here he is-two days earlier we have Hassell having a go at him, two days later Peacock has moved straight back into line; he has reaffirmed there will be no gold tax. The statement stems from a plea for the clarification by the WA Opposition Leader, Mr Hassell. The WA branch of the Party was left in a quandary over the Federal Party's policy after Mr Howard had said what he had to say. Then, in the Australian:
Peacock reaffirms Party's opposition to a gold tax.
That is on the same day, 10 August. He says:
`It is now clear for all to see that the Federal Liberal Party's policy is in line with my views on the matter', said Hassell.
We then jump two years to the lovely Senator Panizza-who apparently is in the gallery today although I do not know him, so I cannot recognise him. But he had this to say in his maiden speech:
I wish to thank the Liberal Party of Western Australia for the opportunity for me to realise the ambition I have had since I was a 20-year-old to be elected to this chamber.
Well, the honourable senator has come in to hear what we say about them. We have, these days, a lot to say about them-particularly Western Australian senators. He said:
At that election the Western Australian team consisted of Durack, Senator Chaney, Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Knowles, Dr Alan Eggleston and young Cam Tingley and me.
This was obviously called the gold ticket. He continued:
I am an old boy of the college in Perth, the Aquinas, which has turned out many good politicians. There were three old boys in the Liberal Senate team-Chaney, Durack and me.
Also the lovely Laurie Connell went to this school, so I am told. Then he goes on to say this:
There have been noises in this place and others that a gold tax should be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong again.
—Well, we can't be perfect, can we? He said:

ANSWER.PARA: There have been noises in this place and others that a gold tax should be introduced.
But listen to this one:
No one would dare impose such a tax.
So says Senator Panizza. Then there is another article, headed `All that Glitters'.
`Are we killing the goose that has been laying a very valuable egg', Senator John Panizza asked today.

Yes, but laying the egg for whom? Obviously not the nation-only the people from whom those opposite received election funding. In the last adjournment debate for 1990 the honourable senator drew attention to the state of the gold industry in Australia. Then we find that the debate goes on into 1988, and by then what has happened is that Mr Peacock has gone, Mr Howard is leader-the honourable member for Bennelong-and the Federal Opposition, it is reported:
. . . will fight the Government's plan for a gold tax despite leader John Howard's recent support for it on economic grounds.
We start seeing it come through then. Then there is a question put to the then Senator Chaney by Michael Maher-I am not sure of the reference-on The World Today, 9 November 1988:
Was Mr Howard rolled by the joint parties on the issue of gold tax? No, not at all.
Then we find, in the last couple of days, we have the honourable member for Bennelong saying to Mr O'Dougherty:
Well, Western Australians were quite crucial to the decision to change your leadership?
Howard: Yes, I know that.
O'Dougherty: I can only rephrase the question. Is it possible that business figures in Western Australia who were donating to the Liberal Party had a say in your downfall?
Howard: Oh look, I don't-look, I have no idea. Why don't you go and ask the relevant people?
O'Dougherty: All right, perhaps we will do that.
Then on the ABC last night we have Senator Chaney saying:
Oh, that's a bit of Keating nonsense.
Then Middleton says:
But people close to John Howard-
cop this one-

claim quite the opposite. They say they have no doubt that in 1989 opposition within shadow cabinet to a gold tax was used to make life difficult for the then Opposition leader, the theme the Government has taken up with gusto.

While the honourable member for Bennelong is not going to mark himself by saying this, people close to him have; so they have gone and said there is no doubt that part of the reason for his removal was his attitude on the gold tax. In the meantime we have:
`I am the man to lead', says Chaney.

Red Fred-now Dead Fred. And then we keep coming back to this very, very interesting piece by Peter Rees, again on 14 October 1989, where he outlines it all, and we have this extraordinary claim that everyone has a distortion which suits them-Senator Chaney's claim. All of the gold ticket people, including the honourable member for Tangney, the honourable member for O'Connor, and the honourable member for Pearce, and the senators-some in the gallery-were about changing the leadership of the Liberal Party because Mr Howard was too expensive a person to the gold industry to be maintained as leader of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish! That is just rubbish.

—I mean, the message had gone out on you, John-they had put a contract on you, old boy. They had put a contract on you-the goldies had put a contract on you, and, what's more, they made it. It only came unstuck when Cro-Magnon got out there bragging about it on television.
—Order! The Treasurer will refer to honourable members by their title.
—It is a deadly serious matter when the policies of the Commonwealth can be voted against in this House and in the Senate to remove the taxation--

ANSWER.PARA: Government members-What about Sinkers? Come back, Sinkers!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Government will cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I might add that the Treasurer conveniently forgets about the coup against Bill Hayden.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will get to his point of order.
—But I take the point of order under standing order 145, that an answer should be--
—An answer shall be relevant to the question.
—Order! Members of the Government will cease interjecting. The Minister for Land Transport!

—You, Sir, have on a number of occasions interpreted your Standing Orders and in fact told Ministers to conclude the answers to their questions and sat them down. This time the Treasurer has been going for over 10 minutes. We have had a very few questions in 50 minutes of Question Time. I ask you, Mr Speaker, to carry out that direction again.
—Order! The Treasurer is answering the question.

—I will draw to a close, Mr Speaker. On this the honourable member for Bennelong had good instincts. I mean, he is not all bad; he had good instincts on this. He knew that it was a ramp and a rort; that income on all minerals was taxed, and that it was indefensible. Party posturing notwithstanding, he was prepared to get up and support such a thing, to be basically rolled over by the honourable member for Kooyong, with the support of these people from Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It was a serious incident in our national affairs. What we discover now is that it was basically done for money, for the support which the old gold industry and the new gold industry had been giving to the Western Australian Liberal Party to maintain the distortion-that is, the favourite and favoured distortion of the honourable member for Pearce. This is, as I said, in the broadest sense of the word rather than in a specific and a personal cash sense, corruption of our national affairs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I have heard the rantings and ravings of the Treasurer, but I would suggest to you that there are restraints within our Standing Orders. If I can remind you, standing order 76 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

I suggest to you, Mr Speaker, that if the Treasurer wishes to pursue the line he is now pursuing there is a course open to him: he can do it by substantive motion. If not, allegations of corruption and allegations of pecuniary interests and other malpractice, I put to you, Mr Speaker, are quite contrary to the way in which any Minister should behave during Question Time. I suggest that for that reason, if for no other, you sit him down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Speaker, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Opposition for its hypocrisy on the issue of gold tax.
We could not resist a challenge like that on this issue from the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the House might put the motion in formal terms.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Beazley having submitted his motion in writing-

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the Government is concerned, we have sat in this place now for two weeks and listened to the utmost canting hypocrisy on the issue of the gold tax and on the issue of campaign donations that has proceeded around it. It is hypocrisy that has finally been found out, finally established, because one member of the Opposition who managed to sit through that canting hypocrisy while the effort was made to impugn the reputation of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on questions of receipt of donations-which he did not at any point of time receive-was prepared to sit there on the front bench and allow that blackguarding to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition, presumably in the full knowledge that it had that sitting there behind it, was prepared to go along with that, and a leader-presuming too that he had full knowledge of it-was prepared to sit there and tolerate that. We have heard in various debates in this chamber a whole raft of efforts by the Opposition to impugn us on a whole series of issues. An allegation has been made by the Opposition that Labor Party policy is there to be bought. When asked to establish that in successive debates in this House, as far as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is concerned he has provided us with nothing.

It is a serious allegation. It has a specific meaning, that is, there is a sum of money; there is a decision to be made. An amount of money is given to the person who has authority to make that decision or who can influence that decision to be made, and then the decision is made as a result. Pure and simple, that is what buying policy means. As far as the Opposition is concerned, that is the allegation it has made here.

When asked to establish that-`What do you mean by having your policy bought?'-the Leader of the Opposition says, `Oh well, it has something to do with your relationship with the trade union movement. Your whole wages policy is based on the fact that you have a policy bought'. As far as the Opposition is concerned, that is an example of serious political corruption. It has demeaned the meaning of the term `serious political corruption' because, as far as wages policy is concerned, it sits in the very centre of decent public policy in this country. The fact that this is a party that is prepared to deal with the trade union movement on a sensible basis on behalf of wage earners in this country is used to impugn it, and the allegation is made that the Party is somehow bought.

In my area of telecommunications, the accusation is made somehow that the policy of the Labor Party has been bought. We all know that there is a public understanding of what that term means, and I go back to it: that somehow there is an exchange of resources or favours in return for a decision that has come forth. The policy decisions were taken by this Government after debate inside our ranks-where there is invariably going to be division on any policy issue. It does not matter what political party one happens to be in, there will be divisions on those sorts of matters. The claim is then made by the Opposition that somehow or other the decision has been bought because we came up with a solution-not a solution, I might say, that the trade union movement or the particular trade unions are concerned about, as they made amply clear at the time, but a decision based on our understanding of what is needed by the telecommunications industry in this country, both to have strength and to have an effective, competitive environment.

The Opposition has over the past two weeks debauched the notion of propriety in the way in which it has debated it in this House. It has come into this place with a grab bag of accusations without substance and has attempted to cite that grab bag of accusations as a ground on which the Government or members of the Government ought to have their integrity impugned and their rights to be members of this place ruled out. Of course, it is a nonsense.

Then the Opposition came back to the one area where it was going to try to establish that there was somehow a linkage between political donations and a particular set of decisions in relation to the gold tax. We get here to the nub of the censure notion. The Prime Minister has said from the time he stood up here first to answer questions on this matter that there were no private deals done in regard to the gold tax, or any matters, as far as that is concerned, in return for policy. He has persisted in that. That has not been successfully challenged by the Opposition.

It has asked the same question about 30 different ways, day after day in this chamber, until today. The same question has been asked day after day, and it has received exactly the same answer on each occasion: there was no exchange of money for favours, no private meeting. The Opposition has not established that at any point of time. It has not even had comfort from the person who created the environment in which such an accusation could be laid because that particular individual stated quite emphatically that, in the course of the meeting with the Prime Minister, whatever matters may have been discussed at that meeting, one matter was not discussed and that was the subject of his particular donations.

There were other meetings, however, which that person had at that particular time with senior politicians of this country in which the subject was most emphatically discussed, of which we have received evidence over the past two weeks, and of course that was with the then Leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate.

People on both sides of this House know the nature of the gold tax debate that took place at that time. It was one involving a whole plethora of factors and influences in Australian national life. There is the question of what is correct policy in that area and, basically, both political parties have at different points of time identified what was correct policy in the gold tax area.

Both political parties-at least, individuals within them-have at different points of time attempted to establish that; and both political parties confronted the possibilities of severe political losses in pursuing particular courses of action. From our side of the House, of course, that severe political loss would be a product of what the Opposition was arguing at the time in relation to the gold tax, had we persisted with the recommendations which had been placed before us on cleaning up the taxation arrangements of the gold industry-no particular mystery, as far as this country is concerned, as to why we arrived at that those conclusions.

We on this side of the House arrived at those conclusions, firstly, because we were concerned about the possibility of political losses. I do not make any particular cover for that point; that was an obvious political consequence if we went down the road of changing a position we adopted on the gold tax. The second reason was that there were being presented at the time-in relation to some proposals on deep mining and in relation to some representatives in areas where deep mining of gold might take place, and of course in relation to the gold industry generally, which was earning export dollars at the time arguments which suggested that, if we went and took that course of action, those opportunities might be shut off.

The third reason was that, in the realities of politics in this country, when the Liberal Party states in the course of a close fought election campaign that it will not introduce a gold tax, it leaves the Government nowhere to go or lose office. That effectively was the position we adopted.

What Liberal Party spokesmen in this place over the last two weeks have tried to do is to suggest that there is another motive: `All those factors, well understood in our national life, are to one side; those are irrelevant. What we shall do is accuse the Labor Party of having based its entire policy on what is alleged to be a donation from Laurie Connell to the Prime Minister'. When those opposite debate the issue of corruption in this place in that debauched fashion, they deprive this chamber of the capacity to be an effective chamber to deal with those issues of public policy which are central to our national life. We did not start this process in this chamber. Those opposite started this process two weeks ago when it came to the question of gold tax. And, boy, do they wish they had not done that at this stage of the game!
Mr Tuckey interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Cro-Magnon is at it again. Boy, do they wish they had not done that! Professor Leakey will make a fortune out of him when he gets hold of him. When we then had to deal with this point, we came to it from a position of relevance. Those opposite, having stood up in this place and, by making those accusations to us, debauched the decency of this chamber to debate these sorts of issues, then found the issue firmly turned upon themselves. A correct question is now being asked of them: `Why have you come to the various conclusions that you have come to in relation to your position on the gold tax and what influence has that played in the way in which you have determined your stand on national affairs?'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell those opposite this: they have provided evidence of having back-scuttled in the face of a dishonourable campaign in the worst possible way, and they have never given answers on that, which they could do in this place. We will not, of course, be listening to any answers from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) because his capacity to convey what happened at the time John Howard was overthrown as leader was besmirched by the fact that he was prepared to go on Four Corners and say, `My normal course of approach to my colleagues in the parliamentary party is to lie to them'. We had on the record that the honourable member for O'Connor would wander around the place telling lies when it came to dealing with questions of leadership changes. And we have established--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable Leader of the House must not direct comments saying the honourable member for O'Connor was telling lies.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. I did think that it was a censure debate and that normally that was permitted. All right, I will withdraw that statement about him in regard to the question of lies. On television he said that he found it extraordinarily difficulty to tell the truth to his colleagues when he was in the process of lobbying them on the subject of leadership changes. During the course of that election campaign one of the leading goldminers in this country-not new goldminers, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed out, but one of the old goldminers, Western Mining-said, `We, of course, know that in a week or two we will be getting a position from the Liberal Party on the subject of gold tax; we know we are going to be getting a position from them; just wait for it, you will see it coming down the line'-and indeed they did.

SPEECH.PARA: What a humiliation this whole episode provided for honourable members opposite. I might say that one of the most interesting features in the declaration of gifts, as I pointed out the other day, is that there is a total lack of coincidence between gifts declared and moneys expended. There is no question of the provision of things coming forward from trust funds, which are admittedly, as I have said here today, a blind that is available to both sides of politics in this country to conceal substantial donations. There is not even that. We have to assume that the funding basis of the Liberal Party's last two campaigns somehow or other disappeared into the ether and that they were paid for by nothing. It just appeared, then disappeared; no bills were presented; it cost the Party nothing. We are expected to believe in this debate that some of these very large companies which have been supporters of the Liberal Party for years made to it no contribution which in any shape or form could find its way into the Liberal Party coffers.

Remember, we did not start this particular debate on the relationship between the issue of gold tax and these particular matters. This is a debate that has been provoked by opposition members' continuing argument around the point of that alleged statement that the Prime Minister's policy was there to be bought. Where are we headed on this particular issue as far as those opposite are concerned? It is this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are struggling.

—The honourable member for O'Connor gesticulates, dances around the place. He is like a gibbon in the zoo down the street from where I live. The point is this: we have had now two weeks of Opposition questioning, firstly, on the issue of an alleged arriving at of a policy on gold tax at the behest of some boodler involved in the politics of this country. The second issue-and this is a new theme that members opposite have warmed to, having had themselves belted about the ears by the Treasurer on this subject-is that somehow or other the questions which those opposite asked and which were perfectly adequately answered at the time of the Rothwells Ltd bail-out are something that this Parliament ought to interest itself in at this point of time. That is a load of nonsense. It is simply slander from them: an attempt to create an atmosphere of difficulty where none exists; an attempt to create a linkage where none exists. The only linkage which has been in any shape or form firmly established as far as affairs in Western Australia are concerned during the course of the last two weeks has been the linkage between them and gold and the preparedness of those opposite to execute a Leader of the Opposition--
—Prime Minister.

—Would-be Prime Minister at the time. That is no fabrication at all. That comes from evidence that they themselves provide about themselves. We do not manufacture this evidence. We get it presented to us by the things that they say about themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we had this latest effort in infamy, when the Treasurer clearly established on the record that he had nothing to do with the Rothwells bail-out at the time. He clearly established that on the record. There has been a plethora of material written on Rothwells. All the ghosts in Rothwells are out singing and dancing. They have been out there singing and dancing for the last three years, and none of those ghosts, none of those problems, ever bore the Treasurer's or the Federal Government's face. Not once in those three or four years beyond that initial questioning have those opposite sought to raise in this place until this week those issues to which the Treasurer went.

The Opposition expects us to take it seriously as some sort of arbiters of the public good and public morality when it comes down to the question of how we should conduct our affairs in this place. There is only one Federal politician on the record as saying he thought it was quite a good piece of activity on behalf of corporate Australia, showing themselves to be responsible people. Only one person has come out into the public light and said that. That was the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). Many people at the time thought that that was quite a good idea. He was not Robinson Crusoe. He was the one person in authority in the Federal Parliament at that time from whom a comment was sought on what he thought of all of that who gave one. That is what he was. He was not Robinson Crusoe in the general public sense; he was pretty close to it when it came to positions being adopted in this chamber.

The Leader of the Opposition has not established, either in relation to the gold tax area or in relation to the accusations he has made in this other area, any point of impropriety as far as this Government is concerned. What we do know about him on the gold tax is this: whilst his position on the gold tax was, from his own point of view, an aspect of his political opportunism, it was for us a struggle to finalise the establishment of decency in the taxation system in this country, the debauching of which was established quite clearly under the period of time that Fraser was in office and members of the Opposition were his servants. All of them were his servants. That is what we were dealing with when we came to deal with the tax regime in this country. The rorts and ramps that underlay the tax regime were steadily peeled away with the Opposition thrashing us all the way to the election. It thrashed us all the way to the election when we had to deal with each of those particular propositions which imposed enormous burden and pain on us. We had to carry it through. This was the last proposition. Members of the Opposition will go to the next election campaign promising to undo this.

The Leader of the Opposition will support those in the goldmining industry with opportunities that arise from a removal of the capital gains tax. He will impose a 15 per cent tax on the ordinary people of this country to make sure that they pay for it. He is totally deserving of censure by this chamber because he is totally unworthy to be debating these sorts of issues in the national Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this opportunity to reject the censure motion out of hand and to put its case on the record about the events that we have been raising in the course of the last couple of weeks. It is not just in the course of the last couple of weeks that we have been raising these events. We are interested in the proper processes of government in this country. We are interested in ensuring that the Government governs for all the people of Australia, not just its special friends, not its special interests, not just a few of its mates, but all the people of Australia. That is what this debate is about. That is where this debate comes from. It has been a consistent thrust of our position in this Parliament in the last 12 months that this Government governs improperly, that it governs in the interests of just a few people and that it does not govern in the best interests of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular motion today arrives for two reasons. The first reason is the leadership issue on the other side. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has sat there defenceless in his attempts to get any publicity for his run for the leadership. Members of the Government know that the man at the table, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), is finished. He sat there as events passed him by. He is playing no part in this. The Prime Minister's surrogate is very concerned about the publicity that the other guy-the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Deputy Prime Minister-has been getting in the course of the last couple of weeks and the way the press has focused on his performance relative to the Prime Minister's bumbling performance. The Leader of the House has started his run for the leadership.

The second reason why this censure motion has been moved today is the blatant attempt to get out from under WA Inc. The Prime Minister knew WA Inc. was going to go all the way through to the Prime Ministership of this country and he has been trying to duck that issue and remove the stench that is there from his inability to remember and from his inability to do the job that he has been put there to do. After eight years in the job the country is in the worst economic circumstances ever seen since the 1930s. Day after day the Prime Minister stands by while his Treasurer inflicts more and more hardship on average Australians.

In those circumstances, there is a leadership challenge on and there is a dead concern about the impact that WA Inc. will have on the Government as a party in the course of the next 12 to 18 months. This censure motion is a cheap attempt to divert attention from the real issues, which is basically the way the Prime Minister attempts to govern this country. It is about the way he does deals, the way he looks after mates and the way he does not operate in the best interests of the people of Australia.

If we go to the specific allegations raised in relation to WA Inc. in the course of the last couple of weeks, we find a Prime Minister who is suffering from selective amnesia. He has a total inability to remember certain key events and details about the way he changed the Government's gold tax policy in the run-up to the 1987 election. He has very selective amnesia when it comes to key things that we raise, but categorical assurances in other cases in which he knows precisely what happened. He can probably tell us what vegetables were on the plate; he just cannot tell us whether he had a meeting before he went to the lunch on that particular day.

We have seen an attempt on the part of the Prime Minister in the course of the last two weeks to divert attention from the fact that here we have before us, as a result of a set of allegations made in the Western Australian corruption inquiry, a very clear-cut example of precisely the way this Government has operated, precisely the way it looks after its mates and precisely the way it does not govern in the best interests of the people of Australia.

If we go back to the arguments of the Prime Minister in the course of the last two weeks-the last six sitting days-we find that he has been unable to come up with any defence of the allegations that have been made in relation to that lunch and the subsequent change in policy. Indeed, all the evidence on the record disproves the position that he would have us believe applies. Members of the Government are trying to argue that they have never changed policy on the gold tax. They have tried to argue that they are the saints when it comes to reforming taxation in this country. They are trying to create the impression that there was no impact of that lunch on their policy on gold.

When we go back to December 1986 and when we look at the initial Cabinet decision not to introduce a gold tax we cannot find any mention of a three-year commitment. As we go through every stage of the process after that we cannot find any evidence of a three-year commitment. When does the three-year commitment emerge? It emerges after the lunch that took place in Western Australia. It appears in a letter on 7 July which was not made public until 10 July, just one day before the Federal election.

How can we rationalise this series of events? One possible explanation, which I think is the appropriate one, is that although the Government was on the record in December 1986 as not supporting a gold tax, the Treasurer, Senator Walsh and Senator Evans all intended to introduce a gold tax as soon as they got back into power. They tried to keep that option open right through that pre-election period. The Treasurer is nodding as I am saying this. He knows that he was intending to introduce a gold tax. The problem was that somebody got at Hawke. Hawke did a deal, according to these allegations. Hawke's problem was how could he announce that deal without--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will refer to the Prime Minister by his appropriate title.

—I will be happy to. The Prime Minister did a deal. He had to announce that deal without risking the public attacks of his Treasurer and his Minister for Finance and Senator Evans at the time. He hung on as long as he could and then he finally put it in that letter on 7 July and it did not appear until 10 July. That is what happened. There was a change in policy that took place after the lunch and after the special meeting of 15 June. The Prime Minister finally had to make that a public commitment so that the donations would come in. It is probably no accident that the date on the receipt given to Laurie Connell for the $250,000 was 14 July, after the election date itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Prime Minister that he has a case to answer. He has to demonstrate precisely how it is that that gold tax policy was changed, given that on every opportunity that he had on the record prior to 15 June to do so he never once mentioned that it was a three-year commitment. He cannot create the illusion that there was a three-year commitment. It never appeared as a three-year commitment until the letter of 7 July and, as I say, was not made public until 10 July.

Related to this, and an essential element of it, is mateship rather than leadership. What the Prime Minister has demonstrated in recent days in a matter also related to WA Inc. is an incapacity to put leadership above mateship. For example, today in the Senate an urgency motion was moved by the coalition, and successfully passed by the Senate, calling on Senator Gareth Evans to stand down Ambassador Burke. The second challenge I issue to the Prime Minister is this: what is he going to do with that Senate resolution suggesting that the Government now stand down Ambassador Burke before he does any more damage to our international reputation?

But these guys in government do not care. They do not have any concern for the status of our ambassadorial service. They do not have any concern for the other people-the good men and women that are serving this country at that level. They do not have any concern for the status of that position. They do not have any concern about the impact that that will have on our reputation in Ireland and the Holy See where Ambassador Burke presently operates. They do not have any concern about those things because all they worry about is mateship.

This begs another question: why does the Prime Minister worry so much about that? He is obviously very concerned as to what Brian Burke might say when he comes back. He is not game to call him on. He is not game to break mateship and show a bit of leadership. He is not prepared to look after the best interests of Australia, and that is indisputable. He is not prepared to bring Brian Burke back because he knows that, if he puts him under pressure, he may lose control of what he is going to say. That is precisely the set of circumstances before us. The Government is putting mateship above leadership at a time of major economic crisis in this country. That is the real tragedy of what we have observed in this Government in the last couple of weeks-that is, the cheap political stunts it has pulled to try to muddy the waters by making accusations about us, saying that we changed our gold tax policy and so on.

There are some fundamental differences between what happened on our side and what happened on the Government side. First, we have a declared code of conduct in relation to political donations and that has been observed. We are seeing a good example of the Government's code of conduct in WA Inc. right now. Secondly, our fellows were not in government: they have not been in government since then. So they were not delivering any deals. Thirdly, there was no change of policy and there was no discussion of policy by former Senator Chaney when those political donations were sought.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly and most distinctively, honourable members on this side of the House-be they Fred Chaney or John Howard-have a memory, and it is not a selective memory: they have a memory which they have put on the record. This man opposite has not put his memory on the record. His memory is so selective that, when it comes to the absolute crunch points, he says, `Jeez, I dunno. I haven't got any idea'. He has absolutely no idea of the significance of the stupid games which those people play while the rest of this country slides further and further into recession.

I go back to the place where I began in rejecting this censure motion, that is, to point out that there is a proper way to govern this country and those opposite know nothing about it. In almost all cases they have got here by doing deals. The Treasurer's preselection is notorious from the point of view of an example of how to do deals: you get your mates running away on motorcycles in the middle of the night. That is the whole basis on which those opposite operate. They do not think in terms of the best interests of Australia; they think in terms of deals, deals and more deals. When they get into trouble they do another deal.

Irrespective of whether they relate to the labour market, the waterfront, the blocking of a development such as Coronation Hill or Wesley Vale, or changing tax policy in Western Australia in the lead-up to the Federal election-they are all deals. The Government cannot move because it is hogtied by deals. The bottom line of those deals is pain and misery for the average Australian. The pain and misery of the average Australian now is worse than it has been since the 1930s and it is entirely the consequence of the processes that those opposite use, the policies they end up adopting as a result of these deals-rather than having the capacity for leadership and getting out and acting in the best interests of the people of Australia.

Currently we have record bankruptcies, near record unemployment-undoubtedly it will get there in the near term-record numbers of small business failures, and the deepest and most protracted recession since the 1930s. Every time an Australian focus is on the magnitude of the damage the Government has inflicted on people, we will draw their attention to the sorts of deals the Government has done against their best interests. For example, when this country desperately needs genuine and substantial reform and more change than at any time in the last 50 or 60 years, this Government is incapable of delivering it because it is hogtied by the deals it has done.

The Government cannot deliver in terms of labour market reform, waterfront reform, privatisation, a broad-based goods and services tax and development projects such as Wesley Vale and Coronation Hill. The Government cannot deliver because of the type of person the Prime Minister is and the types of deals he has done right through his political career. The country is paying an enormous price in terms of the impact on its international reputation and the hardship that average Australians are being expected to bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will refrain from interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise another point of order. I again draw the attention of the Prime Minister and the House to standing order 76. This motion is specific. I am establishing at the outset the total hypocrisy of those opposite-particularly the Leader of the Opposition-because they have revealed throughout the whole of this business that principle is something that they would not recognise and that they have contravened in these debates and in Question Time the most fundamental of principles which must be followed if any democracy is going to be able to properly operate. SPEECH.PARA: Throughout these debates and these proceedings, as I come to these other issues of substance, I am going to hammer the point that members opposite are revealed, they stand totally exposed, as being absent of principle on this issue. Mr Peacock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Kooyong will cease interjecting.
