Mr Speaker, could you imagine anything more laughable than what was said by the Leader of the Opposition in his debate? He said, `We've got a code of conduct'. Let me remind you, Mr Speaker, of what that code of conduct is that he got up and stood behind, that he has put up as his shield and defence. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: While parliamentarians can and, indeed, should, voice the Party's needs for funds or services (and sign appeal letters), a member of Parliament or candidate should not personally accept money . . .
What does the honourable member's press release on 16 April say? It reads as follows:

In 1987 I was leading the Senate team in WA and agreed to assist the WA Liberal Party in raising funds as the Party had very limited financial resources . . . I approached a number of Perth business people including Laurie Connell, and asked for support for the Party.
Then he goes to speak of payments which came to his office.

I am in the position, in regard to this question of a connection between donations from Connell and myself, of having Connell himself saying that I was not there. Those present went to this issue after I left. I contrast that with a man operating under this code of conduct who dashed upstairs to Laurie and said, `Hey, have you got a spare $50,000 or $100,000? Connell himself says that the Prime Minister was not there, and at the same time we have goody-goody two-shoes, as he has been referred to, sitting here, nodding and saying, `Isn't it terrible what the Prime Minister did?'-when Connell said that I did not do it at all. Mr Snowdon interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Earlier in this debate the Deputy Speaker called on the Leader of the Opposition to refer to members by their electorates. I ask you, Mr Speaker, to apply the same rule to the Prime Minister.

—Order! If the honourable member for Corinella interjects again, I will name him.

—The Leader of the Opposition accuses me of selective amnesia in this matter. He knows very well that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), a previous Leader of the Opposition, has recently said that imposing a test in which one is supposed to remember everything that happens at every meeting one has been to is not, for the honourable member for Bennelong, an acceptable test.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get it clear. Is it the Leader of the Opposition who is imposing the test in this matter or is the test of the honourable member for Bennelong the reasonable one? I remind you, Mr Speaker, of what the honourable member for Bennelong said just two days ago. He said:
Nobody is saying that Bob Hawke should remember every single word.
He went on to say that it was totally improper and impossible to expect that he, I or anyone else should remember every exact word and occurrence that took place some time ago. He went on to say:

It's when there's a link. It is when you change policy or you give a fresh commitment in consequence or in expectation of a particular donation, and certainly when the circumstances suggest a degree of secrecy and covertness about it, that you have a problem . . .

The Howard test is not that one has to be able to remember everything that happened in a meeting three or four years ago. That is not the test; the test is, as the honourable gentleman said, whether there is a change of policy or a fresh commitment. On the very Howard test, as you know, Mr Speaker, Mr Connell's evidence itself clears the Prime Minister. What he had to say was:
What I was wanting was some confirmation of the Prime Minister's view in respect of the introduction of a gold tax.

The fact is that right throughout this matter, as the honourable member for Bennelong knows and as the honourable Leader of the Opposition should know, my statements before this House have been consistent that there was no private commitment, there was no change of policy, there was nothing told to Mr Connell or anyone else at that luncheon which was not already public knowledge. There was nothing done.

In the sense that Mr Connell says that he sought a confirmation, that is all he could have got-a confirmation-because it was a matter of public record revealed by the Australian Financial Review the following day. On the sixteenth the Australian Financial Review referred to what I had said on the fifteenth. It said that the Prime Minister had publicly, explicitly, given this undertaking in regard to what would happen. It is known-just as what was contained in all of the 14 press releases of Chaney, Durack, et al was known. They did not say `three years' in any of those; they did not mention three years. They referred to the time of government. Obviously they were not saying that it had been the case for one month or two months. In all those press releases, where they did not mention three years, that was the clear intention.

There is no political meaning in a situation where people say in an election period-coming up to the next election-that they will not have a gold tax if they do not mean that it is for that period of government. Of course, that is what we did. We did not introduce it in that period of government; what we did do in that next period of government was to do what those opposite-at the cost of how many millions of dollars, I do not know-did not do. Those opposite made the commitment that they would not bring in a gold tax. We were in a position where we had given the commitment. It was not for the next term, but certainly in the next term we made sure that we would do what those opposite would not do.

Let me finally say this about the Leader of the Opposition. He had the gall and the temerity to talk about this Government, in the area of taxes, dealing with its mates. I remind the Leader of the Opposition of another royal commission, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you closed down.
—The report of that Costigan Royal Commission came out and it made the position clear.
—You closed it down.
—Order!
—You did.
—It made that position clear.
—You closed it.
—Order! The member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—The Costigan Royal Commission said that, after six years of coalition government, the fastest growing industry in Australia was the tax avoidance industry. That was what the Opposition's position then was; it is what its position is now.
—Order! The Prime Minister's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Fisher!
—So the Leader of the House decided to intervene in the proceedings. Forget about the economy, forget about the unemployment: the Leader of the House bounced in with this motion. Then we had--

Next we will have the third possible contestant for the leadership of the Labor Party, the Treasurer. Something very unusual happened in this Parliament last night-something very unusual indeed. Spotted in the members and senators dining room from a public place, looking in-perhaps for the first time in a long time, perhaps for the first time ever-was none other than the arrogant Treasurer, visiting the members and senators dining room. But guess what?

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my right will cease interjecting.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my right will cease interjecting!

—It is reflecting the paralysis of leadership because the truth of the matter is that, whilst Cabinet fiddles, whilst the Leader of the House moves this censure motion, the country burns. The Parliament would do well to be reminded of the unemployed, the small business operators, the woolgrowers, the wheat growers and the sugar cane farmers who are suffering under the policies of the Hawke Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise in the House.

—The real mistake of this Government is that it applies its standard of conduct as if that is the norm. I want to remind the House of what two Government members have said in the past. The first is the Federal Treasurer. Mr Courtice interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hinkler will cease interjecting.

—We have this standard of mateship, this standard of dealing, of taking over-`Labor Incorporated', which stands for mates to hire and deals to make. Its acronym is `LI', Labor Incorporated. That stands for `lie'. I want to put the lie to this motion before the House and I want to do it--

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Kelly interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts!

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order--
—The Leader of the National Party will resume his seat.
—The Minister will cease interjecting. The member for O'Connor on a point of order.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order which concerns the fact that you have warned four interjectors on this side of the House, yet none on that side.
—I remind the honourable member for O'Connor that if he takes any more frivolous points of order I will do more than warn him.
—I want to introduce a new dimension into this debate in relation to a report--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Grace interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Fowler.

—This report has not been focused on by the media, the Parliament or the public, but those opposite might like to do so now. I highlight to the House the real situation existing in 1987 and the background to this issue. Firstly, in 1987 there was the Government's public agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Keefe interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Burke.
—The Government's public agenda was simply that there would be--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Keefe interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Burke.

—It was simply that there would be no gold tax. But the industry sources-the rumours were about the corridors of power-indicated that in fact that policy was about to change. We need to understand that background. The public statements, the public agenda, from the Treasurer of the day and the Prime Minister of the day in the broadest terms was that there would be no gold tax, but indeed the change was on.

SPEECH.PARA: We then had the secret agenda, which was very clear-cut. It was exposed last week by Senator Walsh. The secret agenda was that there would be no gold tax before polling day, that a gold tax would be introduced in the first Budget after the 1987 election if Labor were successful, and that would apply shortly thereafter. We then had a third dimension, one which has not been fully recognised and one which I bring to the House. It is the report of the inquiry into the taxation of goldmining, dated August 1986. It is sometimes referred to as the Gutman report. What does the Gutman report say about goldmining? It states:
1. Sections 23 (o) and 23c should be removed making income from gold mining subject to taxation . . .
2. There should be no phase-in period for introducing taxation.

I repeat: no phase-in period. The Government's own report ruled out the very course of action which this Government then embarked upon with a three-year phase-in period. That is why we legitimately ask: what is the rationale for the Government's conduct and its actions and the commitments given by the Prime Minister in his letter dated 7 July 1987? Suddenly, this Government's public agenda and its secret agenda were thrown out the window. Suddenly, out of the blue, we had a more finite, a more specific, commitment-an absolute commitment-that no gold tax would be introduced within a three-year period. That came in the letter from the Prime Minister dated 7 July.

The House has a right to know why the change. The nation has a right to know why the change-and why and how the Government justified the change against the background of the Government's own report in August 1986, which argues in very clear-cut terms that there should be no phase-in period for introducing the gold tax.

We have a clear-cut situation. The motion before the House is cant and hypocrisy coming from the Government, coming from the leadership contenders of the Labor Party. In fact there was a very sharp change in the announcements of the Government about the gold tax. Senator Walsh has given the lie to the defence mounted in this House. He said that the Treasurer and he were angry that the Prime Minister had suddenly given this upgraded commitment on gold tax. Senator Walsh said that they had not expected it, that they did not want it, and that suddenly the Prime Minister, out of the blue, had completely changed tack on the gold tax. The proof of that is in this report, which the Government had had since August the previous year and which was absolutely clear cut. The House and the nation have a right to know. There is another aspect to this matter, and that is mateship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are your mates?
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory.
—Mateship is so important to Government members.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gibson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton.

—Earlier today the Senate of this Parliament resolved that Ambassador Burke should be stood down. It was a clear cut resolution of the Senate of this Parliament. What has been the Government's reaction? It has just washed its hands. The Government says that it is in order for Australia's official representative to Ireland and the Holy See, Ambassador Burke, to be allowed to continue, even when the Senate has passed a resolution that he should be stood down. Minister Evans has indicated very clearly that it is improper for an ambassador to continue to intervene in domestic politics once he has been appointed as an ambassador. I ask the Prime Minister: what happens?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Melham interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Banks.

—The Prime Minister does not have the courage to make the one decision about Ambassador Burke that the country demands. He does not have the leadership courage to make a stand, and he will not make a stand because he does not want to upset Ambassador Burke as he prepares to give evidence before the WA Inc. royal commission. That standard is not good enough either for the Parliament or for the nation and it is one for which he will be condemned. These critical issues in the gold tax saga have to be answered fully and comprehensively by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had two attempts at answers by the Prime Minister. Twice in the last week the Prime Minister has had to come back into this House and withdraw and apologise. Last Tuesday, yet again, having attacked me, he was forced to stand up here and apologise. I say to the Prime Minister: the country deserves better leadership from him in this matter.

The country deserves a comprehensive statement from the Prime Minister about all that happened and all that the Prime Minister knows on the matter of Western Australia Inc. The country deserves a full statement from the Treasurer about the Rothwells rescue and all aspects of his involvement and the phone calls he initiated with regard to the Rothwells rescue.

The coalition totally rejects this censure motion. The coalition has fully answered all that the Prime Minister has belted up, and it is about time this Parliament discussed some of the critical issues facing the economy and the nation as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After two weeks of essentially studied abuse by the Opposition of the Government, in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), what we have just heard from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) are the most pathetic contributions I have heard in such a weighty debate in my 22 years here. TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no, Jack Lang would be very happy with my performances. Unless the Leader of the Opposition is in with a question in his hand written by someone on his staff, he is absolutely useless. He thought bluster, volume and decibels could substitute for quality-quantity for quality; and amplitude and noise for real argument.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition is the accuser in this matter. After two weeks, what did he come up with? I will tell honourable members what he came up with.
Mr Ruddock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Dundas!

—He said that the Government should govern for everyone, not just its special friends-that was his first point. His second point was on the Prime Minister's inability to remember. He referred to his selective amnesia. His third point was doing deals. His pathetic closing remarks were about the Liberal Party having a declared code of conduct. The honourable member for Pearce has made a virtue of the fact that he believes in special friends and distortions which he says he supports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Warren Anderson.
—We know all about your friends on the race track, pal.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Peacock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Kooyong!

—The honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) has said all these things about distortions and yet the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has got the gall to talk about special friends when those opposite have, in fact, changed their policy and removed their leader to change their policy. He talks about special friends and governing for everybody. He was fuming at the end of his speech about how we should be discussing the great national issues. He referred to the recession in the late 1930s. What is the matter of public importance about?

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Prime Minister to give a full and coherent explanation of WA Inc . . .

That is the Leader of the Opposition's great national issue. Then he referred to the Prime Minister's selective amnesia. What did the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) say when he was asked about the meeting with Mr Bond? He said, `I cannot give you a verbatim account of every minute detail of a conversation. Could you remember a conversation you had four years ago?'. That is not an issue. I can remember the discussions.

As I said in the House earlier this week, the honourable member for Bennelong blew the Leader of the Opposition's case apart when he said, `You cannot impugn the Prime Minister over selective amnesia when I am saying that I cannot be expected to remember what I said at a meeting four years ago'. That is absolutely what he implied. That is his quotation. The Leader of the Opposition then talked about no change of policy, when we find all these press releases from senators about all that glitters.

We have the very interesting issue of Senator Durack. He actually told the Senate about the written letter undertaking from the honourable member for Bennelong two weeks before the undertaking was actually published. He is recorded in the Senate as saying so. I have the references here of the Senate debate where Senator Durack said this. Yet the Leader of the Opposition has the absolute temerity to try to suggest that there was no change of policy on the Opposition's part.

The Leader of the Opposition then parades himself as a person of integrity. He was impugning the reputation of the Prime Minister while he knew of the position of the honourable member for Pearce. He was happy to stand up here and impugn the reputation of the Prime Minister knowing that one of his own front bench had asked and received $50,000 from the same person. How could he describe himself as a person of integrity when he is up impugning the motives of the Prime Minister, the chief Minister of the Government, saying that he has shifted his policy when one of his own front bench had been to the same person in question, the said Mr Connell, and had asked and received $50,000? That is what this `person of integrity' is supposed to have us believe as he puts these questions. While he was putting these questions to the Prime Minister, he knew of the press report reporting Alan Bond. It stated:
Fundraising did not arise during discussions because when I referred to Mr Howard's meeting with Bond he said, ` We know all about that, we have seen the report'.

Yes, he had seen the report; he had also seen the paragraph above where the spokesman for Mr Bond said that the question of fundraising did not arise during discussions. The Leader of the Opposition knew that, but it was not going to put him off his dirty game, was it? He is an ideas person, someone new in public life, not besmirched by the rest. What a joke! Let me not hear from the press gallery ever again that he is a non-political person. Frankly, we will faint if we hear again that he is an ideas person. He is not really out of the mould of most politicians, he is just a common old garden Liberal, just a common old garden conservative right wing hack who will try to besmirch an honest person's reputation for just cheap political advantage. That is his position.

The Leader of the Opposition has asked these questions, knowing nothing. He knew that the honourable member for Pearce had got $50,000 and he knew of the Bond report, but he asked these questions for two weeks. You fraud. You disgraceful, disgusting fraud.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the Deputy Prime Minister to withdraw those remarks.
—Of course I will not withdraw them. What about the impropriety? No impropriety was committed or could be established by the Leader of the Opposition. `Disgusting' is not unparliamentary, you clown.
—Sit down. This Parliament is not for you, it is for all of us.
—Sit down yourself.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Hume on the point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, with the uproar in the House, I did not hear your ruling. I assume that you asked the Deputy Prime Minister to withdraw.
—This is a very robust debate. The only requirement is that members do not use unparliamentary language or impute improper motives to others without a specific motion. I call the Treasurer.
—That is why there is a censure motion. In two weeks no impropriety was committed or could be established by the Leader of the Opposition. He then referred to special funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wilson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Sturt!
—This week the following question was put to the honourable member for Pearce:

SPEECH.PARA: In all this debate about who said what about the gold tax, isn't the real story that politicians of all persuasions--
listen to this:
are often under pressure from lobby groups and parties and ultimately make political decisions, policy decisions, as a result of that sort of pressure?
Mr Ruddock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Dundas!
—The honourable member for Pearce said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, but the test is the outcome.

The honourable member for Pearce failed the test because he turned his Party Leader's view over. He voted against the Bills to tax the income from goldmining companies and we did not. This week, in humbug which only he can traffic in, in a media release headed, `Chaney called for end of fragmented decision making', he said:
Government had a key role to play in this process by giving some sense of national purpose while ensuring that it was not the creature or captive of any industry or lobby group.

Only somebody with no pride whatsoever, only someone with the front of a Liberal front bencher could get up and give a long speech on the environment and say-after he had his record paraded in front of him about distortions he favours about securing funds while impugning another man's reputation-that there should be a sense of national purpose. This is the sort of humbug which just makes us sick and it particularly made us sick about the honourable member for Pearce. He has been playing this goody-goody role for years, running around the thing, sort of Red Fred-he is not really right wing-a bit tense, with a sort of social conscience. When he had the social security job he did this and did that. They said, `Oh, he is not a bad guy'. He went round the gallery. He is one of the Menzian-type Liberals.

In fact what we find is that the member for Pearce is really red hot; he is up to his ears in any matter that can advance the partisan interests of his Party. The member for Pearce has very hard right wing views, and he pushes them for all they are worth. But worse than that, he protects constituencies, as he put it. Then the member for Pearce goes on with this disgusting humbug. This is what we have had from these people. This is a disgusting Opposition; this is not an Opposition with a skerrick of integrity. It is up there attacking the Government for everything, even suggesting that the Prime Minister changed the policy. There was a crude interjection from one of the Victorian members about the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and he made the charge that the Prime Minister had closed it down-and had established the National Crime Authority in its place, which the honourable member did not mention.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did! He closed it down before it hit the `Goanna'; you know that. Why don't you tell the truth?
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins!

—The Costigan Royal Commission opened it up and lifted the rug on all the rotten corrupt tax practices in this country, which Senator Durack, as Attorney-General, had let happen despite the fact that he had been warned-the famous two-year gap in the documents which Senator Durack had been given. This is the same Senator Durack who waddled up and down St Georges Terrace looking for contributions from goldmining companies, from Western Mining Corporation and all the Opposition members' pals down on the strip from Kalgoorlie to Coolgardie. That is what the Opposition is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government came along and said, `Oh, we better make the taxation system decent; we will tax all income, including capital gains; we will bring in a fringe benefits tax (FBT) for people who have cars, credit cards and all the rest; we will stop this ramp of entertainment being a deduction; we will actually tax lump sums so that we can set up a decent retirement income system for the whole of the community; we will actually put an assets tax on social security payments, so people of real wealth do not get it; and we will tax gold'. No, no, the Opposition would not have a bar of that. It has punished us for every measure; politically, the Opposition has taken us to elections and has punished us for every measure.

The honourable member for Bennelong in the 1987 election campaign got up and campaigned against all these things-`We'll remove Labor's capital gains tax; Labor's FBT; we will turn over the entertainment deduction; we will remove the tax on lump sums; we will turn over Labor's assets test.' We remember: the Opposition has never done anything decent to make the tax system better, and when the Government has done it, particularly with gold, and especially in this case with gold, the Opposition has frustrated us in this House by opposing it and then opposing it in the Senate when its then leader knew that there could be no rational case for exempting one metal against other metals. He knew it, said it, and was rolled by a front bench that had sold itself to the Western Australian gold industry.

So we know what policy buying means. As my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) said, we know what policy buying means. The Opposition has shown us in the most vivid and graphic way that could be imagined, and yet Opposition members have the hide to ask me questions today about Rothwells four years ago, when they know clearly that the Government had no involvement in that rescue package. Opposition members failed when they attacked the Prime Minister, so they are trying to get up another issue.

I ask particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), who is about to get up to speak: where is the honourable member for Pearce? Why is he not speaking in the debate? Why is he not up here? In fact, we on this side will extend the debate to allow the honourable member for Pearce to make a contribution, and we will see his veracity; but to have now another cheap, tawdry political speech from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who traffics in all sorts of distortions to make a cheap political point, will not cut the ice. The fact is that Opposition members have impugned the reputation of the Prime Minister, they have failed and they deserve the censure of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Where's Fred?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Government will remain silent.

—I rise to speak on this motion, which is that this House censures the Opposition for its hypocrisy on the issue of a gold tax. Let me graphically demonstrate what I think of this censure motion by tearing it up. It is literally not worth the paper it is written on. I must say that I think this is a sad day for this Parliament. I ask myself: what are the people in the gallery and those who are listening to parliamentary proceedings today to make of the performance of this Parliament? We talk about standards; we talk about people's respect for the Parliament. No wonder the respect for this Parliament has been subject to diminution in recent years, when we have the sort of sham and shameful performance that we have had from this Government today.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the people listening to this debate now would they have any sense, any appreciation, of the fact that it was only a few days ago that we heard that the unemployment level had risen to 9.2 per cent? Would they have any sense that there are over 800,000 on the unemployment queues as a result of the recession that this Government has admitted it deliberately induced? Would those people have any sense that not only are there over 800,000 people unemployed, but also there are over 400,000 people who would work more if they had the opportunity to do so? That is, 1.2 million Australians are unable to fully satisfy their desires to work and to achieve a standard of living for their families.

They would have no sense from listening to this debate that this country has had in the past few years a massive increase in our national debt. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) came to office, this country had a debt of only about $20 billion. The Government is forever saying that today's problems are the fault of the last Liberal Government, but it has never explained how it is that under this Government our country's debt has risen from $20-odd billion to a massive $131 billion today, and rising. I say to my colleagues in the Parliament: we are simply kidding ourselves if we believe that this country can continue to live off debt. We are addicted to debt, and the more time we spend playing games, as this Government is doing today, the longer will be delayed the essential reforms that really would make a difference to the people in the gallery and to the people listening to this debate today.

Just to round off these introductory remarks, I have an interesting statistic that came out earlier this week from some research. It reveals that under this Government, the rich have been getting richer and the poor have been getting poorer; a massive gap has been widening between those who are fortunate to be well off and those who are unfortunate to suffer a continuing decline in their living standards. There was not a mention today from this Government of that simple but very embarrassing statistic; it is not just a statistic, it indicates the true consequences of the Australian Labor Party's economic policies and the failure of leadership of this Government.

Much has been said today about the gold tax and the policies of both parties at the last election. If one goes back to the 1987 election, one finds that as people went to the polls on Saturday, 11 July 1987, both the major political parties were opposed to the introduction of a gold tax. In fact, there is an advertisement from the goldminers stating that loudly and clearly for all to see.

The allegation that has been made in the corruption royal commission in Western Australia is that this Government changed its mind about the gold policy that it took to the 1987 election. It is true that both parties opposed the gold tax, but it is on the public record and well known that while Labor publicly opposed the gold tax, it secretly intended to introduce it after the 1987 election. The allegation is that Labor abandoned that secret intention as a result of influence exerted upon the Prime Minister at a lunch. That is the central allegation. There is no allegation about the Liberal Party of Australia and the gold tax policy that it took to the 1987 election. Why was there no allegation? Why could there be no allegation? Because there was no change in the policy. It is as simple as that.

The allegation made is an allegation about the Prime Minister's conduct; and a very serious allegation it is. Let me simply quote to the House the evidence that has been put before the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters. It reads:

Is there any doubt whatsoever in your mind that you obtained a personal commitment out of the mouth of the prime minister that no gold tax would be introduced if Labor was returned at the next election?
What did Mr Connell say? He said:
There's absolutely no doubt in my mind at all.

No doubt whatsoever in his mind. We all now know that secretly $950,000 was collected after that lunch and it just happened to find itself across in the coffers of the Federal Labor Party to assist it with the 1987 election campaign. That is the guts of the allegation that has been made; that is the basis upon which allegations have been put to the Prime Minister, and to which a response has been sought from him.

Given that that is the allegation, an unanswered allegation from the Prime Minister; given that the Prime Minister is under pressure to respond to that, what do we find from this Government? What do we find? We find it attacking the Opposition. It really is the classic. The economy is in recession-it blames the Opposition. The Prime Minister faces an allegation of impropriety, so it blames the Opposition. Now it is absolute nonsense!

The Government, of course, has contrived an elaborate defence mechanism against what it knew was going to be exposed in the royal commission into corruption in Western Australia, and of course part of that was disclosure provisions. The Government says, `Oh, these disclosure provisions aren't good enough'. One would never know that it was the Labor Party which introduced the disclosure provisions, with all their loopholes, back in 1984. Is it coincidence that six years later there is suddenly this great enthusiasm for reforming the disclosure laws? Of course not.

The Government brings forward the disclosure law issues, which we support as a matter of principle-we will debate the merits of the legislation when we see the detail-but no one should be fooled about the cynicism behind Labor's motive in attracting that. The Government has run out of money, of course, and is concerned about its prospects at the next election.

A second characteristic of the attack on the Opposition is the leadership tussle between the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Not only was this an elaborate tactic to try to throw mud on the Opposition and say to the public, `You know, politicians are all just as bad as the other'-a favourite tactic-but it was launched by the Treasurer as part of his own game plan to knock off the Prime Minister. It is to make the Treasurer look good.

Now we find a third motive, and that is to divert attention from the Treasurer's own involvement in WA Inc. Today we had a very inadequate, dissembling, confused and contradictory response from the Treasurer during Question Time about his own involvement with Rothwells. Remember, the Rothwells Bank lies at the epicentre of WA Incorporated, at the epicentre of this sordid and corrupt saga now known as WA Inc., and the subject of a royal commission.

The essence of the questions put to the Treasurer, and the charge against the Treasurer, are that he misled the Parliament as a result of his involvement in the Rothwells rescue. Critical in that claim, that charge against the Treasurer, is his claim back in the Parliament on 26 October 1987 that he knew nothing of the details of the Rothwells financing or its structure apart from what he had read in the newspapers.

His statement yesterday-confirmed today-was that he had had a telephone conversation with Mr Peter Beckwith of the Bond Corporation on that crucial date, 23 October. The reason I say it is the crucial date is that on the public record, in the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission, there is evidence-accepted and endorsed by the interim Commission report-which states that on 22 October the directors of Rothwells contemplated putting Rothwells into receivership, but then abandoned that plan and decided to proceed with the rescue of Rothwells: 22 October-a date to be fixed in our minds.

It was late on 22 October or on 23 October that the Treasurer received a telephone call from Mr Beckwith. Mr Beckwith was not a member of Rothwells who was concerned about the day-to-day management of Rothwells; he was the managing director of Bond Corporation. As is well known, it was Bond Corporation that led the rescue, that gathered together those in corporate Australia who were prepared to support the rescue of the Rothwells Bank. So it is that when Mr Beckwith contacted the Treasurer he was not just ringing up as some sort of gossip merchant to give the Treasurer the latest from the markets in Perth; he rang as a principal agent of those who were gathering that very day, as confirmed in official evidence to the National Companies and Securities Commission. He rang the Treasurer as the principal of the rescue team for Rothwells.

The National Australia Bank, which was the subject of the conversation between Mr Beckwith and the Treasurer, was the backer to Rothwells which was putting together the $150m bail out package, part of a total package of $370m. I believe that the National Australia Bank, whilst being prepared to be in it in terms of providing the $150m, was prepared to be in it only on the basis of a guarantee from the Western Australian Government and, most importantly, only on the basis that it satisfied the Reserve Bank of Australia about prudential requirements vis-a-vis its additional exposure of $150m to Rothwells.

I ask myself: why is it that Mr Beckwith rang the Treasurer? I say he rang because he wanted to ensure that the Reserve Bank would give the necessary approvals for the $150m from the National Australia Bank to bail out Rothwells. On the facts that is the only reasonable interpretation that one can come to as to the possibilities and the motives of Mr Beckwith contacting the Treasurer. That is not a piece of information that the Treasurer wants on the public record. Why does he not? Because in the week after, when he was asked what was his involvement in the Rothwells rescue, he claimed no involvement in the Rothwells rescue. He said, `Look, all I know is what I read in the papers', and he attempted to distance himself, to wash his hands of that saga-the putrid centre of WA Inc. in the Rothwells Bank.

Today when the Treasurer was asked as to what advice he received, he was confused. Today he said that he personally had received advice from the Reserve Bank, and yet on the public record yesterday, in Hansard, it is in fact shown that it was his office that was to contact Rothwells on that fateful 23 October, just following the share market crash. They are contradictory answers which require an explanation. So it was that I asked him: `You stated today, Treasurer, that you received advice on 23 October from the Reserve Bank. Was it in writing or was it verbal'-to which we had no reply but a reply in the form of a censure motion from the Leader of the House as a diversionary tactic.

I say to the Government it is a sad day, because this country, in a state of economic crisis, needs some leadership. We do not need the political games that it plays. I can guarantee that no one out there in the real world will give the Government a moment's time as a result of the silly games that it played today. This is nothing but a farce. The Government ought to be ashamed for treating the Parliament with the disrespect it does-with this nonsense motion. The Government will carry this motion on the numbers, I say to the Prime Minister and the Leader of the House, but it will not carry the spirit of this motion in the community. It deserves to be rejected.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Prime Minister to give a full and coherent account of his Government's involvement in WA Inc. which he has failed to give over the past six sitting days.

More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made some remarks about the fact, publicly known as far back as October 1987, that Mr Alan Bond contacted me in relation to the Rothwells bail-out. The circumstances are that Mr Bond rang me on the Sunday evening of the weekend of the bail-out. He informed me in general terms that the bail-out was under way. It was the first I knew of the bail-out, although I had read in the newspapers previously of some of the difficulties of the Rothwells bank. He told me that the bail-out was being held up because the Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke, was refusing to sign the government guarantee unless Barry MacKinnon, the Leader of the Liberal Opposition, gave him a political indemnity against any criticism of the deal.

SPEECH.PARA: That was essentially what Burke was saying to Bond, to MacKinnon and to all the others-`Look, I will sign the guarantee, providing MacKinnon guarantees not to criticise it'. It was the first that I knew of it, so I rang MacKinnon and he explained the circumstances to me. He explained the reason why the Liberal Party in Western Australia was unwilling to accede to Burke's request. I indicated to him that I thought his position was reasonable and understandable. I subsequently spoke to Bond again. I told him of MacKinnon's position. I told him that I did not believe MacKinnon would change his view and that I would not be seeking to put any pressure on him to do so, because I believed the view that MacKinnon took to be correct. I maintain that to this day. I would like, just for the edification of the Treasurer--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member can say where he was misrepresented.
—That bloke has been misrepresenting us for hour after hour on this issue.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong knows the rules about personal explanations.
—I do, and I tell you where. I will tell you where else --
—If there is some other point where the honourable member has been misrepresented, he can deal with that, but he cannot debate the matter.

—Yes. He said that I endeavoured to put pressure on MacKinnon; I have already refuted that and I remind the Treasurer that as far back as July 1988, when addressing the Western Australian Division of the Liberal Party, I had something to say which is very relevant to the point the Treasurer made. I quote from the transcript of my address:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to applaud the courage that Barry MacKinnon displayed some months ago when he was put under enormous and unconscionable pressure to ratify a deal that was not in the interests of the people of Western Australia.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

Yesterday the honourable member for Bass as Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and on behalf of the Committee, raised a matter of privilege. The essence of the complaint was an allegation that a person, Mr W. Willis, who had had a submission made on his behalf to the Committee's inquiry into corporate practices, had been subject to intimidatory threats in relation to the submission to the Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is alleged that Mr Willis, a shareholder in a company, has been asked to withdraw his submission and that a statement has been made to the effect that, unless Mr Willis withdraws the submission, proposed changes in a company structure may not be supported by the Chairman of the company.

I have examined the papers presented by the honourable member and, whilst I can make no judgment on the substance of the matter, I am satisfied that a prima facie case exists such as would warrant proceedings being granted to a motion in respect of this matter. TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government proposes to request that this Committee make an amendment to the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill, which is before the Committee, in order to accommodate in principle certain views expressed by the Opposition but to set out in the legislation an achievable result. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendment be not made, but that, in place thereof, the Bill be amended as follows:
Clause 7, page 3, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:

``(2) Before regulations are made for the purposes of section 6, the Commissioner must consult the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia and such other persons as the Commissioner considers appropriate.
``(3) A failure to comply with subsection (2) does not affect the validity of the regulations.''.

The Government appreciates the underlying intention of the Opposition in requesting an amendment to insert into the provisions of the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 certain requirements concerning consultation with the superannuation industry about the superannuation levy.

The Government has had very much in mind the importance of consultation with the superannuation industry and other relevant bodies. Accordingly, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission has been directed to maintain full liaison on these matters. The Commission has already undertaken consultation with the superannuation industry on the levy for the first year of its operation.

I remind the House that in introducing the legislation the Government did not consider that it should be necessary to insert such requirements regarding consultation in the provisions of the Bill, but rather that it is appropriate to achieve the consultation requirements by other means. In particular, the Government considers it would not be appropriate to have restrictive provisions in the Bill such as those which have been proposed by the Opposition because, for reasons which I will discuss shortly, it might not always be possible to achieve such requirements.

Before moving on to the arrangements which are already in place regarding consultation with the superannuation industry, I want to place on the record my objection to the timing of the Opposition in moving the amendment to the Bill and the confusing way in which it did it. The Bill was introduced in this place several weeks before debate commenced on it. We have had a lot of criticism on this side of the chamber for the fact that we do not give enough notice to enable the Opposition to respond. In this case, there was ample time for the Opposition to make its views known.

In his speech on 9 April, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) indicated that at the committee stage of the Bill the Opposition would seek to make some changes to the regulations to make sure that the Treasurer was directed to consult the `insurance organisations'-and I emphasise those words, `insurance organisations', because that is how it appears in the Hansard-about the superannuation levy. Why anybody would seek to consult insurance organisations about the superannuation levy is beyond me, and clearly it did not make sense, but it added to the confusion in the way in which this was brought forward.

The first we knew of a proposed amendment to the Bill was the circulation of a paper during debate on 10 April which indicated that the honourable member for Dawson was to move an amendment to the Bill concerning consultation, this time with the superannuation industry-at least the right industry. That is not what he said the day before. The amendment was moved virtually after the debate was over.

In any event, the Government had given its assurances that consultation would take place, and it is taking place already. I am confident that the amendment now moved by the Government meets the concerns expressed by the Opposition in this place and by the Opposition and Australian Democrats in the other place.

Turning to the issue itself in hand today, the arrangements which the Government proposed in bringing forward the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 include a requirement for consultation with the superannuation industry. My second reading speech for the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 indicates that the intention of the levy is to recover the cost of the supervision of the industry and that there would be annual discussions with the industry in the determination of the scale of the levy. In addition, the speech also indicated that consultation is to take place between the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the Department of Finance in determining the amount of revenue needed to fully recover costs.

As I have mentioned, discussions have already been undertaken with industry representatives concerning the amount of the first year's levy. I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that the industry consultations, which are continuing, are with a broad grouping of superannuation industry bodies and representatives, not just with the two associations mentioned in the request for amendment circulated by the Opposition.

I am happy here today to reaffirm the Government's commitment to consultation with a broad range of bodies and persons in the superannuation industry on an annual basis and to reaffirm that the amount of revenue required to be raised by the levy would be agreed annually with the Department of Finance.

The reasons for the Government requesting the amendment before the House is to acknowledge the concerns expressed by the Opposition regarding the consultation process and to set out such a process in the Bill in a way which will provide for these industry consultations with a wide group of bodies and persons-in other words, wider than the two associations mentioned in the Opposition's requested amendment-and not require the involvement of the Minister in the consultation, as was proposed by the Opposition. It is the Government's view that the involvement of the Minister in this level of discussion would not be appropriate.

In addition, we want to ensure that the mechanism required for consultation can actually be achieved. The concerns I have with the Opposition's views on this matter are that it may not be practical or possible, in some circumstances, to have regard only to the views of the industry associations mentioned by the Opposition. Those mentioned in the amendment are the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia Ltd and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia. If, for instance, these industry associations expressed divergent views it might not be possible to have regard to all of the views, and that could threaten the validity of the whole of the levy regulations. A requirement to have regard to industry views could also be seen to be too restrictive if it were seen to be exclusive.

In setting the scale of the levy, it is likely that the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner would need to have regard to other factors. These would include taking account of relevant aspects of the Government's retirement incomes policy and cost recovery policy and taking account of the views of other persons and bodies, including the Department of Finance. The Government amendment I have moved places a legal obligation on the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to consult with the superannuation industry. He is bound to observe this obligation, and bodies whose interests are affected could bring action in the courts to enforce such consultation.

Subclause (3) of the proposed amendment has been included not to negate subclause (2) in any way but to ensure that the validity of the regulations cannot be threatened. Without such a clause it is strongly arguable that trustees could claim that there had been some technical deficiency in the consultation. This could be used as a ground to challenge the validity of the levy regulations.

For the reasons I have outlined, the Government requests an amendment to the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 which would ensure that consultation was undertaken but which would not, of necessity, include the Minister; which would require consultation with a broad representation of the superannuation industry; and which would allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to take account of relevant matters other than industry views concerning the supervisory levy. I commend the amendment to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the surface, this appears to be almost what the Opposition put forward at the time of the general debate on the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill. I will take up a few points. First, as I understand it, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) was not present in the House to reply to the second reading debate. I am not sure to what extent he was present during the general debate. Certainly he was not here when I was leading the debate for the Opposition, nor was he here at the end. In fact, I remember an exchange between the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who was at the table at the time, and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) about why the Minister was not here. The Minister should be here, not for the whole debate but certainly during its closing stages. The Minister was not here that night.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Minister talked about absence of knowledge of the amendments. On the morning after I spoke, the Minister's office and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner got in touch with my office to find out the meaning of the amendment. That was a warning of at least 12 hours before the closing of the debate. In fact, I think 36 hours elapsed. To say that there was no warning is absolute hogwash.

The Minister talked about warnings, but this is the first indication I have had from the Minister on this matter. I did not know about his proposed speech. In addition, we were unaware of how the Senate would view the amendment we had moved. The Minister talked about there being no warning, but there was 36 hours warning-enough for the Minister at the table to come in with a prepared speech from which there would be no deviation. He could argue the case and it would appear in the Hansard. At that stage there was no intimation that the Government would agree to it.

I refer now to the difference in the terms of the amendments now before us. If the Minister had been here at the time to debate his legislation it would not have been necessary for us now to debate these amendments. My point is that this has gone from the House of Representatives to the Senate. It is obvious from the manner in which the Senate has passed the amendments that there has been no intervention by the Minister to argue the points he is now arguing at this very late stage. I do not agree with him when he says that the case for clause 7 (3) is strongly arguable. It states that, before regulations are made, the Commissioner must consult. In the next sentence it is stated that a failure to comply with subsection (2) does not affect the validity of the regulations. That is double talk. Without the advantage of hearing the argument or seeing the reasons for this, it is strongly arguable that this in effect means that the Commissioner may not consult at all. There is no consultative mechanism in this. Failure to comply is an acknowledgment that it will not be looked at.

I will not accept these amendments for those reasons. They vary considerably from the thrust of the debate in the Senate. Firstly, we were not notified. The Minister has obviously not talked to anyone. It was only by accident, because I was in the chamber at the time, that I knew it was being called on. The Minister gave my office no notice that this was to be brought on, nor did he give me the advantage of looking at it so that I could discuss it with my colleague in the Senate who is responsible for this area to get his reaction. At this stage, because of the lack of consultation and because of the wording of the amendment, the Opposition will not accept it. It is double talk; it does not conform with what we were looking at.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Crean's) be agreed to.
