DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1990-91APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to these Appropriation Bills, my comments tonight are directed at the Government's industry statement and relate to those matters relevant to technology and its application across the manufacturing sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by commending the Government for its initiative in reviewing the commercial orientation of industry related research and development (R and D) programs conducted by the Industry Research and Development Board (IRDB), to which I will speak shortly. The Government's actual plans, however, are ill defined and constitute statements of intention. As I foreshadowed in the House on a previous occasion regarding legislation affecting the IRDB's discretionary grants and generic technologies grants schemes, this is a direction in which the coalition will move. If Australia is to make a fist of commercialisation, it will need to work towards building a much more commercially oriented technology development program. The public research sector is coming to realise this truth.

If the Government's intention is to encourage industrial R and D which is internationally competitive and has significant commercial application, I am curious as to how this is achievable under the current structure of the generic technologies grants scheme. A prioritised strategic R and D grants scheme, while admirable for its social role, tends to lack the hard-nosed commercial orientation for a scheme masquerading under an industry related R and D program. I look forward to witnessing the Government's own initiatives in this regard.

The Government has also announced an initiative designed to assist in the pace at which Australian companies take up locally produced advanced manufacturing technologies. While the initiative, if it can be called that, has hitherto gone without any public and detailed explanation, it too must be seen as a move designed to redress failings on the part of the Government. A report released last month by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce demonstrated the extent to which there has been under-investment in advanced production equipment in Australian industry. The report, entitled Australian Science Innovation Impact Brief, clearly demonstrated the extent to which the investment climate had militated against the replacement of equipment with advanced technologies. The extent to which Australian industry makes use of basic robotics in production processes is appallingly low by international standards. All in all, some 30 per cent only of Australia's medium-sized firms have no familiarity whatsoever with advanced manufacturing production processes. On the basis of available business surveys, some 65 per cent of Australia's small firms are unacquainted with computer-aided design and manufacturing technologies, which are at the heart of advanced manufacturing processes.

The Government's decision to extend the relevant bounty scheme for machine tools and robots and to create a form of procurement program to develop and trial local manufacturing technologies is meant to redress this problem to some undefined degree, but in so doing it makes a mockery of certain of the past claims made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

The House will recall that it was informed, along with the Australian public, that Australia's massive import bills were feeding a once in 20 years' capital stock replacement program in local industries. If this is so, why are we back here introducing schemes of this sort, which really are an indirect means of compensating for market-driven forces which make for genuine technological restructuring? We are back here for the simple truth that the economic conditions which determine the extent to which industries invest in plant and equipment and develop long term technology strategies have been absent.

Recent Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures confirm that high interest rates have sharply curtailed the manufacturing sector's capacity to re-equip itself. This is the fundamental problem for Australian industry in re-equipping itself. In fact, the share of gross domestic product (GDP) devoted to new plant and equipment is at its lowest level since 1975. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, only 6.8 per cent of output was invested in new capital stock over the course of the last financial year. This represents the third-lowest annual investment in new plant, equipment and machinery in the past 30 years. The other lowest years on record were 1974 and 1975-coincidentally also under the stewardship of a Labor Treasurer. The next quarter's figures may be worse still. It is conceivable that the Government, despite the Treasurer's past claims, will preside over the worst level of annual industry reinvestment in the postwar period.

In last year's Budget statement, the Government predicted that investment in new plant and equipment would fall by 4 per cent. What prediction does the Government offer now that we are well and truly into an engineered recession? Is it any wonder that the Government made a quick grab for a depreciation policy in the industry statement? The Government knows what is staring it in the face. While depressing in their own right, these observations about the rates of reinvestment tell us just how far Australia really has to go before its manufacturing sector is able to obtain even a measure of competitiveness in respect of its production processes. Each year industry dips in its reinvestment levels, the further and further ahead streak its trading rivals.

Over the course of the industry statement, the Government also committed itself to the further open-ended extension of the 150 per cent tax incentive scheme, which after 1993 will be at a reduced rate of 125 per cent. That is a low-risk initiative; the Government will not be here to meet the cost in forgone revenue that this will result in. So the scheme, quite frankly, will be handed on to the incoming coalition government. It is a commitment which should not have been made in the absence of a mandatory review period. This is not a political judgment; it is just a sound public administration policy.

I would also add that in throwing open the taxation scheme in perpetuity, the Government has sent the wrong signals to industry on its approach to industry development strategy. Schemes such as the 150 per cent tax incentive scheme must be accountable to public scrutiny. I think the Government must balance the carrot-and-stick approach; the Government must provide an incentive to industry to look to and actually experience the rewards of higher investment in research and development, but it must not promote a sense that the public purse will for all time be the essential trigger for making decisions in this regard.

If it is to be used effectively, the scheme must provide the impetus for expanding levels of private sector R and D in the economy. But what if the level of R and D slows or plateaus in the next few years? If this happens, what will be the role and function of this scheme? Is it then to underwrite a nominal level of R and D investment, which might represent core industry commitments alone? Generally speaking, the knowledge of the determinants of current levels of R and D expenditure in the private sector is still inadequate or, at best, imperfect. Australia does not have an historical perspective-that is, a sufficiently stable representation of R and D performances over time-to make hard and fast judgments about the long term significance of schemes such as the 150 per cent R and D taxation incentive scheme.

To date, the Government has not been able to sift out the key factors making for R and D activities, and quantify them or their outcomes with any accuracy. We do not know on any empirical basis, for instance, whether current levels of R and D would have been attained without the existence of the incentive; that is to say, there is still a great deal of uncertainty as to the direct and real impact of the existence of the scheme on management decisions as against other larger financial issues affecting the company's performance, or as a result of changing business strategies. We need to study R and D performances over time and in different economic circumstances in order to make firm judgments about these matters.

Moreover, the changing definitions of R and D have dramatically altered statistical representations of levels of research and development activity. In view of this, the Australian economy is still coming to grips with the concept of R and D activity and management and, particularly, R and D measurement. Despite this the Government has seen fit to throw open access to the 150 per cent research and development taxation incentive for all time.

A review simply designed to assess the scheme would take into account the continuing relevance regarding the extent to which it is effectively changing industry attitudes in respect of R and D investment, the impact of changing economic circumstances on its operation, the implication of such matters as dividend imputation for its effectiveness, and the extent to which it is simply effective in realising its objectives in respect of other social objectives.

These tests are essential to measure the commitment of the public purse to a 150 per cent tax scheme, let alone an open-ended 150 per cent research and development tax incentive scheme. Such schemes do have relevance in the current economic environment, but they should also play a role as a means of encouraging industry to develop eventually its own self-sustaining R and D effort. What sort of signal is an open-ended taxation deduction scheme free of any continuing built-in review sending to industry? Moreover, what indication does it give of the Government's commitment to common standards of public administration?

The Government has also moved towards recognition of the impact of the wholesale sales tax system, but not nearly sufficiently so. The wholesale sales tax system impacts disproportionately upon the high technology industry sector. The limited and qualified efforts to alleviate this in the industry statement of 12 March will not markedly affect this situation. The statement provides for changes to the wholesale sales tax system which will alter only $375m of the incidence of tax. The incidence of wholesale sales tax on business input actually amounts to in excess of $5 billion. So one can see that the Government's changes are a drop in the ocean.

Similarly, the Government made a vain attempt to lure the superannuation and other investment funds into a contrived venture capital pool. The industry understandably baulked. It will understandably baulk again when word filters through that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) would like to see union influence at work in the direction of investment decisions affecting superannuation funds.

Interestingly, we now see the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, offering to offset the impact of the Government capital gains tax if the superannuation funds would only come to the party. At least Senator Button has come to understand how serious is the impact of the capital gains tax on the mobility, and therefore on the availability of venture capital across the Australian economy.

This is a matter about which the Industry Commission will have a great deal to say in the wash-up from its inquiry into obstacles to the formation of venture capital in Australia. The rush to formulate the industry statement for last March has, of course, meant that the Government is out of kilter with the Industry Commission's findings in this regard. There is little doubt that the Government will be unwilling to listen to the Industry Commission's findings in respect of the availability of venture capital. We already know that it will largely argue that the pool of venture capital is directly affected by the dynamism and performance of the industrial base. If one wishes to understand this, then one must look at how the venture capital industry operates in countries like the United States of America, Japan and the United Kingdom.

The cost of local capital and therefore interest rate policy, the level of domestic savings, the taxation settings which determine capital mobility and so forth are all matters which will provide a direct critique of Government taxation and macro-economic policies. No wonder the Government chose to pre-empt the Industry Commission's report. We all know just where the Government stands on those critical economic settings which determine the viability of the manufacturing sector-indeed, for all industries in the economy.

The Government's preoccupation with schemes like a directed fund of funds, and so forth, provides further testimony to its failure to bring change where change is needed. For all the debate about the need to direct superannuation funds to provide capital support for high technology industries, the Government has turned its back on one of the main determinants of capital support for, as an example, research and development efforts within small high technology start-up companies, and that is the cost of capital itself, or interest rates.

For advice on this matter, the Government had no need to go further than its own Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) in this regard. In its 1987 review into small business, the BIE surveyed 119 high technology companies. The survey spanned biotechnology companies, communications and information technology companies, micro-electronics companies, and new materials and scientific and medical instruments industries. The survey revealed that the major constraint to higher levels of R and D activity was the cost of capital. It was not just fragile start-up companies which were adversely affected in this regard, but the more stable ends of the more high technology industry sector. The BIE review concluded, at page 29:

The factor which emerged as the most important constraint . . . was the cost of finance. Around 90% of firms regarded this as at least `important' and of these 70% perceived it to be a `very important' constraint.

Remember, this review by the BIE was published in 1988 and drew on 1987 data; that is, the firms surveyed were only just beginning to feel the impact of the high interest regime imposed upon the economy by the Treasurer.

So we can validly ask: what is their experience now, three years down the track-three years of labouring under the world's highest interest rates in real terms? Even with interest rates falling off in the recession, real interest rates-that is, prime rates less consumer price index-remain at 10 per cent as at December 1990. This compares with 4.5 per cent in Japan, 4.1 per cent in the United Kingdom and 3.7 per cent in the United States. Is it any wonder our market competitiveness in the tradeable high value, high technology goods sector is eroding?

Australia needs, as all honourable members would agree, to retain and build upon its scientific and technological skill base. It needs to invigorate the various research processes at work in the public sector research community. It needs to ensure that the structure and the physical resources which underpin those processes are adequate to the task. But the other hard policy work must also be carried out. I really do believe that the Government has to make some of the hard decisions that impact generally across the economy, but nowhere more so than in high technology manufacturing.

In conclusion, the House must be reminded that in order for Australia to capture the benefits of its present R and D efforts, in order for it to capitalise on the body of existing intellectual property and strengthen the market position of its youthful high technology manufacturing sector, the Government must as a priority establish an economic environment which is conducive to those ends. There is, on the Government's part, a belief that these areas of activity are somehow separate from the economy. This is simply a convenient and useful fiction.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills are designed to provide funds to keep the programs of the Government running after the moneys appropriated last year are exhausted. They arise because extra funds are required as a result of new programs, and despite savings that have been achieved and were set out in the papers. A large number of programs are involved here and I rise to speak to only two of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to make a couple of comments about the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). By and large, I agree with his statement that the Government should-and in fact the Government does-place considerable emphasis on the development of new technologies. I spent five years before coming into this place on the board of a company that was seeking to develop new technologies and commercialise them. It was extremely difficult. Some of the remarks the previous speaker made were appropriate in pointing to the difficulties involved. We started from way behind the starting line in a society that historically has not commercialised its new technologies, particularly in the manufacturing sector, which is where our attention was devoted.

The management and investment company (MIC) program then in place was an attempt to encourage the development and commercialisation of new technologies, and we started off very enthusiastically. As we got into the business it became clearer and clearer that the lead times from an idea to a commercial application were much longer and that the percentage of such ideas that became commercial successes was much smaller than we had previously conceived. Some societies and economies have proved very successful at commercialising new technologies. I suppose Japan is the most startling example of this at the present time, but the Germans and the Americans have also had successes.

The conclusion I reached eventually was to some degree along the lines put by the honourable member for Gippsland-that we need to get the general economic settings right and to make the capital markets awash with capital to the degree that they are prepared to take risks in new technologies, which are very risky and very long term investments. There are a few other micro-economic policies that can be applied, particularly in the form of a fund of funds, which I think is a good idea if it can be got together.

The MICs as part of an overall policy setting are useful. But I note that, particularly in Japan, which has recently been the most successful economy in this respect, the new technologies have tended to be developed within arms of much larger companies that have a cash flow from lower level technologies. So typically one finds a large conglomerate engaged in the production of, say, newspapers, soap, beer and perhaps motor vehicles, which provide a cash flow, setting aside part of its annual earnings into high risk and long term investment strategies dealing with the development of new technologies. As a result of the five years experience I had in the field, that is a habit that I fear will take a longer time to acquire than I realised a decade ago. Nonetheless, I am encouraged by the fact that both sides of the House recognise the importance of getting that process under way.

I rose to speak about two other matters, the first being tertiary education and the Austudy program and the second our foreign aid. These Bills incorporate an increase in expenditure of $28.677m on the Austudy program. I note from the reports that are coming out of the universities this year that there is overenrolment in some of our universities. Nobody is very happy to see overcrowding in the facilities of our universities and nobody, particularly an academic or a former academic like myself, wants to see library facilities clogged and unusable, students unable to get the books they require, and so on.

This has to be set in the historical context that a decade ago, when I was still working in universities, some universities in this country had considerable difficulties filling the quotas they had for some of their courses. Young Australians were not going on to tertiary education. The rate of completion of secondary education was very low, both compared with today and compared with other economies at a similar level of development. To compensate for that the Government has tried to undertake an expansion of university places.

I suppose it is with mixed feelings that I now find that we have excess demand for university places. This is extremely good in that there has been an increase in the number of Australians wanting to go to university for training, but it suggests that, despite the massive expansion that has been undertaken, we have not been able to increase the supply of university places at a commensurate rate. I believe the Government should continue to maintain its program of increasing facilities and staff at universities such that the demand for places can be met.

We need to plan right now to avoid the projected 20,000 shortfall in the number of university academics by the end of this decade. I have looked at the study that projected the 20,000 and, with due respect to the authors, one of whom is an old acquaintance of mine, I think they exaggerate. Nonetheless, there is the likelihood of a shortfall of academics. We need to address that problem now and to increase the attractiveness of university teaching as a career. This will involve, as in all other supply and demand situations, improving the pay and conditions of academics.

I note that this is presently under review and that an agreement has been reached between the employers, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, and the employees, the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations. The agreement is now being examined by the Government with a view to providing the additional funding that will be necessary to reach a satisfactory resolution. I hope this receives the attention it requires.

We have also expanded scholarships for students who want to stay on at university and who lack the financial support to enter university. Austudy has become an integral part of the expansion of that system. This appropriation continues the expansion of Austudy to students who need financial support to get to tertiary education. I get, and I am sure I will continue to get, complaints from people who feel they are entitled to Austudy but do not get it or are not to receive it because of the means and assets tests that are applied. Without committing ourselves to the existing levels of means and assets tests for all time, I think the principle does need to be recognised by everybody that the more lax the assets and means tests that are applied to the receivers of Austudy, the fewer poor children will be able to receive total Austudy payments and thereby enter the university system.

So the factor that has led to the higher than expected expenditure on the Austudy program, to the extent of $28m plus, is that the Austudy program has been extremely successful since it was introduced in 1987. It is expected that over 350,000 students and their families will be receiving assistance during 1990-91, an increase of 9.5 per cent over the previous year. It is also true that a higher than expected increase in the number of students receiving assistance means that $28.7m more will be spent on Austudy.

The increase in the number of beneficiaries is related to a number of factors, including the higher than expected enrolments in the tertiary education sector, to which I referred just now and which is to be welcomed; the higher retention rates that have been experienced in years 11 and 12, which has been a development occurring over the last 10 years, and one which I hope continues; improved marketing and information materials that have led to increased numbers of eligible secondary students applying under the scheme; an increased program recognition-and I note here that an Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls survey shows that the Austudy scheme receives the highest recognition among 15- to 24-year-olds of all government programs directed at youth; and an increased recognition on the part of students of the benefits of completing appropriate education and training before entering the labour market.

In other words, while we come before the House to vote on whether an extra $28m should be devoted to this program, it is clearly a success that we are having to appropriate more money. It is a recognition of one successful step towards making the cleverer country that the Government is trying to achieve.

The other matter I should like to talk about is our aid program. In these appropriations we find that there are two different line items relating to aid. One is a saving of $6.2m in development assistance to South East Asia, and the other, moving in the other direction, is an increase of $5m in assistance for the Middle East. I should like to speak about these items together but deal with them rather discretely.

The reason for the cut of $6.2m in expenditure in South East Asia development assistance has been due not to a governmental decision to cut the aid programs, although that might well be undertaken, but to an International Monetary Fund aid program in Vietnam being postponed and to a Thai pilot equity scholarship scheme being absorbed under other headings. However, I would like to take this opportunity to make some observations about our aid program to east Asia.

I want to make it very clear at the start that I am not against foreign aid programs in general. In some cases it is quite clear that they can produce economic development where it would not have otherwise occurred, or achieve a level of economic activity which would not have occurred without such an aid program. I suppose that the two most startling examples of these instances are Israel and Cuba, which until recently were the two most strategically dependent economies in the world-one very heavily dependent on a United States inflow of funds, the other on similar kinds of arrangements from the Soviet Union. Quite clearly both of them, by being underwritten by superpower programs, were able to achieve a degree of economic activity which otherwise, particularly given their military commitments, would have been very difficult.

On the other hand, such aid programs do not always work and I suppose that, in the literature, the most commonly cited instance of them not working very satisfactorily has been in sub-Saharan Africa, which has been a major-possibly the major-recipient of international aid programs during the last decade but which, nonetheless, has one of the least successful economic performances of any region in the world, with what now would appear to be the exception of the Soviet Bloc, sections of which have perpetrated absolute disasters.

It is also the case that aid programs can achieve strategic advantage for the donor state that wants to achieve military strength in a particular part of the world and provides economic assistance to other states. I suppose that the most striking example of that is the Marshall Plan of American assistance to postwar Europe.

Against these kinds of backgrounds, I ask myself what kinds of assistance programs we should be delivering in South East Asia-and east Asia, for that matter. It is very widely known that the economic performance and growth rates of the east and South East Asian economic sector as a whole have been quicker than Australia's. The Australian currency has slipped against many currencies of the region over the last 10 years or so, and many of them, or at least some of them, are generating large external surpluses and have now become major foreign investors in their own right.

I note that in the latest Westpac Bank survey of per capita income trends in east and South East Asia, including Australia, published in April 1991, the movement of per capita incomes has been significantly to the relative disadvantage of Australia, which still rates at No. 2 in the region after Japan but has slipped relative to many of the others, with the exception of the Philippines, as far as the open market economies are concerned, which has very badly slipped during the 1980s. In other words, many of the economies to our near north are producing very significant growth rates of economic development, some of which would be, to a degree anyway, our envy.

It seems to me that in such circumstances, we ought to scrutinise much more closely the aid programs that we deliver to that part of the world and direct them either to strategic purposes or to emergency relief against natural and other disasters-which I regard as always part of our international commitment-or to specific projects with definable outcomes and/or diplomatic advantages; otherwise I think that the focus of our aid programs should be towards clear cases of need, such as Cambodia to our north, to the South West Pacific countries that are not having such success stories in economic development, notably Papua New Guinea, or to regions of great disaster, and I would include here the Middle East.

The other region I would like to talk about is the Middle East, where we have been providing special development assistance over the last eight or nine months. I have received-I will not say a pile of letters-a steady flow of letters, phone calls and personal requests, since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in early August of last year, saying that it is a shame that we have had to get involved in this war, and what are we doing to ensure that the postwar world of the Middle East will be improved?

I would just like to say a few things about our contribution in that respect, before closing. We have, since August 1990 to February 1991, provided $5m in various forms of relief and aid to the Middle East. I note that on 9 April, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) announced a further contribution of $1m, which involved, on 13 April, a Royal Australian Air Force 707 aircraft leaving for Turkey with some 22 tonnes of relief supplies.

I might point out here that I had a number of offers from constituents, including notably the Salvation Army, to provide material assistance for the Middle East, and much of this had to be refused because the requirement at the time was for tents and for blankets and the offers that were being made particularly by the Salvation Army were of clothing. That gives a total of $6m that has been provided already, and we should note that the Government is, in addition, giving urgent consideration to identifying further sources of humanitarian aid, particularly for the Kurdish problem.

I should point out also that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is fast-tracking about 100 longstanding Kurdish refugees in humanitarian applications; our charge d'affaires in Tehran has visited the border area where the Kurdish problem is involved; and our embassy in Ankara has been in close contact with Turkish authorities. In other words, as the military resolution of that conflict took place, alongside it Australia was providing developmental assistance and emergency aid to the people who were suffering partly as a result of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait but also as a result of the unhappy situation that obtains in the Middle East in general.

Now that the war is over, we are providing humanitarian aid and have been providing humanitarian aid to the situation in the Middle East. I noted that yesterday, when I had been contemplating speaking on these Appropriation Bills, I was intending to make some very critical remarks about the United States policy; instead, I will confine myself to merely critical remarks. The United States, I think, undertook essentially a just war in liberating Kuwait from Iraqi occupation. It then openly and very volubly suggested that the Iraqi people should rise and throw out Saddam Hussein, an idea which I, too, thought was very good. But having unsuccessfully undertaken that project in northern Iraq, they were left stranded in their hundreds of thousands across the mountains of northern Iraq where the Turkish military were denying them entry to Turkey, for reasons that I understand, and they were finding it physically difficult to gain refuge in Iran. The Americans' determination to wash their hands of the problem, given United Nations commitments to sovereignty of its national constituent states, was understandable, I suppose, but very much a shame and was a blemish on the otherwise very successful, if you like, finest hour of American intervention in the Middle East.

I have received again many phone calls from constituents over the last couple of weeks asking what the United States intended to do about this particular tragedy, and I was delighted to see in the paper today that the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Turkey are about to build what amounts to, as it is described here, `security enclaves inside northern Iraq'. I also notice that our mission in New York has made known our wholehearted support for such operations and our views in support of the development of safe havens in which relief can be provided for the Kurds and our exploration of the scope of use of provisions of Security Council resolution 687 to maintain pressure on Iraq in relation to its treatment of the Kurds, and we are actively exploring possibilities for further action through the Secretary-General. We are, in other words, undertaking aid in conjunction with the leading coalition powers from the Gulf war to try to alleviate the difficulties presently presented by the Kurdish situation, particularly in Iraq.

Finally, I would like to say something about the shuttle diplomacy being undertaken by the American Secretary of State, Mr Baker. I would welcome very much the more positive attitude that the Americans have adopted towards the resolution of the Palestinian question. I spoke in the adjournment debate a couple of weeks ago on the urgency which I believe should be attached to the resolution of that problem. I am delighted that the Americans are giving it top priority in the post-Gulf war period, and I think that, as part of our continuing readiness to provide Australian development assistance and emergency aid for the Middle East, we should contemplate assisting in that fashion the resolution of the Palestinian question.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will implement one of the most significant changes to the Australian system of social security since the 1940s. It involves the end of the unemployment benefit (UB) program-a program which was created in a world very different from today's. It will see the introduction of a new strategy-the Newstart program-which will help us deal far more effectively with the pressing problems of the 1990s.

Mr Speaker, I do not need to remind honourable members of the urgent need for a program such as this at this time. We must not repeat the mistakes of 1982-83. Those who lost their jobs at that time were largely ignored. As a result, enormous damage was done to their skills and motivation and serious problems of poverty were created. When the recovery came, long term unemployment remained a serious problem that has taken many years of government effort to tackle.

The major changes which are introduced in this Bill build on the successful reforms of recent years which have received widespread community support and produced far more effective outcomes for the unemployed. The Jobsearch allowance for youth and the initial Newstart program for the long term unemployed have clearly demonstrated the effectiveness of positive measures of assistance, and form the foundation for our new approach.

The Newstart program provided for in this Bill is a wide-ranging strategy. It centres on the creation of two new payments-Jobsearch allowance and New- start allowance-which in turn involve new patterns of obligation, greater emphasis on training, increased responsibility for the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), and improved Commonwealth Employment Service/Department of Social Security liaison.

Newstart is a major step forward in the integration of income support with labour market assistance. We recognise that it is simply not enough in these difficult times to provide people with income support and leave them to their own job search. We have to find out why people are having difficulty in finding work. We have to think about their prospects, not just immediately, but in the longer term. We then have to make serious attempts at dealing with their needs through training and other programs.

One of the keys to the success of this strategy, Mr Speaker, therefore, is the availability of labour market programs. The Government has substantially increased the availability of these programs for the long term unemployed in recent years. As part of the Newstart program, an additional $227m is to be provided for labour market programs until the end of 1993-94, giving over 50,000 additional program places each year. This increase will be supplemented by the $105m expansion of labour market programs announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the March 1991 Industry Statement.

With the Newstart program, we will not be repeating the disastrous social and economic policy of 1982-83. We will be working with unemployed Australians in the most effective way possible to ensure that they will share in the benefits of economic recovery. More than that, we will be working to improve the competitiveness of the Australian economy and its labour force. The Newstart program integrates social and economic goals in a way which will build on Australia's proud reputation as an international leader in social policy.

In developing the arrangements for Jobsearch allowance, a major aim is to help prevent long term unemployment wherever possible-to deal with problems before they become entrenched. Recipients will be required to participate in a labour market program or vocational training if this is likely to improve their chances of finding a job. The CES will provide early intervention assistance to Jobsearch allowance recipients within the first three months where it is needed. There will remain a strong focus on helping young people, and the current arrangements for 16- and 17-year olds will be incorporated into the Jobsearch allowance provisions.

The Bill provides that Jobsearch allowees, like Newstart allowees, who start Commonwealth Employment Service approved training will continue to receive their Jobsearch payment together with the normal training allowances. Improving skills should be seen as an integral part of effective job search, particularly in the current economic situation. The change will help resolve some problems of interruption of income support that people have experienced under current arrangements when transferring from unemployment benefit to a training allowance.

When unemployment benefit was first introduced, and indeed for most of the first 30 years of its operation, long term unemployment was largely unknown. For the last 10 years, however, it has been a major community problem. The introduction of Newstart allowance for the long term unemployed will enable us to meet this problem in the specialised way that is needed.

Experience has shown that the key to tackling successfully the problems of the longer term unemployed lies in integration of income support and other forms of assistance. Since the Government upgraded efforts in this area, with the first phase of the Newstart program, the results have been striking. Newstart has also shown that concentrated efforts, utilising options from a range of available measures, to assist the long term unemployed can contribute to useful employment outcomes, even for persons in receipt of UB for five years or more. No country has found this problem easy to deal with but the figures show that significant numbers of people can be helped.

Between February 1989 and December 1990, 134,000 persons in the Newstart target group left unemployment benefit. During this time, around 75,000 unemployment benefit recipients have participated in labour market programs which will improve their employment prospects. The proportion of the unemployed who are long term fell from around 38 per cent in February 1989 to 25 per cent in November 1990.

Under the arrangements for Newstart allowance, therefore, the CES will have greatly increased responsibility for the long term unemployed. Willingness to undertake training or take advantage of other program assistance will be a major condition of income support. The CES will, under delegation, administer the activity test for Newstart allowees.

The Newstart program will see assistance and requirements tailored far more closely to individual needs and capacities. A key feature of the Newstart allowance will be the activity agreement that recipients will have to enter into to receive the allowance. In each case, the activity agreement will set out the steps that individuals will have to take to improve their employment prospects. There should be no misunderstanding about this. The activity agreement will be a requirement for payment. If a person is not prepared to enter into, and abide by, an agreement he or she will not be paid Newstart allowance.

This is an initiative very much aimed at providing real hope and assistance to people. It offers scope to people to acquire skills so that they will be better placed when the labour market starts to improve. I should stress, however, that the Government is strongly of the view that acceptance by the community of increased obligation to help the unemployed must be accompanied by increased reciprocal obligations for the unemployed to take advantage of the assistance available and so help themselves. Recipients of either allowance who unreasonably refuse offers of assistance or make insufficient efforts themselves will have their payments suspended for a period, or cancelled. Jobsearch allowance for those over 18 will be available for no more than 12 months. Transfer to Newstart allowance is not automatic. These are firm signals that income support will be payable only where recipients' obligations are met.

The interests of the community will also be protected by continuation of the measures introduced by the Government in recent years within the Department of Social Security to reduce the risk of fraud and incorrect payment. The Department will maintain its efforts in this area through its program of interviews and reviews, computer data matching, mobile review teams and other strategies. Those receiving Jobsearch allowance and Newstart allowance will have to lodge a form in person each fortnight to continue payment. Compliance will be enhanced by significantly improved liaison arrangements with the CES and the increased contact with individuals that is an essential feature of the Newstart program.

When the Newstart program was announced in the February 1990 Economic Statement, it was estimated that the program would be a minor net cost to the Commonwealth in 1990-91 of $0.4m with net savings of around $12.13m accruing in subsequent years.

The announcement of new labour market programs in the March 1991 industry statement and substantial changes to the UB parameters since early 1990 will change the overall cost savings of the program from the February 1990 estimates. However, net program savings are still anticipated from 1991-92.

There are those who would wish to deal with the problems of unemployment in a simplistic and socially and economically irresponsible way-by, for example, providing little or no program assistance and terminating benefits after a period regardless of whether a person has genuinely been able to find work.

This Government, however, has no intention of making scapegoats of the unemployed. The necessary measures to require reciprocal obligation on the part of the unemployed and to maintain the integrity of the system should be seen in the context of the positive assistance and encouragement which will be provided. The Newstart program is intended to address the real problems of the unemployed and work in their interest and that of the whole community.

This Bill would also incorporate initiatives introduced during the Budget sittings 1990 that would impact on the payability of Jobsearch allowance or Newstart allowance or the rate of payment at which a person is to be paid.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.
(Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It contains measures to extend normal mainland Australian taxation arrangements to the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The Bill also contains amendments that relate to the measures enacted by this Government last year to deal with the avoidance of Australian tax through the use of controlled foreign companies and trusts.

The Bill will give effect to the changes the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced on 13 December 1990 to the taxation arrangements for foreign employment income derived by Australian residents. These changes will greatly simplify a complex part of the tax system that affects individual Australians working overseas and will benefit, in particular, Australian missionaries and volunteer aid workers engaged in foreign service in a country that does not tax their income. Following consultations with the finance industry, measures are included to give effect to minor concessional modifications to the thin capitalisation provisions of the income tax law. Amendments to the land degradation provisions to give effect to the measures announced in the 1990-91 Budget arising from the review of Landcare objectives are also proposed.

The Bill will also provide for taxpayers to be able to claim a deduction for both current and capital expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1991 in the course of rehabilitating mining or quarrying sites. Amendments to various provisions relating to the quotation of a tax file number for the investment phase and to simplify the provisions of the Act relating to pensions, benefits and allowances are also included.

The Bill will extend the taxation relief presently available for securities transferred between lenders and borrowers under securities lending arrangements. The gift provisions of the income tax law and the law in relation to the assessment and payment provisions for companies and superannuation funds will be amended. Finally, as part of its continuing commitment to the fight against organised crime, the Government has decided to extend access to taxation information to three law enforcement agencies.

I now turn to a more detailed discussion of these measures. In relation to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands the Bill will give legislative force to certain taxation measures that are part of a number of reforms to be introduced under the Government's commitment to give effect to the vote by the Cocos Malay people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to integrate with Australia.

Broadly, under the proposed changes, residents of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands will, from 1 July 1991, be subject to Australian tax obligations in respect of presently exempt income and capital gains. In addition, previously exempt fringe benefits will become taxable from 1 July 1991. These changes, the main features of which I will briefly outline, mirror those set out in a memorandum of understanding that was signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and representatives of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands community on 7 March this year.

Personal income tax is to be phased in so that a tax in respect of previously exempt income and capital gains will be reduced by 50 per cent during the 1991-92 income year. Full rates of personal tax will first apply to such income and capital gains in the 1992-93 income year. As Cocos (Keeling) Islands residents already have access to Medicare benefits, normal rates of the Medicare levy will apply from 1 July 1991. Full rates of company tax will apply to previously exempt income and capital gains of Cocos (Keeling) Islands resident companies in the 1991-92 income year. Capital gains tax rules will now apply to all assets disposed of on or after 1 July 1991 by residents of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. However, in respect of previously exempt assets, only the gain which has accrued on or after 1 July 1991 will be subject to the capital gains tax.

A consequential effect of the proposed amendments is that the residents of Norfolk Island will, in the 1991-92 and later income years, be liable to tax on income or capital gains derived from sources in the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands in the same way as they are presently liable to tax on income or gains from sources in mainland Australia. Revenue from these changes is estimated at $260,000 in 1991-92 and $750,000 in 1992-93, although this will be offset by other aspects of the integration package for the Islands.

Under the heading of foreign source income, amendments in this area reflect the Government's willingness to act on proposals for the smoother implementation of these measures. In this vein, the Bill will exempt from Australian tax certain dividends paid by a controlled foreign company from income that has been taxed under another country's accruals tax measures, and will clarify that distributions from non-resident trusts that qualify for the rebate of tax on winding-up will not be subject to the interest charge.

On the other hand, I must emphasise this Government's determination to ensure that these measures have their intended effect in countering tax avoidance. Some of the amendments will therefore streamline the provisions that were enacted to deal with tax avoidance through disguised distributions of profits, while others will ensure that offshore money lending businesses cannot claim excessive deductions for bad debts.

In relation to taxation of foreign employment income, under present law an Australian resident person working overseas on certain approved projects, or otherwise as an employee, may be entitled to a full exemption from Australian tax as long as the foreign service is not less than 12 months, or a partial exemption for periods between three and 12 months.

The law also makes the exemptions subject to the tax treatment of the income in the other country, and requires complex calculations to take the exempt income into account when taxing other income of the taxpayer. The Government considered several representations concerning difficulties arising under those provisions, including the position of Australian missionaries and volunteer aid workers who generally receive only a modest amount of remuneration and were often disadvantaged by the existing rules. I am therefore pleased to say that the measures proposed in this Bill will provide a more generous level of tax treatment to these volunteers who contribute to Australia's foreign aid program by working abroad.

The Government concluded also that the variable tests and complex calculations under the existing law should be rationalised in accordance with the Government's announced policy of simplification of the income tax system.
The Bill will therefore amend the income tax law to:
* extend the exemption in some circumstances where the foreign earnings are exempt from tax in the other country;

* reduce, from 12 to three months, the length of time a person must work overseas to qualify for full exemption-a consequential amendment will give a similar result under the fringe benefits tax law; and
* apply an average rate rather than a marginal rate to the taxpayer's non-exempt income and thus effectively reduce the Australian tax on that income.
The amendments will apply to foreign earnings derived on or after 1 July 1990 and are estimated to cost about $3m in 1991-92 and subsequent years.
Thin capitalisation

The Bill proposes minor modifications to the thin capitalisation provisions of the law which operate to limit interest deductions for Australian companies or other entities on borrowings from related foreign sources.

The first modification will exclude from the definition of foreign debt of an Australian company debentures eligible for the section 128f interest withholding tax exemption which are temporarily held by a foreign related party for the purpose of distribution overseas.

Two other minor technical modifications will extend the existing thin capitalisation concession for a foreign owned resident holding company which partly owns a resident bank. The revenue effect of these cannot be estimated, but is not considered to be substantial.
Land degradation

The deduction available to primary producers for capital expenditures designed to prevent land degradation is to be extended to taxpayers who derive business income from rural land. The proposed amendment will allow both primary producers and rural businesses to claim a deduction for fences erected to separate different land classes in accordance with an approved farm plan designed primarily and principally to prevent the degradation of land, whether or not it is already degraded.

These amendments, which see to fruition an undertaking given by this Government in its July 1989 statement on the environment, will have effect, broadly, from 22 August 1990 at an estimated cost of $2.7m in 1990-91, $4.2m in 1991-92 and $5m in 1992-93.
Mine site rehabilitation

This Bill will give effect to the Government's 1990-91 Budget announcement that current and capital rehabilitation expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1991 is to be immediately deductible against income from any source. Rehabilitation expenditure will qualify for the deduction where it is incurred on a site where exploration, mining or quarrying operations have been conducted.

Transitional measures in the Bill will ensure that the rehabilitation process is treated as part of a mining operation for the purpose of deductions available for housing and welfare and plant or articles under both the general and petroleum mining divisions of the income tax law.
The estimated cost of the amendment is $10m per annum in 1992-93 and later years.
Tax file number changes

These changes, which will have a negligible effect on the revenue, are in response to representations from investment bodies and investors and will lessen the administrative burden associated with the reporting requirements of the tax file number arrangements.

The law will be restated to make it clear that where a person makes an investment in a capacity as trustee he or she may quote the tax file number of the trust estate even though the investment is not held in the name of the trust. Further, the quotation rules will be streamlined where a person invests in an investment body through an interposed entity that is a solicitor or a body corporate.

Where all of the primary investors are identified in the investment made on their behalf by an interposed entity, the amended quotation rules will allow each primary investor to quote his or her tax file number to the investment body directly. If all of the primary investors are not identified, the interposed entity will be able to quote a reference number-to be called the `investment body remitter number'-instead of its own tax file number.

Other amendments proposed by this Bill will allow the Commissioner of Taxation to vary the date on which investment bodies must remit amounts withheld. Also, the existing exemption from quoting a tax file number where the income being paid is subject to non-resident withholding tax is to be tightened. The exemption will apply only where the investment body paying the income is actually required to withhold the tax, or would have been so required but for certain exemptions.

Finally in this regard, the Bill will remove the requirement-which is technically defective-that a deduction be made where a tax file number is not quoted for certain deferred interest securities. It is proposed to introduce new rules in the Budget sittings to deal with such investments.
Pensions, benefits and allowances

A project to improve the readability of social security and veterans' entitlements legislation by the use of a clear English drafting style and format is nearing completion and required consequential amendments to the income tax law.

In giving effect to these changes in this Bill, the opportunity has been taken to simplify the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act that exempt from tax certain pensions, benefits and allowances. The new legislation is intended to reflect existing policy and, accordingly, will have no financial impact.
Securities lending arrangements

The existing concession for securities lending arrangements will be extended to remove the restriction that currently denies relief if distributions are made or rights or options are issued or exercised during a borrowing period. Relief will be available where lenders receive any such distributions, rights, options, new securities or a compensatory payment. The allowable borrowing period will also be extended to less than 12 months.

These amendments follow consultations with the Stock Exchange and other parties involved in introducing improved settlement procedures in the securities industry. They were foreshadowed when the Government introduced the concession last year, and will have no effect on the revenue.
Company and superannuation fund self-assessment

The Bill will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to correct a technical deficiency in the assessment and payment provisions for companies and superannuation funds that commenced to apply in the current financial year.
Provision of tax information

Access to tax information is already given to certain other bodies including all Australian police forces, the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the National Crime Authority and the Australian Securities Commission.

The Bill will allow the Commissioner of Taxation to communicate, in specified circumstances, taxation information to authorised officers of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, the Independent Commission Against Corruption of New South Wales and the Crime Commission of New South Wales.

The Commissioner will be allowed to disclose taxation information to the authorised officers where he considers that the information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence-that is, an indictable offence-has been committed. He may also release information relating to a person convicted of a serious offence for evidence purposes for a post-conviction proceeds of crime proceedings.
The requirements of secrecy applying to taxation officers and other persons privy to confidential taxation information extend to officers to whom taxation information is to be communicated.
Gifts
The gift provisions of the income tax law are amended to reflect a change in name of the College of Nursing, Australia, to the Royal College of Nursing, Australia.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Hungary and Australia and Kiribati.

The Bill will insert the text of those agreements into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as schedules to that Act. The agreement with Hungary was signed on 29 November 1990 and that with Kiribati on 25 March 1991. Details of each agreement were announced and copies were made publicly available at the time of signature.

The agreements allocate taxing rights over all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and Hungary and Australia and Kiribati respectively. The agreements substantially accord with other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years.

Conclusion of the agreement with Hungary reflects Australia's support for that country's decision to adopt democratic structures and move towards a market economy, whilst negotiation of the agreement with Kiribati is in keeping with Australia's recognition of the development aspirations of regional developing countries.

As with Australia's other modern tax treaties with such countries, the agreement with Kiribati provides for `tax sparing' credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by Kiribati under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment. This means that where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives and is subject to Australian tax, a tax credit is to be allowed by Australia as if the Kiribati tax forgone had been paid. By this means the development incentives will retain their attraction for Australian investors and allow them to compete on favourable terms with investors from other countries, as they will not be negated by Australian tax.

Each of the respective agreements will enter into force when diplomatic notes are exchanged advising that the last of the necessary constitutional processes to give the agreement the force of law in the respective countries has been completed. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia for that purpose. The Government believes the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment and wider relationships between Australia and the treaty partner countries, but it is not possible to predict their effect on the revenue.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1990-91APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 provide additional estimates for a whole range of activities. In speaking to these Bills I will address briefly some of the issues that these additional estimates raise. I note that the additional estimates provide $32.2m as a contribution to the cost of the deployment of Australian naval vessels and personnel to the Persian Gulf task force and the vessels that took part in Operation Desert Storm. I am happy to support this appropriation, which forms part of a total cost of the Australian involvement in the Gulf war and the sanctions that preceded the Gulf war of about $100,000m, although as yet we do not know the total figure. It has to be understood that Australia played a very small part in that triumphant exercise, Operation Desert Storm, but we should never forget--
—But significant.

—As the Leader of the National Party says, Australia played a significant role. As a nation we did ourselves proud by participating in that exercise. Never let it be forgotten that all the alternative options that others put forward to us-and, of course, on a grander scale to the United States of America, Britain, France and others-were substantially worse than the option the world finally decided on.

SPEECH.PARA: I make three particular points about both the Australian involvement in the Gulf deployment and the more general issue of what has happened subsequently in that part of the world. As I said earlier, Australia was proud to make a contribution. We were very proud of the work done by our naval personnel in particular in that exercise. There is no doubt that they behaved with characteristic dignity in the best traditions of the Australian armed forces, particularly the Royal Australian Navy. They upheld the reputation of this country quite admirably. I understand from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) that we have present in the gallery tonight two naval officers who have just returned from the Gulf. I am not sure where they are sitting, but on behalf of everybody here I extend our congratulations to them on doing such a good job for our country. All of us appreciate what they have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the House supports the fine remarks of the honourable member for Mayo.

—As everybody would know, we sent two warships and we also sent a support ship. I make a handful of points about the totality of our contribution. I mentioned earlier that it was a small but proud contribution; but it was a matter of concern to me in the lead-up to the Gulf war when I learnt that there were so few ships in the Royal Australian Navy which had the capability to participate in that exercise. The ships that did participate did so admirably, but it is a concern-I was told by the appropriate officials-that only four ships out of the total Australian naval fleet had the appropriate close-in weapons systems to be able to make a truly useful contribution to Operation Desert Storm.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia could have considered a number of other possibilities. Hypothetically, we could have considered sending some ground troops and some Air Force deployments as well. But regardless of the politics of this issue, regardless of whether it would have been right or wrong to send additional support to Operation Desert Storm, we simply did not have the defence capability to do so. We could not have sent ground troops even if we had wanted to because we would not have been able to provide appropriate support for those ground troops.

We could not, as some people suggested, have sent F18s to make a contribution, as I think Canada did, because our F18s are not properly equipped for that sort of work. In particular, in Australia we do not have the radar jamming devices used on comparable aircraft in countries such as the United States and Britain. We were asked by the United States whether we would send some F111s with surveillance capability. The Government, for political reasons, decided that it would not send those F111 aircraft. History will judge whether that decision was right or wrong.

My major point about Australia's contribution is that we had so few ships, and no other capability beyond those F111 surveillance aircraft, to offer to Operation Desert Storm. It really underlines the fact that the Australian Defence Force has been allowed to deteriorate over recent years as a direct consequence of Government policy. One could say that it is the primary role of any government first and foremost to ensure that the country is properly defended. Therefore its primary role is to ensure that we have an effective defence force.

My great concern is that our Defence Force now has insufficient equipment and there is low morale amongst Defence Force personnel because of lack of training and lack of career opportunities. Related to that, it has insufficient resources to be able to conduct appropriate exercises. Aircraft are not able to fly sufficiently on exercises. There is not enough money to pay for the Navy to participate in exercises. It has had to cut back its steaming time. Training exercises for the Army have become extremely limited.

My concern is that the morale of our defence forces has sunk very low. Over recent years the potential effectiveness of our Defence Force has been weakened. The prestige of our Defence Force, despite the extraordinary degree of professionalism and commitment of those in the Defence Force, is simply being eroded. In a military sense, in the Asia-Pacific region and in particular in the South East Asian region Australia has nothing like the relative position it had 10 or 20 years ago.

That was one of the consequences of our participation in the Gulf war. It focused the minds of Australians and the minds of this Parliament, I would hope, on the inadequacies of our Defence Force and the need to reconsider the whole structure and operational effectiveness of our Defence Force. That is why the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) decided to establish an Opposition review of the whole of the Australian defence efforts, starting with a complete reassessment of the 1987 Defence White Paper, which is the basis of the Government's own defence policy.

The second point in relation to the Gulf war that I want to address involves this question which is much debated now about what the trade consequences of that war are. There is a view around in the Australian community, and certainly in the business community, that there are an enormous range of opportunities for Australian businesses to participate in the reconstruction of Kuwait and perhaps other parts of the Middle East. The Kuwaitis are in the process of letting a large number of contracts. As a result of that the Minister for Trade and Overseas Aid (Dr Blewett) visited Kuwait a couple of months ago.

Austrade has established what it perceives to be a special unit in order to assist the business community in Australia to get some of those contracts. The fact is that we need to understand one or two simple points in this country about those contracts. In the first place, if we are to get any of those contracts-so far I do not think we have any; Telecom has a good chance of securing some, but beyond Telecom we certainly do not have any-we will need to make a much bigger effort than we are already making.

We have one or two Austrade officers who are based in Kuwait. They have a mobile telephone system which has been set up for them by Telecom, and so we have some capacity on the ground. The Government may think that is just terrific and will tell the business community what a great job it has done. In truth, we have to look at that in relative terms.

Let us take Britain as an example. Rather cynically, before the war was over Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, took a trade delegation to Saudi Arabia to begin negotiations with Kuwaiti politicians and the Saudis about contracts for the reconstruction of Kuwait. Just in the last two weeks, four British Ministers have visited Kuwait with businessmen-and women, no doubt-as part of a trade delegation. That is just to take the example of one country, Britain, which is making an enormous effort to get contracts there and is already securing contracts. As I said earlier, so far we have secured no contracts. If we are really serious about getting some of the business in Kuwait-the business that is available; perhaps there is not as much as people sometimes think-we will have to make a much grander effort than unfortunately as a country we are already making.

Let me also add that in this country we think that because we participated with 27 other countries in asserting the United Nations sanctions, and also with some countries in Operation Desert Storm, that that would give us automatic access to those contracts. I can assure the House that that is not so. When I was in Japan recently, the Japanese were telling me that they did not believe they would get any contracts at all except where they might be providing services or goods, which they had the unique capacity to provide. The point is that Japan did not provide anything except money. They did not send any military forces whatsoever to assist, but they did underline the point that the countries that had sent ground troops in Operation Desert Storm were the countries that would get the major contracts-obviously the United States, close behind it the United Kingdom, maybe France as well and, beyond that, possibly Canada.

It is worth our while understanding that it will be very difficult for us to get some of this business because despite the very valiant and professional effort put in by our Navy in Operation Desert Storm, it is a fact that, for political reasons, we sent no additional forces and, for military reasons, would not have been able to even if we wanted to. Therefore, we do not have the capacity to get the business in the post-war reconstruction that would otherwise have been the case.

The third point in relation to the Gulf war issue that I want to mention is the post-Gulf war arrangements themselves. During the Gulf war, the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, Senator Hill, and I, as shadow Minister for trade, talked about the need for Australia to be prepared for the post-war reconstruction process-in the case of Senator Hill in a political sense and in my case in a commercial sense. The response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) to our assertions that we should be doing more to prepare for the post-war environment was that we were premature. We did not know that the Gulf war would finish so quickly and so successfully, nor did Senator Evans. But it has to be said-I think history shows that we were not premature-we were right to be trying to encourage the Australian Government to take up many of those important issues as quickly as possible.

I want to refer to the issue of wheat. We said during the Gulf war that Australia should negotiate with the United States to ensure that in the post-Gulf war environment Australia does not get wiped out of the Iraqi wheat market which used to take 10 per cent of our wheat exports before the Gulf war by the United States export subsidies or by dumping from the European Community. This passionate plea on our part for the Australian Government to talk to the United States about that contingency was ignored until much later, after the war, the Australian Government accepted the proposal of this side of the House that we should send a bipartisan trade mission to Washington to discuss the wheat issue in general. While we were in Washington-I was a member of that delegation-we were able to take up this issue, but very late. I think that if we had taken it up during the war our representations would have been substantially more effective.

In the context of this issue of post-war arrangements, the focus of the international community is, without doubt today, on the plight of the Kurds. In conclusion, I want to say a little about that. Before I do so, I would like to quote to the House a report which appeared the other day. I think it highlights the quite terrible situation that is now taking place. I remind the House that approximately 1,000 Kurds a day are believed to be dying and approximately two million Kurds would now have the status of refugees. Many of them are on the Iraq-Iran border and a smaller number on the Iran-Turkish border.
I thought that this quote was rather heart-rending. In the few minutes left to me it might be appropriate for the House to be reminded of it. It states:
Six small bodies of Iraqi refugee children, wrapped in muddy wet towels, lay in the mosque of this border village today.
They had perished of cold at a makeshift camp overflowing with families who fled Iraq in terror of Saddam Hussein and who are now fighting to survive freezing rain and hunger.

``Kill me,'' shouted Ihsan, a middle-aged Iraqi jostling with a soldier trying to push back crowds fighting for bread. ``Drop a chemical bomb on us. It is better than dying slowly like this.'' Two other bodies lay beside the dead children in the mosque-a man of 40 who died of exposure and a girl of 18.

There are many other stories such as that which we see on our television screens and would have seen this very night on our television screens. It should be a matter-I am sure it is-of great concern to this House that that situation should have occurred. Nevertheless, I think many people predicted that after the Gulf war, should Saddam Hussein have remained in power, this was likely to happen. Some people argue-General Schwarzkopf apparently did-that the United States should have, as they would put it, finished the job and continued to send American troops right up to Baghdad presumably to deal appropriately with President Saddam Hussein, but in any case ensure that he left the position of the presidency of that country and then there could be completely new arrangements made for Iraq. The trouble with that proposal, though-I do take the side in this issue of President Bush and Prime Minister Major of the United Kingdom-is that to do so would simply have been contrary both to international law and the United Nations resolutions.

It would have been much better if Australia had taken the lead-or had perhaps encouraged other bigger and more powerful countries to help us take the lead-to ensure two things in the postwar wash-up: firstly, that the cease-fire did not allow the Iraqi Government to use military helicopters in the way it has done, because there was a ban on the Iraqis using military aircraft of the normal and conventional type but not on their using military helicopters, which, above all, have been used to destroy the livelihood of the Kurds; and secondly, that the United Nations cease-fire resolution included a guarantee for the Kurds and a guarantee that their claims would be properly recognised and considered by the Government of Iraq. It is a matter of great personal regret to me that the United States and Britain-and also, let us not forget, Australia-did not take the opportunity to make that addition to the cease-fire resolution of the United Nations.

There was much joy when the cease-fire resolution passed through the Security Council. Subsequently, it was accepted in toto by the Iraqi Government. I am not sure whether that means anything, but at least in theory, legally it does. However, it was a tragedy that no guarantee was written into that cease-fire for the Kurdish people. Through these Appropriation Bills this country is providing financial support of $1m specifically to the Kurds, and in this Bill it is providing a total of $5m for humanitarian aid.

It is very sad that we did so little to ensure that the cease-fire resolution did something for the Kurds.
