When Senator Hill asked Senator Gareth Evans on 9 April whether Australia would consider that, Senator Evans simply shrugged his shoulders metaphorically and said there was little the Australian Government could do in the United Nations. It would have been nice at least to have tried, would it not? If we had, Australia would at least have had the pride of knowing that as a country we had tried to do something for the Kurds. It is disappointing that a Labor Government, which claims to be so compassionate, did so little when presented with that opportunity to do something for the Kurds.

In conclusion, I repeat that I am glad that two naval officers from the highly professional Australian contribution to Operation Desert Storm are in the gallery for this debate; it is appropriate that they be here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's future prosperity depends heavily on our ability to lift our international trading performance. Arriving at this diagnosis is relatively simple; achieving the necessary improvement in the performance of our economy, however, is something else again. It demands a massive and sustained effort across all sectors of our economy and our community. A wide range of ingredients is necessary. There is a need for business leaders to critically assess where the genuine opportunities for Australia lie; there is a need for management to be more skilful and innovative; there is a need for labour to be increasingly flexible and committed to the success of enterprises; and there is a need for a government to create the right preconditions and do all it can to eliminate the roadblocks to greater efficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most vital areas in improving our trade potential is the waterfront industry. The Government recognises that Australia's trading performance is determined not only by the price and quality of our products, but also by the performance of those sectors of the economy concerned with their delivery. It is for this reason that the productivity, efficiency and reliability improvements on the waterfront continue to be a major government priority. There has been much public comment in recent times about the level of progress in this key area of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda. There has also been much public speculation about the merits of pursuing reform through a negotiated consensus approach. There has been singularly little public discussion about any credible alternatives to the Government's strategy, apart from the celebrated comment made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to use troops on the wharves as a `last resort'. He did not bother to describe what would be the Opposition's first resort to improve waterfront performance.

The complete paucity of the Opposition's policy was revealed by the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), in a recent speech to the shipping industry. When asked whether the Opposition would have the guts to get stuck into the waterfront, in line with the Opposition's confrontationist rhetoric, he said:
I don't know. George Bush said `read my lips' and he backed down. I can only say you're going to have to either trust people or keep voting labour.

That just about sums up the policy of the Opposition: `Just trust us, but be aware we will use troops in a brawl on the waterfront if it all gets too hard for us'. That really defines the difference between the Government's negotiated consensus approach, which is quietly achieving real and sustained productivity improvements, and the headline-grabbing `troops on the wharves' approach.

The Government's waterfront reform program is 15 months into a three-year timetable, which provides for comprehensive reform across all aspects of the waterfront. It is based on the recommendations of an extensive two-year inquiry by the Inter-State Commission into the whole waterfront industry. At the time of their release in April 1989, considerable support for the findings existed among relevant interest groups. Even the shadow Minister for shipping, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), described the report in October last year as containing:
. . . a range of very sensible recommendations . . .
and:
a package of reforms that . . . were worth implementing and would deliver real and achievable gains for the Australian economy.
Despite the gloomy forecasts of all the doomsayers who want the Government's program to fail, waterfront reform is gaining momentum.

The movement to company based employment for stevedoring employees at major ports is well under way. The first enterprise agreement is currently being implemented at the two largest container terminals in Sydney and Melbourne, which are operated by National Terminals (Australia) Ltd. This agreement will result in a 34 per cent reduction in National Terminals' work force, with the exit of 460 employees by mid-year; some 350 employees left the company last month. This, together with the company's $60m investment program in more modern equipment and new computer systems, guarantees improved efficiency and customer services.

Other enterprise agreements are completed or nearing finalisation. The Union Steam Ship Company of Australia Pty Ltd recently forwarded agreements covering its terminals in Melbourne, Sydney and Hobart to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) for assessment. The Authority is responsible for overseeing stevedoring reforms and must approve each enterprise agreement as meeting the Government's productivity targets before releasing any funding under the program's redundancy scheme.

Following the recent breakthrough in the Industrial Relations Commission, the agreement of Conaust Pty Ltd for its CTAL container terminal in Sydney is being finalised. This will open the way for other Conaust agreements to be concluded, covering nearly half the stevedoring labour force in major ports around Australia. These include Adelaide, Sydney, Melbourne, Fremantle, Darwin and Brisbane.

A program for negotiation of revised employment arrangements for regional ports is also under way. Supporting these changes is the development of a new stevedoring industry award, which aims to consolidate some 20 awards and agreements covering stevedoring work and includes a new skills based classification structure. Union rationalisation on the waterfront is being pursued under the auspices of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). It initially involved the formation of a federation of seagoing and stevedoring unions, which will receive recognition as the principal union in the port authority area as well.

Already in a number of areas unions with a small membership representation on the waterfront have agreed to withdraw coverage in line with the ACTU rationalisation policy. The Opposition has been spreading the story that the Conaust agreement was progressed outside the Government's reform program because of the involvement of the Industrial Relations Commission. In fact, the in-principle agreement covering the stevedoring reforms specifically provides for the Commission to be involved in resolving any impasse between the parties in implementing the reform program. The Commission expressly recognised the relationship between its role and the functions of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority in its statement in the Conaust case.

Another furphy being spread about the reform program is that it is only producing a 30 per cent increase in productivity. Admittedly, the program aims at a net reduction of 2,000 employees in the stevedoring work force. This represents a 30 per cent increase in labour productivity. However, the basic structural and attitudinal changes flowing from this program, not only on the part of the work force but, more importantly, new management approaches, will produce substantial additional rises in productivity.

The national terminals agreement aims at productivity improvements in cargo handling of up to 60 per cent, which will put its facilities on a par with highly regarded terminals in Europe and North America. Reforms negotiated by the waterfront authority for the stevedoring of grain have produced reductions in labour requirements of between 50 and 80 per cent. The Australian Wheat Board recently estimated these reforms are saving the grain industry more than $5m per annum.

It is interesting to note the recent comments of the Assistant General Manager of the Australian Wheat Board, Mr Tom Pile, about the success of the grain reforms under the Government's program. He said:
I think we've got a result that is faster in terms of the whole of Australia than could have been achieved by confrontation.
When asked whether a more confrontationist style should be adopted by the Government, Mr Pile replied:

I think the answer really is that it does take time. You can't sit behind a desk somewhere and make a decision on what the work practice arrangements might or should be, what the manning levels might or should be, without actually physically going out and looking at the job being done.
How very true. Mr Pile was also asked whether reform should be quicker, as claimed by the Opposition. He answered:
I think there's a lot of people who have got it wrong, and I think there's a lot of people that are not actually trying to work within the process.

I think there's a lot of people who are making a lot of noise. I've heard people too that jump up and shout and scream and say this is doing nothing for me. The question really is what are they doing to get involved in the process? Very often, its nothing.

The Government's reform program involves the comprehensive restructuring of all aspects of the waterfront and not just the stevedoring sector. Of course, the wharfies present an easy target and, if we believe the Opposition, they should get all the blame for our waterfront ills.

However, there are significant areas of our ports which fall within the direct responsibility of State governments-namely, the operation of port authorities and associated port services. Port authorities employ around 7,000 people and have annual revenues of about $800m, which is of the same order as the much maligned stevedoring sector.

Under the reform program, the State and Northern Territory governments have agreed to promotion of measures to enhance port efficiency. These include establishment of appropriate corporate charters, setting financial targets, ensuring high level expertise on port boards, introducing user-pays pricing to encourage more efficient use of resources, and reviewing leasing and licensing arrangements to maximise competition.

Another important area requiring review is the interface between waterfront and land transport. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, under the chairmanship of my friend the honourable member for Shortland (Peter Morris)-who is probably one of the most able members of parliament-is undertaking an inquiry into the appropriateness, efficiency and performance of the links between ports and land transport. An area that the Committee has already identified is the need for rapid development of electronic data interchange (EDI) technology. The reform program actively pursues advancement of EDI which promises savings in the range of 3.5 to 5 per cent of transport costs, or some $100m to $200m.

The Government does not regard the waterfront reform program as an end in itself. The program is being pursued because of its importance in ensuring Australia's ability to be an effective, reliable supplier to world markets. We have taken a consultative rather than a confrontationist approach, working with the industry parties rather than against them. This is the only way that long term, sustained productivity improvement will be achieved.

Nothing could be more destructive to the growth of this new productive culture than a period of massive industrial disruption cultivated by a confrontationist government. This would just rekindle all the old divisions and prejudices of the past. The resulting reforms would never be as significant as those achieved through the consensus approach.

The whole thrust of the reform strategy has been the negotiation and implementation of enterprise agreements. Notwithstanding media commentary to the contrary, any objective assessment would conclude that the agreement negotiations are progressing well.

I would like to acknowledge the positive role that the Waterside Workers Federation has played under the stewardship of its very able and competent secretary, Tas Bull, in working towards a responsible, integrated port labour force agreement. Over a number of years I have had a keen interest in the developments and changes that have taken place, not only on the waterfront, but with the seagoing unions as well.

It may interest honourable members to know that in 1958 there were 26,000 registered waterside workers. Today there are 4,600 registered workers and another 1,600 members, such as shipping clerks and tradesmen, which brings a total of 6,200 workers into the industry. This has been a dramatic decline on the waterfront, and of course it further highlights the Herculean task Tas Bull and his union officials have had in selling changes to their constituencies. Surely the positive actions of Tas Bull and his officials deserve to be praised for their contribution, and we on this side of the House do so unreservedly. It is sad indeed that those opposite do not give that acknowledgment, but revel in the falsehood that the economic difficulties of this country are all the fault of the waterfront. What hypocrisy!

There is no doubt in my mind that in Australia both the Waterside Workers Federation and the Seamens Union of Australia have led the way, particularly in the transport industry reforms, in positive structural reforms within their industries. It is indeed a pity that in other sections of the transport industry the same effective, capable, visionary leadership as shown by Tas Bull of the Waterside Workers Federation and by Pat Geraghty of the Seamens Union is not also there in other unions in the transport industry. We on this side of the House do acknowledge the tremendous work that Pat Geraghty and Tas Bull have done for reform in the transport industry, and I think we in Australia-particularly we in the Government-owe a lot to those two gentlemen and the unions they represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make some comments on the 3 cognate Bills before us this evening-Appropriation Bill (No.4), Appropriation Bill (No.5) and Appropriation Bill (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2)-I would like to add my welcome to our naval visitors. They have probably left the gallery now, but I would also like to welcome them, and to make mention, of course, of the arrival in Brisbane City tomorrow of the DDG HMAS Brisbane and the FFG HMAS Sydney on their way back from the Gulf. I am sure all of us in this House bid them a very kind welcome home, and I am sure their families are looking forward to seeing them when they berth in Brisbane River tomorrow morning.

SPEECH.PARA: May I also say, first of all, to the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), before he leaves the chamber, that I cannot let the occasion go without making one comment about what he had to say, and that was particularly in relation to the reported use of Defence Force personnel on the waterfront, which was recently reported as a point that our Opposition Leader (Dr Hewson) made.

I say to the honourable member that it is yet again an example of very, very selective reporting. We have to look at what the Leader of the Opposition was saying to understand its import in relation to micro-economic reform on the waterfront. I refer to one or two points the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) made, I think very reasonably, including the question of stretch in the Australian Defence Force. That is something that I and others have commented upon in this place on many occasions over the past few years. I have often commented that we continue in this country to have defence very much on the cheap, and I do not resile from that comment. I have seen nothing in this place in the last three years, and of course in my 30-odd years as a serving naval officer, to make me change that view.

This evening I want to concentrate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and, in particular, the defence aspects of that Bill, and then to say a little about defence policy generally, with particular reference to today's media reports attributed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray and, quite properly in my view, well commented upon on this evening's television by the shadow Minister for defence science and personnel, Senator Newman.

What then does Appropriation Bill (No. 4) refer to in relation to the Defence portfolio. As the honourable member for Mayo said, firstly it includes $32.2m for running costs, reflecting costs associated with the Gulf deployment, approved civilian and service salary increases and increases in certain allowances for Defence Force personnel. That, added to the $52.7m covered in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) only very recently, comes close to the forecasts of the Ministers in both places of around $100m per annum for our Gulf commitment. I say to both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) that the Opposition will be watching future developments to see whether that prediction is close or is a fact.

The second aspect of that increased expenditure is $6.8m for defence housing, reflecting an increase in the capital subvention to the Defence Housing Authority as part of the Government's commitment to spend $750m on defence housing over 10 years. As the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) said yesterday, the Opposition supports a general improvement in standards for Defence Force personal. In my view, the Defence Housing Authority is doing a very good job in raising those standards, in getting Defence Force personnel out of the ghetto conditions-that would not be too strong a word-that many of them have experienced over a number of years and, in the main, back into the general community.

The third element is $29.6m for defence facilities, attributable to greater activity levels due to economic conditions and price increases. That does not mean anything to me. I say to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), who is at the table, that hopefully the Defence Minister can explain that expenditure in a little more detail. Nothing I can find explains it to the extent that I think it should be explained in the Parliament.

Finally, we find a very large amount of $206.3m, which largely reflects adjustments for price movements and variations in progress on a number of projects, including payments for Anzac ships and the submarine refit. Once again, I do not know what that means. Indeed, I would suggest that nobody in this place does at the moment. Again I ask that we be given a little more explanation as to what that means. All of this, including offsets provided from increased revenues and a reduction in the provision for contingent salary and related increases, means a total defence outlay increase of $181m. That in itself is a substantial amount of money.

All of this is coming before us this evening in a climate of increasing confusion on defence matters, not only in this parliamentary arena but up there on Russell Hill. In my view, the basic problem is fairly and squarely back with the responsible Ministers. There is a very serious lack of ministerial leadership up there on the Hill. Whilst it is very easy for us to be critical of the present incumbents, Senator Ray and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, one has to look further back than that to what has been referred to in the report I read today as the persistent shadow of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) pervading the corridors of Russell Hill. I think there is some essence of truth in that, and I quote from an article in today's Australian by Tony Parkinson headed `General cutbacks the order of the day'. I shall read a very short segment of what he had to say because I think it is relevant and quite accurate. Referring to Senator Ray, he said:
It is just over a year since he took on the job, and he is still suffering by comparison.
He goes on to say:

It is no easy thing to compete with a legend. Beazley, who combined a long-standing and fervent interest in military matters with a ready ability to engage support and enthusiasm among the services (partly a result of his capacity to persuade Cabinet to bankroll a massive arms procurement program) still gets the vote of many a military man as the best defence minister since Federation.

That is a very arguable point. Nevertheless, I think it is a very persuasive argument for the basic problem that exists up there on Russell Hill and, as a result, in these parliamentary corridors. In my experience, the Minister for Transport and Communications, the previous Minister for Defence, is an intelligent man. He has a very good comprehension of the national security strategy and other matters such as that. He obviously has the ability to compete in Cabinet when it comes particularly to large capital acquisition projects. He also understands, I think, the need for the defence programs to support our industrial infrastructure needs. One cannot really argue with the strategic need enunciated in the two-ocean navy posture.

What I would say to him, in all honesty, is that his approach in Russell Hill still lingers on and, as a result, they suffer in a number of areas. First of all, I think his administrative ability in terms of detail was questionable. He arguably very much forgot about people. We saw his overseeing of some of the largest resignation rates and departures from the service on record.

Finally, I say in all seriousness that he, in my view, politicised Russell Hill to an unparalleled degree. In fact, as many in this place would know, I was a long-serving senior naval officer, and I have to say to the House that one of the major reasons that I resigned, and perhaps one of the ideological reasons that I sit on this side of the House after winning the seat, is that I could not sit up there and watch that politicisation process take place to the extent that it did. It still goes on, and not only does it go on in the civilian bureaucracy-and many of those people know exactly whom I am talking about-but, I have to say very regrettably, politics and political pressures have been brought to bear in the uniformed area. I am not going to name names, but I think one or two senior officers sitting up there at the moment know exactly what I am talking about and are sitting there in many ways as a result of the pressures and the personal influence that the previous Minister for Defence had on Russell Hill.

Senator Robert Ray, on the other hand, in my experience, is an intelligent man. He is a good public communicator, as he showed in the Gulf conflict. Of course, that was a day-to-day requirement that he had, a very pragmatic requirement. His role at that time required very little practical understanding of deep strategy, and I have to say to Senator Robert Ray that he did it very well. But I think-and again I go back to Tony Parkinson's article-that the time has arrived when that day-to-day understanding of what was going on in the Gulf is not enough, and that the Minister will have to come to grips in the next few weeks and months with some very large reviews, two very large reviews in particular. Again I quote from what Tony Parkinson said about Senator Robert Ray. He said:

. . . in the coming weeks, Ray may well answer some of the criticisms. He now has in his grasp two important defence reviews which, in several respects, could result in reforms as fundamental-and more far-reaching at the practical level-than those achieved during the Beazley years.

The reviews-one into the structure of the defence forces, the second into how savings can be achieved by contracting out defence support work-will go to Cabinet late next month. Ray will then deliver a statement to Parliament, probably on June 6.

A lot of that lack of in-depth knowledge by the present Minister for Defence he is attempting, in my view, to make up with selective media briefings indicative in this sort of reporting. I have to ask the House and the Ministers whether this is all part of the softening up process simply because both Ministers perhaps do not understand exactly what faces them over the next weeks and months and, in particular, the implications of a strategic review. As the honourable member for Mayo has said, we on this side of the House, as a result of yet another initiative by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), are taking up the challenge. We are putting defence very much back on the political agenda and, unlike the present Ministers and, indeed, Mr Beazley, we do not see this particular document here, the White Paper entitled Defence of Australia 1987, as any sort of tablet of stone. In fact, it is there to be queried and, indeed, the Opposition defence strategy review group will be doing just that.

In the article by Tony Parkinson, again, there is a report that all of the changes that are reported to be about to take place, unspecified-although, it would seem from leaks, very extensive-will be achieved without a fairly basic reassessment of strategic planning, and I fail to see how that can be done. In fact, Senator Ray is quoted as insisting that there will be no rewriting of the 1987 White Paper. Indeed, I have just been skimming the record of Estimates Committee B in the Senate two days ago and implicit and explicit in that evidence before the Committee is an indication that that will be the case. One particular point offended me and I feel sure that it will offend a lot of the very professional military people up there on Russell Hill. Let me just quote one thing that Senator Ray said in response to a question from Senator Durack. Senator Durack asked him:

For instance, Air Vice-Marshall Fennel made a statement just before the air power conference expressing his concern about the capacity of the Air Force to know what is going on and take steps in the air-sea gap, for instance.
Senator Robert Ray went on and said:

I draw a distinction between a chief going out and calling a press conference for that purpose and, having called one for another purpose, answering questions on that. I see a different set of circumstances.
That in itself is reasonably innocuous. Then Senator Durack asked yet another question:

I really just want to find out what the position is. For instance, if one of the service chiefs were called upon to give an address, apart from giving evidence to an inquiry-you have answered that question for Senator Newman-on matters of major importance to Australian defence, that would be quite an appropriate occasion when they could speak frankly and freely, within the limits of security, of course. You have no objection to that?
Senator Robert Ray said:

We have no objection. We have encouraged that process. The last thing we want to develop in the top echelon of the military are just simply puppets of Government. There is a degree of intellectualism there that often surprises me and I like them to exhibit it.
I think that is an affront to the professionalism of military personnel on Russell Hill and throughout the country.

As I said before, the Opposition will be carrying out and is carrying out this defence strategic review. In the very short time remaining to me, can I just suggest to the House some of the things that need to be looked at. What needs to be looked at in that review is what the White Paper talks about-the area of strategic importance. That area clearly at the moment excludes some very major land masses, such as the Indian subcontinent, which in my view and many people's views should be included within such an area of strategic importance. We need to look at the area of direct military importance. We need to consider the budgetary situation, bearing in mind that this Government promised defence expenditure between 2.6 per cent and 3 per cent of gross domestic product-and what do we have in this current financial year but expenditure at 2.3 per cent of GDP or the lowest expenditure level in 40 years. Finally, we need to think very carefully about self-reliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4), Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), I want to address my remarks this evening to a range of industry activities but, to begin with, the shipbuilding industry. Last Saturday morning at Carrington Slipways at Tomago in the Hunter, the last vessel begun by the former Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd was launched. That vessel is the Searoad Tamar, which was being built by Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd for the Australian National Line (ANL). That day was a day of great pride. It was early in the morning at the top of the tide, a rather misty morning, but it was a day of great pride and a day of sorrow for the employees whose jobs will terminate with the completion of that vessel in about two months time, in June, when the vessel will be commissioned.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly this evening I want to say how proud I am of the men and women who have worked at Carrington Slipways-for their skills, dedication and achievement. I want to congratulate them on the fine vessels that they have built at that yard over the years, ranging from fishing trawlers, offshore vessels, tugs, the HMAS Tobruk and to this latest vessel, the ANL vessel, Searoad Tamar, which will provide a container service across Bass Strait.

That morning, as I said, was a very sad morning. On 21 December last year the Commonwealth Bank, as mortgagee, was invited by the management of Carrington Slipways to take possession of the yard. The yard had reached a state of insolvency and the management invited the Commonwealth Bank to take over. The problems with that yard did not begin in December. The fundamental problem has been the same problem of shipbuilding around Australia-that is, it is either a feast or a famine; there are gaps between orders. It is related to the sparsity of orders and the scarcity of orders for the shipbuilding industry generally that has led to the problems that Carrington Slipways have had over recent years.

In more immediate periods, the business suffered a serious loss on the construction of the Aurora Australis, not necessarily of its own actions, but originally beginning from losses incurred and delays when the company that was to carry out the design work on the vessel and whose use was specified in the original contract from P and O-the company was Wartsila of Finland, a world renowned firm in ship design-went into liquidation shortly after the contract was let to Carrington. The work that had been performed by Wartsila was inadequate and inappropriate. It had to be done again by Carrington. Carrington had to recruit the design skills to carry through the design completion and, ultimately, the completion of the vessel. In the process, the company incurred a substantial loss.

Towards the end of 1989 the company, through earlier borrowings and through pressure, came into a critical period when it sought with greater effort to find orders overseas. In July last year there were very high expectations that the company, in association with TNT Ltd, would be contracted to build four of the high technology wave piercing catamarans for use on the Yugoslav coast. That seemed to be at the stage where the order was going to be formally signed, always by next week. The company maintained its work force and maintained its skills in strong expectation of that order materialising. The fact is that it did not. One can look to Yugoslavia and the political instability of that country to understand why. One can understand also why the management maintained its work force in the expectation of receiving that order. That order was going to be a breakthrough into the substantial world market for wave piercing catamarans.

Later in the year the prospect arose of being able to build four Lady Hawkesbury class ferries for the Bangladesh Port Authority. Similarly, that dragged out and ultimately export assistance which was being provided in respect of both of those projects ceased. But in the case of the Bangladesh project conditions were set by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation that the company ultimately was unable to meet. So that order did not materialise. Again, the work force was kept together in expectation of one or both of those orders materialising. The fact is they did not. There were no other orders available in the near future that would enable the company to carry on. As I said at the outset, on 21 December last year the company invited the Commonwealth Bank to take possession of the business as the mortgagee in possession.

I am sad to have to raise this. Last evening in the other place Senator Tierney, a newly elected Liberal Senator for New South Wales, who is based in Newcastle, took considerable delight in lambasting this Government for what he tried to argue was its responsibility, as he saw it, for not salvaging Carrington Slipways. I want to go quickly through his speech, as reported in Hansard-that is the most accurate way to deal with it-and point out the basic inaccuracies of what he was saying. It is very clear from his speech that he did not know what he was talking about. He could not miss the opportunity to lambast Newcastle and the Hunter and attempt to lambast this Government. On page 2657 of yesterday's Senate Hansard he said there would appear to be a question mark over the persistence of the Royal Australian Navy with the Krupp sonar system that was to be fitted to the minehunters begun by Carrington Slipways in 1983. That is true. That is about the only thing in his speech that was true.

The sonar system was a dud. It finally resulted in the program of minehunters, originally expected to be six, to be curtailed at two. Navy has a case to answer for that. I have no doubt that at some later stage whatever happened in respect of that sonar system will be explored by others. In the meantime, my understanding is Krupp is still working on a system that will be effective in the Southern Hemisphere with different water densities, higher temperatures and a different seabed formation. When that sonar system is perfected we might look forward to a reinvitation of tenders for the minehunters. Senator Tierney made the statement:
If the faulty system had not fouled up the minehunter project, the project would have gone ahead for the other six minehunters that were originally planned and Carrington would still be operating.

That is sheer nonsense. The minehunters were being built in the fibreglass facility nearby to Carrington Slipways. It is not a part of the Carrington shipyard. It was to employ at most some 60 people in the construction of the minehunters. That facility, which is really owned by the Department of Defence, was already in mothballs. There is only a handful of people there minding that facility, waiting to see what happens with the sonar. That is wrong. On the same page Senator Tierney went on to say:
There was no doubt that Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) was offering the cheapest ship . . .
He went on to say:
. . . the contract was finally awarded to AMECON, but with the promise that some of the work would be contracted interstate, and especially to Carrington Slipways.
The undertaking and expectation of AMECON-restated by the Government-was that some $700m worth of Anzac frigate work would go to Newcastle, to the Hunter region. He then said:
Since that day not a single piece of work has come to Carrington or, for that matter, to any other shipyards in the Hunter.
It is coincidental that the same day he made his speech the announcement was made that Comsteel in Newcastle had won a $4m contract for the Anzac frigates. The story reads:
The Commonwealth steel company, Waratahs, won a $4m ten-year contract to provide part of the propulsion system for the 10 Anzac frigates.

That story is under the byline of Norm Skellams and Tim Isles, staff reporters of the Newcastle Herald. That made a mockery of the honourable senator's remarks that no work had gone to the Hunter. More than that, the tenders for the construction of the five hulls that are expected to be built in the Hunter, for their assembly and partial testing in Newcastle, have not yet been called. They are yet to be called. The program is more or less still on time, as was announced at the outset. In time, those tenders will be called and the opportunity will be there for Hunter firms to tender for the work that is likely to come up. Senator Tierney said in his speech:

. . . I point out that the awarding of the Anzac frigate project to AMECON will create work for the Williamstown dockyard in Melbourne for more than 15 years. In December 1990 the only major subcontracts let by AMECON were for the hull and superstructure units by its subsidiary, Eglo, in Newcastle and Adelaide.

The fact is that the work being done on the frigate contract in Newcastle at the moment is for the FFG class frigates. The vessel for which the sections are being built by Eglo in Newcastle is the HMAS Newcastle. It is not part of the Anzac frigate contract. How little does this new honourable senator really understand? He is plain wrong, but it did not prevent him taking the opportunity to lambast the Hunter and to lambast AMECON and all those associated with it. On the next page he says:

There was hardly any inducement to investors to become involved in the yard when their return was equivalent to leaving money in the bank. There is a real need for inducements for investment in this country in high-risk projects with the enormous potential of Carrington Slipways.

The Federal Government, through shipbuilding bounty, has paid some $50m to Carrington Slipways over the past five years, some $28m of that in the last two years. Far from being a case where there was not any inducement to investors, this was a case where there was a considerable investment by taxpayers in the work being done in that yard. Unless the honourable senator wants to say that another $50m ought to be appropriated, and the Opposition cares to move in that respect, let us again expose the nonsense that this new senator is speaking. He went on to ask:
Did the Federal Government offer any last-minute reprieve for Carrington?

He referred to the remarks-which I thought were splendid remarks and gave excellent recognition to the role of Carrington workers at the yard-by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), whose wife launched the vessel last Saturday morning. The senator stated:
The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) uttered a pious wish for a buyer for the shipyard, but he ruled out any assistance from the Federal Government.

The Federal Government and we, as local members-unlike the honourable senator-have been working with the trade unions, the Lord Mayor of Newcastle, community and industry organisations and other companies to interest a successor to Carrington Slipways in purchasing that yard. As I said, the Federal Government has already spent $50m in shipbuilding bounty on the yard. What we have tried to do is to encourage firms, but no government can compel a business to buy a business it does not want to buy.

The brick wall that all of us have come up against is that no company wants to buy a shipyard with 400 employees and an empty order book. There are a number of substantial firms interested in acquiring the yard and its equipment. It has excellent equipment. It has an excellent team of shipbuilders-a team of men and women of all skills. But it wants to reorganise and try to build up a better prospect of orders before investment takes place. It is my confident expectation that at a later stage there will be a successor to Carrington. We in the Hunter want that successor to Carrington there so that successor can tender for the Anzac frigate work when it is called.
The senator asked the very foul question in the Senate yesterday:
Who in Canberra influenced the decision of the Commonwealth Bank to pull the plug on Carrington Slipways when the yard had assets in excess of $20m?

I say to the House that again the honourable senator does not know what he is talking about. It is a foul accusation and a reflection on the management of the Commonwealth Bank. The Commonwealth Bank was invited by the management of the company to take possession on 21 December. It did not intrude; it was invited by the management. So again the honourable senator ought to put his brain into gear before he opens his mouth.

When the Anzac frigate contracts were being let and there was a concerted campaign from Victorian members in support of AMECON to win the lead contract, the Federal Opposition was mute on the Hunter. It was mute on the Australian Warships Systems tendering against AMECON. Not a word was heard until almost the eleventh hour when former Senator Peter Baume happened to blow into the area saying, `The Anzac contract ought to go to the Hunter'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I lobbied the Minister in good faith.

—We have flushed one out. Welcome! It would have been nice to have known about it before. It is nice after the event, is it not? I thank the honourable member for Gwydir. It would have been nice to have heard from him. The honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) has drawn attention to the fact that the contribution of the New South Wales Government was to give its order for ferries to a north Queensland yard, on a minor difference in price. In net terms, after collection of payroll tax, it would have done better having that order placed in the Hunter region.

SPEECH.PARA: In late 1990 the New South Wales Government invited tenders for a further five ferries. We have heard nothing more about that. But those five ferries, as the honourable member for Newcastle has pointed out this afternoon, would be a substantial incentive to a prospective purchaser of the Carrington yard were it known that the order was to be placed with that facility. But there was not a word. The honourable senator obviously forgets, as the honourable member for Newcastle says, that the frigate tendering process was quite public.

I did not know this until the honourable member told me today, but he says in his statement that at the time after the frigate decision, the shadow spokesman for defence indicated to him that he-that is, the shadow spokesman for defence-and the Opposition would be supporting the Cabinet decision to award the contract to AMECON. He intimated to the honourable member for Newcastle that he ought to do the same thing. So it is all out in the open.

The Opposition has not supported the Hunter region. We can go through a range of issues where it has turned its back on the Hunter. So this kind of sarcastic, hypocritical grandstanding from the new senator does not do anything to lift morale in the Hunter. We will fight through. We are a region that has a tough community spirit. We lead this country in industrial relations. We lead this country in the process of industry restructuring. We lead this country in the export of coal, the manufacture of steel and the export of aluminium. We will continue to lead this country in other products as we develop. But we are not going to cop this kind of cheap grandstanding from a new Liberal senator based in the Hunter who purports to represent the people of the Hunter and purports to represent industry and investors in the Hunter.

In the minutes that remain, I want to very quickly say something about the waterfront. The Opposition has an obsession with the waterfront. After many years, it has discovered that there is a waterfront and there are some problems. Those problems on the waterfront are being addressed. It took me four years as Minister for Transport to convince people that there was a problem. Most people argued that there was not a problem. It took the Opposition even longer to recognise it. But let me say to the House this evening: the waterfront is only one kilometre in a journey that can be 1,000 to 15,000 kilometres. The waterfront is a reactor. It has problems and those problems are being addressed. It does not manufacture anything; it does not build anything; it does not create anything-it provides a service. The waterfront is very much controlled, in timetables, by those who use it.

I want to make this call to industry in this country-to exporters, to importers and to the Opposition: lift your game. The waterfront reacts to the demands made of it by others. If we can level out the peaks and congestion on the waterfront and the use to be made of its services, we can get a far greater improvement in productivity than anything else. There is more to be gained in productivity improvement from users of the waterfront than there is on the waterfront itself-desirable, speedy and essential as those users are. It is very clear to me that the users of the waterfront are living in Rip van Winkle land. They are slumbering away. They are all hiding behind the wharfie shield-`It's a wharfie. It's a wharfie. Fix him up and everything will be all right.' The wharfie has a role to play, but the users of the waterfront-importers and exporters arranging their cargoes; those who organise the services-have a much greater role to play in improving the competitiveness of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say in good faith to the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) that indeed I did lobby on behalf of the Hunter for the frigate contracts-it was early in my days in this place-and I felt particularly that they were the right frigates for the job. The Hunter Valley, including the area into the southern end of my own electorate, could have benefited from that.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to turn to the debate on the Appropriation Bills and to a particular interest and concern at this time which relates to the Commonwealth meat inspection service. I note that there is a reference to an amount of $500,000 being claimed on the basis of the need resulting from reduced payments due to an unresolved dispute concerning levels of employer liabilities for meat inspectors formerly employed by the New South Wales Government.

On Tuesday of this week the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) withdrew meat inspection services from New South Wales domestic abattoirs which had, for very understandable reasons, sought to protest against the gross inefficiency, excessive cost and amazing resistance to reform of the Commonwealth meat inspection service. The theory was that without inspection services, the abattoirs were not supposed to slaughter stock.

One abattoir at Cowra in New South Wales found itself with 180 men ready to start work and stockyards full of valuable prime cattle and sheep for slaughter. Not having access to its regular eight AQIS supplied inspectors, but being nonetheless in the happy position of being able to source two senior currently licensed inspectors-each of whom has in excess of 20 years experience, I am informed, and each of whom has been employed as teachers of trainee meat inspectors-the management of the abattoir thought it sensible to proceed with the day's kill.

So 131 head of cattle and 2,200 sheep and lambs were slaughtered and packed, the total value of the product resulting from this day's work being of the order of $200,000. On Wednesday, as I am informed, AQIS compliance staff appeared to inspect the product. They looked at the carcasses-I gather fairly cursorily-and, as I understand it, gave them a green light and commented to the effect that it appeared that the whole process had been well and satisfactorily undertaken. I understand that during the course of the day, as often is the case, three or four carcasses had been condemned by the two duly licensed and qualified inspectors who were there, but that basically there were no problems and the usual high standards of this abattoir were maintained and seen through. So, as I am informed, AQIS left the site and said, `Everything looks to be in order, but we will be in contact. Don't move until we are'. AQIS sat on the issue for 24 hours and then this afternoon rang the abattoir and told it that this very high quality, duly inspected meat was to be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —What for?

—No apparent reason. That is exactly what the abattoir management inquired about. As I understand it, in response to that perfectly reasonable question as to why, the answer was that it was unfit for human consumption.
—On what ground?

—No ground has been offered, in response to the interjection from the honourable member for Parkes. What is to become of these 131 prime quality beef carcasses and 22,000 sheep carcasses? AQIS says that they cannot go to commercial outlets. It has also said that they cannot go to charity because, in AQIS's view, the abattoir should not be allowed to divert the meat to the needy, the aged or the unemployed. So what is it required to do with this meat product? Make pet food out of it. The commercial value of this product will slip from $200,000 to $10,000.

SPEECH.PARA: I may be a trusting country boy, a little slow on the uptake and a little slow to spot a conspiracy or a rort, but I think I smell one in this case. Could it be that this bloated, inefficient, costly, inflexible body called AQIS wants to maintain the enforcement of its monopoly on the rights to provide inefficient, costly and overmanned inspection services on the meat industry? Is AQIS perhaps more interested in maintaining these costly performance inhibiting jobs than it is in reform-the sort of reform that is needed to give the industry a future and to give the people involved in it job security and to develop job security and opportunity for their children in the future?

AQIS has a long history of inefficiency and high costs in the provision of meat inspection services. The problems relate both to the bureaucracy at the top end of the service and the militant and cost inefficient delivery of services at the bottom end, at the abattoir sites. I want to document some of these problems tonight. Lest anybody becomes bored and wanders off into the night, let me say firstly that this latest unbelievable exercise by AQIS, coming as it does on the top of a boiling over of frustrations in New South Wales domestic abattoirs, must serve as the trigger for action. Action has been needed for years. This must serve as the trigger for it. Real action from the Minister this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he will bite the bullet?

—I hope he does, because it is time there was a full and independent inquiry into AQIS. It must be done as soon as possible. It must investigate the provision of inspection services, their efficiency, their reliability and their cost. It must look closely at manning levels.

SPEECH.PARA: Cowra proves what is known by everyone in this industry-that there is a need, as a matter of priority, to review manning levels in this industry. If two inspectors can adequately do the job-and I believe that they did adequately perform that task, a task normally undertaken by no fewer than eight inspectors-is there not the need to do what AQIS is plainly unable or unwilling to do, that is, to get on with the job of an effective manning review?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worse than the waterside.

—It is a junior brother to the waterside; I sometimes think the meat workers might have taught the waterfront people how to do it. AQIS is currently undertaking a review into its own operations. It is due to report to the Minister by mid-year. This is a little reminiscent of Dracula being left in charge of the blood bank. AQIS should be required to make a full submission itself to an inquiry, listing its objectives for reform, modest as they appear to be, and any impediments that AQIS is able to find under the implementation of such modest objectives. Not only that; it must be required to make a full and adequate submission of its own, not to adjudicate, as it is currently doing with the inquiry that is running at the moment.
—An independent inquiry.
—That is right. None of this is new. Nine years ago the people in the Department of Primary Industry (DPI), as AQIS was then known, said of themselves:

SPEECH.PARA: The D.P.I. inspection service has proved to be inefficient, costly, poorly managed, overstaffed and in some respects corrupt.
That comes from the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry in September 1982, page 89.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was done?

—Precious little was done. Not only did the DPI say that of itself, but the then Minister for Primary Industry, the Hon. Peter Nixon, and the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Woodward, agreed with the assessment. Except in the last matter-namely, corruption-all of the inefficiencies and standover tactics are still applicable today, especially when we compare the performance of our inspection services with those abroad. I will come back to that later; it is very interesting, not to mention embarrassing.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry was troubled enough in the old days when cost recovery was set at 50 per cent. Things got a bit worse when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) declined, presumably in response to a directive from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to move from 50 per cent cost recovery to 60 per cent in 1989. But still the industry struggled on, not wanting to run the risk of being closed down by upset and offended meat workers if they kicked up too much of a stink about the inefficiencies and the rorts that were going on. But then, despite the promises of Minister Kerin-reminiscent of wool and the reserve price scheme-that 60 per cent would be it and that there would be no further increases, last year the Treasurer, presumably, interfered again and it was declared that from 1 January 1991 the fee for service would rise to 100 per cent cost recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 66 per cent increase.

—That is about what it was. It was 68.37, just to get the maths exactly right. The industry's leadership reacted very strongly, and well it might have, because costs were to rise dramatically. As I have just told the honourable member for Parkes, they were to rise by 68.37 per cent-I hope my maths is correct; I believe it is-since abattoir operators, who had been paying previously $38,420 per year per inspector, were suddenly expected to pay no less than $64,686 a year from 1 January.

SPEECH.PARA: This is really quite amazing. Any other industry that had on-costs in excess of perhaps 30 or 40 per cent might be regarded as inefficient. But this one manages something between 100 and 130 per cent. In fact, these fellows are charged out by AQIS to processors at $64,686 per year, despite the fact that their actual gross average annual salary is in the order of only $31,795.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the vets?

—Where does the money go? Let us leave the vets alone for a moment; there is enough here to keep me busy for a moment. We will come back to the vets later. Of the total meat inspector staff of 1,654.2-this is a bureaucracy we are dealing with-1,249 are directly engaged in inspection activity at a particular time and therefore able to be directly cost recovered from industry.

SPEECH.PARA: But, interestingly, 87.8 inspectors are deemed to be surplus to requirements and it is estimated that another 155 will become surplus within the next two years; they have been removed from the charge base. That leaves 162.4 meat inspectors who cannot be directly recovered from industry; they are the people who take over on the holidays, rostered days off and so on. They are recovered by way of loading on those inspectors who can be recovered, and the cost amounts to $14,200 per inspector per annum.

Then we look at all the other costs. There are field administrative expenses. What do honourable members think they are? Are they the costs of going to have a beer in the pub? They amount to $5,432 per inspector. Superannuation is fair enough. There are Comcare premiums, leave loadings, regional office administrative expenses, and central office program administrative expenses. It goes on and on.

The industry sought consideration for reform before the fee for service was increased. That seems reasonable enough. I understand that, for example, the Country Meatworks Association of New South Wales made very strong representations to the Government last year. In November, I think, of last year it wrote to the Government in very strong terms indeed along the lines that it felt it necessary to point out that industry was being required to pay for an excessive number of meat inspectors, some of whom work four to five hours a day, sometimes less than five days a week, just as they have done for the past 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Champion card players.

—That is right. Despite constant assurances that reforms have taken place and that further reforms are continuing in terms of the number of inspectors, plus undesirable work practices, nothing is happening. The realities are to the contrary, as people in the industry have been saying for a long time. All they are getting are promises, not action. The interference by departmental officers is such that the claim is that the slowness in reform is largely due to our members' failure to introduce satisfactory quality assurance programs. That is the claim. It is always somehow the employers' fault. AQIS, it seems, cannot cope with the militancies, stoppages and unacceptable work practices of meat inspectors, and their award restructuring discussions over the past six months-or 12 months or 18 months-have achieved little in terms of reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the Government has decided to burden the industry with a total cost to employ public servants over whom they have no say in the workplace as to what work they perform, what manning levels will be employed or the initiation of any form of disciplinary action. The Government's decision to recover 100 per cent of meat inspection fees was seen by them, and should still be seen, as unfair, given that there was no effective industry consultation. It is unfair and unacceptable to hand a problem and a cost to an industry which not only is unable to absorb the extraordinary costs but is unable to do anything effective about it, especially when we remember that fee for service was sold to the meat industry on the basis of a 50:50 contribution. It was moved all the way up to 100 per cent cost recovery without any effective implementation of the promised but never delivered reforms.

Of course, nothing happened and the charges were duly introduced on 1 January of this year. Let us take a few moments to look at how inefficient we are compared with our competitors abroad. At the moment, the Minister is running around the countryside, as I understand it, saying that our charges in Australia are roughly comparable with what New Zealand processors have to pay. I have some figures that show the difference between a comparable processing works in New Zealand and one in New South Wales. They both process around 84,000 head of cattle a year. The New Zealand one, which is United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) and European Commission (EC) listed, employs a total of six inspectors-one vet, one senior inspector and four inspectors. It costs them $2.29 per head or, in Australian dollar terms, $193,148 per annum. A similar works in Australia with the same number of head of cattle processed which is USDA listed but not listed for the EC has no fewer than ten inspectors. It costs $8.70 in this particular works for inspection charges for each beast, and a total of $730,816 per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 3 1/2 times as much.

—That is right, and the Minister is claiming, as I understand it, out in the field that there is some comparability between the cost of these services in New Zealand and Australia. Maybe these figures are not as accurate as they might be, but if they are not we had better have an inquiry to find out.

SPEECH.PARA: We then move to the United States of America. That is even more interesting. I will give honourable members a bit of an idea about what happens in America. Running through some of these figures, one American abattoir slaughters 2,640 beasts weekly and has two slaughtermen on the floor. The number of carcasses inspected per inspector is 1,320. The equivalent in Australia is 385. In another example, 1,590 in America; in Australia, 200 to 233. In yet another example, 1,875 in America; 500 in Australia. We are talking about an efficiency differential of 3 : 6 against us, and we have to compete with the Americans in the Asian markets, where they are very intent on pushing us out.

The move to 100 per cent cost recovery has focused attention on these rorts and inefficiencies. That is a good thing; well it might. My abattoir in Gunnedah has had its government-imposed costs rise by $1.1m over the past 12 months, and $600,000 of that is the result of the Commonwealth meat inspection 100 per cent fee for service. It is not just a matter of overmanning. As I have indicated, work practices need looking at. First, there is lapping. In almost any chain in Australia, if there are eight meat inspectors, four will be working and four will be in the smoko room, and every so often they swap. It is not allowed for in the award.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder the farmers are broke.

—Yes, farmers do not work that way. Their holidays and rostered days off do not coincide with industry standards. The inspectors resort to militant behaviour. Somehow or other they often manage to work five or six hours a day and yet still claim one hour on overtime. The whole thing is utterly ridiculous. The boilover last week in New South Wales in the face of all this was not surprising.

SPEECH.PARA: I have corrected one of the Minister's statements. We are not by any means as efficient as other countries. Further, the Minister said that reform is under way. He cited the fact that in the past few years 600 meat inspectors have gone. He should keep in mind that many abattoirs have closed. The reality is that a survey has established that, of the 20 major abattoirs in New South Wales, none has fewer inspectors than it had 18 months ago and some have more.

Let us return to Cowra, since it is the trigger for everything I am saying tonight. I am sure that, when the community hears about this, like me it will take a lot of convincing that this is about ensuring safe, hygienic quality meat and not about preserving industrial muscle, bloated bureaucracy, inefficient rorts and jobs for the boys. Just remember: $200,000 worth of mostly prime quality meat is to be scrapped as dog food worth $10,000.

I have only touched on the myriad issues that I wanted to talk about tonight, suffice to say that there can be no excuse for avoiding a full inquiry. That full inquiry should be directed towards developing an efficient, perhaps corporatised, structure that will allow for relevant on-site employment contracts, perhaps involving a reformed AQIS, plant operators and inspectors, but nonetheless an efficient and accountable system. Now is the time for action. This Government talks about picking winners, but it seems that it cannot even get out of the way and stop obstructing the few winners we do have, let alone presume to be able to pick the winners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Appropriation Bill (No. 4)1, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). In the limited time I have available I would like to touch on a particular area of concern to my electorate. Of the $274.4m being allocated in these Appropriation Bills, of particular interest is the amount of money being allocated for natural disaster and restoration. The $75m being sought would bring the total Federal allocation for natural disaster relief for this financial year to $155m. Some $90m of this money will go to New South Wales following the widespread cyclones and flooding since March 1990 to help in the restoration of the central State and community infrastructure and to help the people who suffered personal hardship and distress during the floods, as well as many small business people and farmers. The problem of flooding has always been of great interest to me because this issue has affected my electorate for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I would like to point out that I believe that the Government should be commended for its sensitivity and its support for people who suffer as a result of natural disasters, such as those people who were caught up in the floods along eastern Australia during 1990. However, if more money was spent on effective flood mitigation programs, in many instances the disaster of flooding would not be so severe and could even be prevented.

During the debate in September 1990 on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I mentioned that one of the most important areas which needed assistance within my electorate was flood mitigation. I said then that the increase of 23 per cent for the flood mitigation program's budget for 1989-90 was not enough to overcome some of the major flooding problems in Sydney's west and particularly within my electorate. I also said that the severity of the problem in the Prospect electorate warranted a significantly increased financial commitment. I still stand by those statements today.

From the 1990-91 Budget, $450,000 was allocated to my electorate for bank stabilisation and restoration work at Lansvale, following the three major floods in Fairfield city between August 1986 and April-May 1988. The sum of $90,000 was also allocated for channel improvements in the Prospect and Orphan School creeks areas. From estimates in a flood management strategy study of the Lower Prospect Creek in May 1990, solutions to the problem faced by this area alone would cost $33m. At the level of funding my electorate is currently receiving, it will take a very long time to achieve even the most fundamental changes that are required to overcome the flooding problems within the Prospect electorate.

The catchment area of Prospect Creek is one of the largest urbanised catchments in Australia and 97 kilometres of Fairfield city falls within that area. Prospect Creek drains into the Georges River, which forms Fairfield's south-eastern boundary. Cabramatta Creek, which is another major tributary draining a large area of Liverpool city, forms the city's southern boundary. The combined effect of flooding from the Georges River and these two creeks results in serious problems for residents and businesses, particularly in the Lower Prospect Creek flood plain and the Lansvale peninsular adjacent to the Georges River.

There are many reasons why several areas within my electorate are prone to flooding, according to a presentation report by Fairfield City Council to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in December 1990. The report states:

Fairfield City is characteristically flat . . . The soils of Fairfield are primarily heavy clays which exhibit poor drainage and have a low absorption capacity. These qualities accentuate run-off and exacerbate local flooding.
Increased urbanisation and industrial development in the upper catchment areas could create additional--

(Quorum formed) I find it absolutely astounding, as the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) would realise, that he called the quorum on me when I was trying to get the concerns of my electorate into about 10 minutes. I now have less time than that but I will make sure, as was suggested to me by my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), that the people in his electorate are circulated with the concern he has for ordinary people in flood mitigation areas.

I would like to continue with one part of the report that was submitted which is urgent in my particular area. In August 1986 and April-May 1988 major flooding occurred along Prospect Creek. These floods caused serious financial losses and hardship to a large number of families and businesses. The 1986 flood caused total damage of approximately $4.8m on Prospect Creek.

In 1988 serious and extensive damage was caused as a result of the flooding of the Georges River and its tributaries at Canley Vale, Carramar and Lansvale. Almost 700 dwellings and more than 30 factories were flooded above floor level, with some homes inundated to depths exceeding two metres. Also during this flood, 550 people were rescued by the State Emergency Service. Flood levels on the Georges River were equivalent to a one-in-20 years, or 5 per cent probability flood. If it had been a one-in-100 years, or one per cent probability flood the levels would have been over a metre higher and twice as many homes and businesses would have been affected.

If a one-in-100 years flood of the Lower Prospect Creek were to occur today it is estimated that 822 properties would be inundated, some to a depth of three metres; 637 houses and 57 non residential buildings would be flooded above floor level; there would be a total potential flood damage of $15.1m; transport would be paralysed by the flooding of the Hume Highway at Lansvale; early flooding of low lying roads would occur, preventing evacuation by road for over 200 properties; and 50 home units would be flooded at Carramar where ground floor exits would be inundated by floodwater putting residents at serious risk.

Obviously, to set the minds of the residents who would be affected by such a flood at ease, and to prevent a large scale disaster if a one-in-100 years flood were to occur, it is necessary for all levels of government to address this problem immediately. Fairfield City Council, for instance, needs more money to be able to carry out its flood mitigation strategies effectively.

According to the Council, these strategies are to develop and implement a flood plain management plan to reduce the impact of mainstream flooding; control new development to minimise the impact of urban run-off into existing drainage systems; improve consultation with external authorities on proposals which may have adverse downstream implications for Fairfield city; improve public awareness on flooding issues, including emergency procedures; maintain and improve existing and new drainage systems to ensure that flooding problems are not aggravated; and ensure that the design of the flood mitigation works recognises the role of open space and takes into consideration visual impact in public places.

Two solutions to the problems of flooding which are being implemented under the Council's flood plain management strategy are the voluntary purchase and the house raising schemes, both of which require substantial funding from the State and Federal governments. The four-year rolling program for voluntary purchase was established in Fairfield in 1987. The scheme's implementation involves targeting blocks of properties in hazardous flood affected areas and demolishing them. Following the adoption of the flood plain management plan for Lower Prospect Creek in May 1990, the number of properties identified as eligible for voluntary purchase has now increased from 29 to 88. The number of properties purchased and demolished to December 1990 totals 29.

In some sections of our community this approach has been very successful, and in others it has led to less success, as some long established residents prefer to stay in their existing homes than to relocate to flood free areas. This may be because the cost and social changes involved in relocation often outweigh the flood hazard, particularly for those residents who have learned to live with flooding problems.

The subsidising of house raising is another viable flood proofing option which is being pursued in some areas. The submission for increased Commonwealth financial assistance for the New South Wales flood mitigation program for 1988-93 states:

In many of the older flood prone areas the dwellings are typically timber framed on pier foundations. These dwellings can be readily and economically raised above flood, thereby flood-proofing the dwelling without dislocating the residents and disrupting the amenity of the local area. This option is particularly attractive in flood fringe areas where flows and velocities are unlikely to cause structural damage.

According to the discussion paper entitled, `Review of Floodplain Management Practice in New South Wales', dated May 1989, the house raising scheme implemented 25 years ago has come under repeated criticism from potential users, some councils and the flood mitigation executive, because of its apparently limited availability.

Under the scheme, which was originally administered by the State Bank of New South Wales but was taken over by the State Government in January 1990, and is now administered by the New South Wales Rural Assistance Board, loans are available for up to 90 per cent of the cost of raising or relocating homes above flood level, subject to a ceiling amount of $10,000. The loans carry a maximum term of 15 years and currently have an interest rate of 8 per cent.

In the limited time that I have left I wish to say that, clearly, all the submissions that have been given to me and to many government areas combine into one thing: we can control some of the flooding problems in our area. It is clear that money is urgently needed for flood mitigation works. I believe it is important to recognise that there is a problem out there, and many people who can ill afford to change their circumstances are unnecessarily suffering time and again from floods. Although this Government has been supportive of funding for flood mitigation works, it is fast becoming obvious that if a flood disaster is to be prevented from occurring again, particularly in western Sydney, more funding from all levels of government is needed. I will continue my remarks when we resume this debate on the Appropriation Bills.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -I want to make the observation that the behaviour today of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the House sank to new depths. It is interesting to watch him performing and to observe his personal attacks, which he seems to mount from day to day on the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Those two honourable members are poles apart, not only in the opinion polls but also in their abilities, capacities and intellect and just about every measure I can imagine. I know the Leader of the Opposition does not need to me to stand up and defend him. What I want to do tonight is read a poem. I might say it is not Keats or Tennyson. It was written by Mr Kuchel, from Robina on the Gold Coast, who sent it to me. He did not name it, but I will name it `Ode to Australia':

SPEECH.PARA: Now listen you ``Australians''
Both old and new, the same.
We've got to help fix our ailing country
or we'll be held to blame.
Our fathers showed us how to do it-
They laid a very firm foundation.
And then they carefully nurtured it;
until we became a strong and proud, free nation.
The pioneers laid for us the corner-stones.
They laid them firm and strong.
We were to put the walls up
so that Australia could go on and on.
Now a terrible thing has happened.
Somehow they let a cancer in.
And, what's worse-we-
it should probably read `you'-
let it prosper.
Now that really is a sin.
(Because) no matter which way you look at it;
you'll find one plain and simple fact.--
Let no one try to kid you,
And tell you it is socialism we lacked.
They've tried that in other countries,
and they found it does not work.--
You don't breed a pack of winners
by teaching them how to shirk!
There are those in other nations
who work hard to earn their pay:
and they don't expect extra percentage
when they take their holiday.
So,``Australians'', pull together.
Let's strive for the farther shore.
``She'' certainly is not ``Right'', Mate!
Who want's ``Australia'' back once more?

That work was sent to me by Mr Trevor Kuchel of Robina on the Gold Coast. As I said, it is not Keats or Tennyson. I am told it lacks a little in terms of rhyme and metre. However, it laments, as most Australians are doing these days, the way our country has gone since 1983. It has taken a few short years to see Australia go down to the point where many people, whether through poetry or in some other way, are expressing great disappointment with what the Hawke Government has achieved.

In the time I have been here I have observed that Government members will live to regret what they have done, when they are on this side of the House. When the tables are turned in a couple of years time, we will have the opportunity to point day after day to the almost 10 years the Hawke Government was in office. I hope we do not behave in that way, but we will have the opportunity to point to everything honourable members opposite have done over the past 10 years. Just about everything they did in what will be 10 years by 1993, we will be able to say represented great failure and that during that time this country, on just about every possible score, went backwards. That is what we will say. Honourable members opposite will have to live that down in this place day after day. I thank Mr Kuchel for sending me that poetry--

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not poetry; don't make that mistake.
—I will not pass judgment on the extent to which it is poetry, but it is the words and sentiments Mr Kuchel expressed which count.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a matter that concerns me and I am sure would concern many colleagues in this chamber, yourself included, Mr Speaker. I refer to a matter that arose and was adjudicated upon in the common law division of the New South Wales Supreme Court, concerning a case involving two rugby league players, Mark Bugden of the Canterbury Bankstown Rugby League club and Steve Rogers of the Cronulla-Sutherland club.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it was a common law action taken by Rogers against Bugden. Both were professional rugby league players; the claim was for personal injury arising by assault on the field. Incidentally, it was determined by the court that negligence was not applicable; however, compensatory damages were awarded jointly against each defendant-in this case against the first defendant, Mark Bugden, and the second defendant, the Canterbury Bankstown Rugby League Club. The club was held vicariously liable for the acts of the employee-that is, Mark Bugden-and exemplary damage tests were applied.

The outcome of the case was that $68,154.60 was awarded, plus costs entered for judgment, and the costs until 9 April this year were $242,000. I might add that clearly the lawyers have been in for their chop, because for the amount of money that Steve Rogers actually got-some $68,000-they have done a lot better.
