It is not the only time that I find that lawyers act as what one might call `parasites' upon the community. In this case I find the amount of costs awarded quite appalling. Clearly justice was done, but that cost was excessive.

It is for that reason that I rise to speak on this matter. What we are now facing is a series of cases in both major codes in Australia. As the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) would be aware, there is a case in Australian rules football which involves Rodney Grinter of the Melbourne Football Club and Terry Wallace of the Footscray Football Club, in which it is alleged by Wallace that Grinter engaged in an action of assault on the field. Wallace, incidentally, is claiming $1m.

When we approached the football clubs around Australia they said, `We are not responsible, because in effect we don't authorise the player to go out and do that'. This case, however, gives the lie to that, because this case suggests that, yes, the player is authorised to go out on the field and to play the game hard, so to speak, and if an action occurs outside the rules, which in fact this case does determine, unless the club demonstrates some other way in which it no longer has responsibility for the player-that is, he has been removed from the training squad or his rights as an employee have been taken away-in fact the club is still responsible for the player. While the players remain on the club's training list or they attend and they have the potential to be selected, the club is still responsible. The club itself would have to fine the player and expel him from the list in order to remove its liability.

The consequence of this is that we could well see football clubs in both major codes-rugby league and Australian rules-made bankrupt. If one takes $300,000 out of a club like Canterbury Bankstown, that is a large amount of money. When one recognises that a club like Fitzroy, for example, is trying to rescue itself and needs a sum of, I think, $500,000-it may even be $1m-by June, one realises that these are extraordinary amounts of money. We need a way to insure against this.

I have spoken to clubs for some time about this matter. Sports people are precluded from workers compensation Acts; they were taken out because it was the view that the employers could not afford the premiums. Either they could be brought back under workers compensation, which would have to be done by State governments, or there could be, as a second possibility, a common pool insurer, such as the Government Insurance Office of New South Wales, which would offer to have a one-in, all-in policy, rather like motor vehicle insurance. Then a reduced rate premium could be offered for football clubs in exchange for cheaper ground advertising for organisations such as the GIO.

So the same would apply in the AFL as in the Rugby League, and it seems to me that if we want to obviate this possibility in the future, of clubs being bankrupted by actions like this, we need to go this way. I would conclude by saying that it would be futile for club officials to say it will not happen again. With videos now, with the capacity to have brain scans done, with people recognising that their professional careers can be at risk, the chance of a repetition of the Bugden Rogers case is quite significant. I might add, incidentally, we have also had the Malcolm Johnson case in racing. So what we have now opened up is very much a significant area of litigation in sport.

I seek leave to have a table incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The table has five columns in it. The first column shows the Vines recommendations. They are based on assumptions that we will sell 900 million kilograms of wool next year at an average greasy price of 288c per kilogram. It also acknowledges that there are 821 million kilograms in the stockpile, and that we will be borrowing at 11.75 per cent. If that is followed through, then the total levy that would need to be paid to service the debt and to have promotion, research and development et cetera, would bring the levy to about 21 per cent. Of course, that would cripple growers, so Vines has recommended that the taxpayer kick in $250m, which would bring the levy down to about 12 per cent. But even that levy would be an impost on growers, such that 25 per cent of growers could almost go to the wall.

SPEECH.PARA: We have looked again at these figures, and we have come up with the second column. By selling off $120m of the Australian Wool Corporation's assets, most of them based in Melbourne, and with the more favourable borrowing percentages that we have, the levy could come down to 14 per cent without any taxpayer input at all-without that $250m input.

Further, if we went on and not only did that, but also slaughtered 10 million sheep by continuing the program of slaughter that is in place now, we could knock another 45 million kilograms of wool, with an average cut of four and a half kilograms per sheep, out of the market next year, and still sell the 900 million kilograms that Vines says we can sell by taking 45 million kilograms from the stockpile. If we did that-which would be worth about $130m-the levy would come down from 14 per cent to 10 per cent.

Of course, in the fourth column, if we go further and knock out 20 million sheep in a wool reduction or slaughter program, that would take 90 million kilograms out of the market. It would mean that we could sell 90 million kilograms from the stockpile and still sell 900 million kilograms in total. With the $120m asset sales, it would mean-remarkably-that the levy on wool growers could come down to 5 per cent without one dollar coming from the taxpayer's pocket. That is quite remarkable indeed. There is another scenario in the final column which says that if we use some of that money to pay off $70m of the debt, the levy would be only 8 per cent.

I congratulate the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), and those others in the leadership group who worked on it, and in the primary industry committee, and in fact the coalition as a whole for what they have come up with. This is a magnificent initiative which gives growers some hope. They have all been out there trying to balance their budgets, fearful that they will have to pay at least a 12 per cent tax next year. We have to remember they will not have the supplementary payments next year, and if that is the case, as I say, 25 per cent will be in dire trouble.

But with this coalition initiative that has come forward, I hope the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will consider it very carefully because it gives great hope to the growers: it gives great hope to the wool industry. It will send a signal to buyers around the world that we mean business in this country, that the wool growers can stay viable, and that the industry has a future.

This is probably the most exciting initiative that has come out of this whole 18-month-old dreadful wool debate we have been going through where gloom and doom have been preached. If something like this is put in place, the industry can go forward and continue to contribute to Australia as it has done for the last 200 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a speech in the New South Wales Parliament on 13 March 1991, and in a press release the following day, the State Liberal member for Minchinbury, Anne Cohen, claimed that the proposed Badgerys Creek Airport in Sydney's west would be an environmental disaster resulting in air pollution, and, I quote her words, `equal to the worst American cities'. Mrs Cohen also claimed that the results of the recently released pilot air quality study for western Sydney indicated that the environmental impact study (EIS) on Badgerys Creek Airport was, in her words again, `totally flawed, out of date and lacked relevant data'.

SPEECH.PARA: The member also said that the development of Badgerys Creek Airport must not begin until an updated EIS had been produced and pollution control measures were put in place. I refute Mrs Cohen's claims and suggest that she study her facts a little better before she makes official statements such as these to State Parliament and to the media about Badgerys Creek Airport.

Mrs Cohen's claim that Badgerys Creek Airport would be an environmental disaster is totally unfounded. The air quality study done for the second Sydney Airport site selection EIS included the development of an inventory of total annual airport related emissions, both from within and outside the Badgerys Creek Airport site based on the long term, ultimate development scenario. The EIS considered the impact of airport related emissions for Sydney pollution levels, taking account of meteorological dispersion patterns to the extent that these were known at the time of the study. The EIS found that airport related emissions would not add significantly to air pollution levels, any more than would major new shopping centres, recreation centres or any other major commercial development.

As for Mrs Cohen's claims that the recent pilot air quality study showed that the EIS was flawed and out of date, they are laughable. The findings of this pilot study were consistent with those of the second Sydney Airport site selection EIS. In fact, it is likely that the study overemphasises the impact of Badgerys Creek Airport relative to future industrial development in the region.

The pilot air quality study for western Sydney was jointly funded by the State Department of Planning and the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Communications, and the study's objectives were to give an overview based on the worst possible scenario, as was the EIS, of the potential impact of proposed urban and industrial development in the region on air quality. The study found that levels of hydrocarbon emissions from airport related activities would be less than those currently generated from major urban and commercial developments in western Sydney. Levels of nitrogen oxide emissions from the airport would be comparable with those currently generated from industries such as the ACI Pilkington glassworks.

The pilot study, therefore, has not produced any evidence to suggest that the operation of Badgerys Creek Airport would result in an impact on air quality greater than anticipated in the second Sydney Airport site selection EIS. The EIS was based on predicted maximum operational levels as specified in a preliminary airport master plan, and was also based on the ultimate development scenario which would be reached only in the very long term future.

The development of Badgerys Creek Airport will proceed at a pace consistent with the anticipated growth in air traffic demand. Therefore the environmental impacts identified in the site selection EIS for a major airport at Badgerys Creek will not eventuate until well into the next century.

As for putting pollution control measures in place before going ahead with the airport, perhaps Mrs Cohen and the Liberal Government in New South Wales should talk to the Minister for Water Resources, because a total water management plan for the site has been developed in close consultation with New South Wales State agencies including the State Pollution Control Commission, the Department of Water Resources and the Water Board. This water management plan provides for specialised stormwater retention basins, pollutant traps and treatment systems to be constructed on the airport site to ensure that the quality of the water run-off conforms with the requirements of the New South Wales Clean Waters Act and the guidelines issued by the State Pollution Control Commission. These preventative measures have also been specifically designed to ensure that the flooding problem in the area will not be exacerbated by the development of the airport.

I suggest Mrs Cohen should also research the reasons why a second airport is needed at Badgerys Creek. More than 13 million passengers pass through Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport each year. The airport employs more than 19,000 people, of whom 16,000 live in the immediate vicinity of the airport, and it contributes in excess of $2,000m to the national economy each year. More than 200,000 aircraft movements occur each year at Kingsford Smith Airport, and it has now been declared as the third worst airport in the Asia-Pacific region by the International Air Transport Association. Kingsford Smith Airport is rapidly approaching crisis point and air traffic problems of congestion are already having a significant impact on our economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I bring to the notice of this House the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation, which will be debated in the Senate but not in this place. It is worthy of discussion in this place because of the effect it may have on firearms imported into Australia. The background for introducing this regulation is a meeting in 1988 of police Ministers from around Australia arising out of the Hoddle Street tragedy in Victoria. All honourable members would agree with me that something had to be done to avoid a further such tragedy in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, this regulation repeats some of the fundamental mistakes that were made in Victoria when the then Premier, Mr Cain, introduced changes to the gun laws. I believe that those laws were brought in with good intent but perhaps with some ignorance about guns on the part of members of both sides of the House. I do not claim to be an expert in this area but, coming from the land and being brought up with rifles and shotguns for most of my life, I have a basic idea of what is being spoken about.

We noticed at that stage of the debate that members who had been brought up in the city really did not know what an automatic rifle was or what a repeater was. For that reason the legislation that came forward upset many legitimate shooters in Victoria. I think that folly is being repeated in the other place with this regulation.

One of the things that should be changed, and changed quite quickly, is the provision that is made for the importation of firearms for use in recognised sporting events, with the proviso that the importer or competitor takes the firearms out of Australia in that event. It sounds simple enough, but the net effect of that is that it puts Australia's best sporting shooters at a disadvantage. They cannot have those weapons all the time and they cannot have the latest technology. I do not think anyone would suggest that they are in danger of contributing to a Hoddle Street-type tragedy. They look after their rifles very well, and they should be given all the help they can get.

The regulation changes the law from prohibiting imports of firearms to the possession of firearms. This is a fundamental change which means that anything that is not covered in this provision may well turn out to be illegal. In other words, something one owns today that it is legal to have may very well be found to be illegal under this provision. That is bad law and may well have a retrospective effect.

The other point I make relates to the arbitrary provision that only semi-automatic rifles with more than five rounds are to be prohibited absolutely. This does not take into consideration the needs of so many groups in our community in relation to special sporting events, the eradication of feral animals such as pigs, and so on. These people may not belong to a sporting body but they may have a legitimate use for a weapon of this nature. However, under this regulation they may very well find that the rifles they own today may be illegal or they may not be able to import the latest technology.

I ask the Government to look at this regulation and urge its senators to rethink it, to apply a bit of fair play and commonsense to people who carry on a legitimate sport in Australia and who are responsible Australian citizens. All they want to do is get on with their sport without interference from an ill-conceived regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the question of Australia's membership of the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO). It is now over two years since Australia withdrew from UNIDO, the first and only country ever to do so since the organisation became a specialised agency of the United Nations system. The position of Australia vis-a-vis UNIDO has been the subject of numerous recent reviews which, to my mind, have proven beyond doubt the benefits that our country could gain from renewed membership in the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: These benefits are not only financial in that Australian industry will be fully involved in the activities and projects promoted by UNIDO, but also political in that Australia will once again be able to participate fully in the decision making process and contribute to charting the course of the organisation. All our major partners have recognised the influential and profitable role that UNIDO is playing in promoting international cooperation in the industrial sector. Indeed, it is quite abnormal that Australia should not be among the 150 member states of UNIDO.

Since taking office in September 1986, the present Director-General of UNIDO, Mr Domingo L. Siazon, Jr, has imparted a new spirit to the organisation, bringing it closer to the needs and concerns of industrial enterprises and making it more responsive to their requirements. UNIDO has now been proven to be able to provide swift and effective assistance to its member states through direct contacts not only with governments and governmental institutions but also with private sector industries and industrial associations. The renewed confidence in the organisation and in the services it can render is proven by the increasing number and importance of funding agreements signed with UNIDO by industrial companies in industrialised and developing countries alike.

Moreover, UNIDO is positioning itself to play a significant role in the United Nations system's activities for the reconstruction of the countries which suffered from the Gulf conflict. Its long experience in and association with those countries, its knowledge of their industrial structure and potential, its international status and its recognised impartiality render UNIDO a credible and respected partner in that region as well. I do not need to emphasise the significance of Australia's membership in that context.

The activities of UNIDO extend well beyond the standard concept of technical assistance. The organisation has also been very active in the field of investment promotion, development and transfer of technology and industrial studies and research. The fact that UNIDO has struck out along the right road is confirmed by the developing countries' increasing requests for UNIDO services each year. In 1990, UNIDO delivered close to $US160m worth of technical assistance and successfully promoted $US699m worth of investment projects.

Despite Australia's absence from the ranks of its member states, UNIDO has continued to involve Australian companies and institutions in its activities. Australian firms have successfully secured purchase and service contracts in respect of major UNIDO projects, especially in the Asian and Pacific regions. I have also been informed that UNIDO and Australia-specifically the Department of Industry, Trade and Technology in South Australia-are jointly organising an international conference entitled `Adding Value to Natural Resources-Petrochemicals and Minerals', which is scheduled to take place from 2 to 4 December this year in Adelaide.

I understand, and I must confess to being greatly concerned, that it is becoming increasingly difficult for UNIDO to justify to its member states the continued involvement of Australia in its programs. I would therefore request that the Government approve immediate resumption of Australia's membership of UNIDO and that the required financial resources, modest when compared to the benefit that can be derived from membership in the organisation, be allocated for that purpose as a matter of high priority. It would cost Australia something like $1.4m to renew its membership and from that we would get an investment potential in the region of $20m per annum. That $1.4m would be money well invested and we should rejoin immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 6 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) been awarded a contract to operate and maintain the Fokker F-27 aircraft registered as VH-CAT for the CSIRO; if so, (a) is this the first occasion on which the CAA has undertaken such a commercial operation, (b) what training and endorsement did CAA flight crew require to be able to undertake the contract, (c) with whom and at what cost was that training undertaken and (d) are the regulators of the aviation industry able to compete with the commercial industry as well as maintaining supervision and control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. However, the CSIRO has asked the CAA to enter into negotiations with a view to forming a contract for maintenance and operation of the F27 aircraft registered as VH-CAT.
(a) This is the first time the CAA has undertaken such a commercial operation.

(b) No training or endorsement is required for the CAA's Flying Unit to fulfil the terms of the contract. The Flying Unit's pilots already hold the necessary licence qualifications and possess the required proficiency.
(c) Not applicable, as no training is required.

(d) The CAA's policy is to make its specialist air services available on commercial terms in circumstances where industry sources cannot fulfil the requirements of the work. The CAA is also interested in assisting aviation industry operators to win business by entering into joint ventures or sub-contract arrangements, and to date this has occurred on one occasion.
It must be stressed that the Flying Unit is part of the Corporate Management Division of the CAA and has no supervisory role over the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 11 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he circulate an information paper on resource security on or about 20 February 1991; if so, (a) is the paper a restatement of the views of the National Association of Forest Industries and (b) is he the author of the paper; if not, who is the author.

(2) Does resource security entail procedures under the Australian Heritage Commission Act and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act being circumvented for certain forest sector developments; if not, what is entailed.

(3) Does the information paper referred to in part (1) state that the proposed resource security process will identify and protect the environmental and heritage values of forests; if so, how will this be achieved in any manner that is not already provided under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

(4) Would the introduction of the proposed resource security process mean that certain provisions of the Australian Heritage Act and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act would no longer apply to certain forestry developments; if so, (a) which provisions would be affected and (b) in what manner would they be affected.

(5) Would the introduction of the proposed resource security process result in State environmental and heritage laws being rendered inoperative in respect of certain forestry sector developments; if so, (a) what laws would be affected and (b) in what manner would they be affected.

(6) Does the information paper refer to``umbrella'' Commonwealth legislation; if so, will that legislation deem the provisions of Commonwealth environmental or heritage laws to have been met; if so, (a) would the provisions be met at any stage of the process and (b) at what stage would they be met.
(7) Would the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories be the appropriate Minister to administer the proposed resource security process.
(8) Is he able to say whether State forests reserved under State laws are less secure than national parks reserved under State laws.

(9) Is he able to say whether State forestry authorities have legal instruments at their disposal for the granting of secure rights to timber and pulp supplies from the forests under their control; if they do not, why not.

(10) Does the proposed resource security process include an integrated forest assessment process involving other Commonwealth and State agencies; if so, how will it avoid duplicating the work of the Resources Assessment Commission under its forests reference.

(11) Does the information paper referred to in part (1) suggest that the proposed resource security process (a) does not preclude incorporation of the outcomes from the Resource Assessment Commission and the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Groups and (b) will involve a new and enhanced role for the Australian Heritage Commission and the Environment portfolio; if so, what advantages does the proposed process offer to resource development interests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An information paper on `Resource Security' was prepared by my office in February at the request of the Government's Primary Industry and Resources Committee.
The paper prepared by my office was a background paper and not a statement of Government policy.
(2)-(11) The Government's policy on `Resource Security' was announced on March 12th. Full details are contained on pages 5.56 to 5.59 of the publication``Building a Competitive Australia''.
